summary:
A roadside bomb injured four civilians in central Baghdad early on Friday morning. Local sources said the device exploded close to Al-Khelani square, damaging several shops and cars.
It is not immediately clear what the intended target of the attack was. No group claimed responsibility.
Since the 7 March elections, low-level bombings have been a daily feature in Iraq's major cities.

summary:
A bomb exploded outside the western gate of the International Convention Centre - which houses the Constituent Assembly (CA) - at 17:00 in Kathmandu. No one was injured in the blast.
Police said they defused another socket bomb in the same place, and found pamphlets in the name of the Dynamic Youth Forum at the scene. The Dynamic Youth Forum, a previously unknown group claimed responsibility for the attack, saying it was carried out as a warning to the CA members for their failure to write a new constitution.
After the bomb, security was tightened in the area.
Nepal remains in political turmoil, after Maoist Prime Minister Prachanda resigned in May, following a dispute over the sacking of the head of the army. This sparked daily clashes between demonstrators and security forces.

summary:
Police removed two landmines, together consisting of 75kgs of explosives, from a national highway (NH-221) near Manikonta village in Errabor, Dantewada District, Chhattisgarh Province. The 30-strong bomb disposal unit and police team acted following a tip-off. Maoist Naxals, who reportedly planted the mines, fired at the police when they arrived at the scene. A 30 minute gun battle ensued until the Maoists fled. Nobody was hurt in the incident.
According to a police officer, the improvised explosive devices (IEDs) planted at two and three feet were meant to target security personnel. The police conducted further searches following information that Maoists planted more mines on the highway.
On Saturday, an IED incident in Bijapur killed eight police officers.

No group claimed the attack however the Ingush Jamaat Sharia is a likely suspect. Security forces frequently conduct counter-terror operation in the wooded areas around towns in the Caucasus where many of the militants are thought to be hiding.

At approximately 21:39 Taliban militants bombed two boys' schools in Shago village, Bajaur district, Pakistan. The assailants blew up the 21-room government high school and five-room primary school with heavy explosives overnight. No casualties were recorded.
According to a local administration official, militants have destroyed at least 60 schools in the the Bajaur district, which is located along the Afghan-Pakistan border. The official claims that these attacks are often in retaliation to military operations waged against the Taliban.

summary:
A suicide bomber dressed in army uniform detonated explosivesclose tothe governor's, Qassim Mohammed al-Fahdawi, offices in the centre of the Anbar provincial capital of Ramadi, shortly after another suicide bomber detonated explosives in a vehicle in the same place. The second attack killed 11 and injured 10. Among the injured was the governor Wassim Mohammed al-Fahdawi.Some sources claim that one of the suicide bombers was one of the governor's bodyguards. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, but Al-Qaeda in Iraq is most likely. 
This was the second of a twin suicide bombing in Ramadi, which was preceded by a suicide bomber in a vehicle. The assailants targeted the provincial governor of Anbar. Anbar province was at the heart of the Sunni Islamist insurgency following the 2003 overthrow of Saddam Hussein, but became a relatively safer place after allied forces persuaded local tribal leaders to begin supporting grassroots guard units against Al-Qaeda in 2006.
The recent increase in terrorist attacks is part of the Islamist militants' strategy to destabilise the region as Iraq's general elections in March approach.
author: Unknown author

summary:

No group claimed responsibility for the attack, although Al-Qaeda in Iraq are most likely responsible. The bombing targeted Shi'a pilgrims coming back from Karbala in al-Umal.
Over the past week there have been a number of attacks on Shi'a pilgrims during the Ashura celebrations.

summary:
An explosive device detonated at 02:30 at a downtown branch of the BBVA Banco Francés bank in Buenos Aires. The branch is located on the corner of Uruguay and Corrientes Avenue. Although there was damage to the bank's property, no one was injured.
According to police sources, some minor structural damages were reported after the explosion, which took place close to the Tribunales square.
The attack was claimed by Revolutionary Cells, an anarchist group active in the area. It claimed the attack was to show solidarity with the international hunger strike being carried out by anarchists, and to demonstrate the vulnerability of the capital and ueslessness of police forces to protect it.

summary:
Unknown assailants detonated a large roadside bomb near Dand, Kandahar that killed four Canadian soldiers and a Canadian journalist. Canadian military authorities had considered this district relatively peaceful prior to the incident and it had been the focus of Canadian counterinsurgency efforts. Afghan civilians and soldiers frequently travelled the bombed road. According to Canadian Brigadier-General Daniel Menard, commander of the coalition forces in Kandahar, the Canadian soldiers were conducting a community security patrol in order to gather information on maintaining security in the area.
While no group claimed the attack, the Taliban is suspected. Roadside bombs remain the most lethal tactic used by militants in Afghanistan.

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated his explosive vest in an attack that killed seven CIA operatives and a Jordanian intelligence officer, and wounded six others in Khost, Afghanistan. The attack occurred inside the US Forward Operating Base (FOB) Chapman, located in close proximity to the FATA tribal areas of Pakistan. The attack was carried out by a Jordanian CIA informer, Khalil Abu-Malal al-Balawi, who was being brought to the military base by his handler allegedly to disclose information about Al-Qaeda (AQ) second-in-command al-Zawahiri.
Al-Balawi, as a high-value CIA asset accompanying his Jordanian intelligence handler, was able to bypass many of the external layers of security into the base to avoid exposing his identity. At the last check where the private security team of Xe (formerly Blackwater) began inspection, he detonated his vest. The explosion killed his handler, four CIA officers and three security contractors. The vehicle shielded several other CIA operatives but at least six were injured. Among those killed were the CIA chief of the Khost base and reportedly the agency's foremost expert analyst on AQ.
Reports after the incident indicate that al-Balawi, also known as Humam Khalil Mohammed, was likely an AQ triple agent. The Jordanian intelligence service (Mukhabarat, or GID) arrested then recruited him in 2007; acting in collaboration with the CIA, the GID moved him to Pakistan then Afghanistan in an attempt to infiltrate Al-Qaeda.  Al-Balawi regularly posted anti-American essays in jihadi internet forums under the name Abu Dujana al-Khorasani and passed information to the CIA about mid-low level AQ operatives in the area. It is unclear if al-Balawi was ever a genuine asset to the CIA, but at some point in the last year he apparently approached the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and the Afghan Taliban to work with them against the CIA and GID.
Both Afghan and Pakistani Taliban groups, as well as Al-Qaeda initially claimed responsibility for the attack. Due to the location, it is not far fetched to suggest that the Haqqani network may also have cooperated. However, a posthumous video aired on Pakistan television on 9 January purportedly showed al-Balawi with TTP leader Hakimullah Mehsud. In the video he claimed that the attack was to avenge the killing of Baitullah Mehsud, and said that all jihadists must attack US targets.
The attack was the most deadly against CIA personnel since the 1983 Beirut bombing. However, despite the severity of the attack, the bombing appears less the result of an intentional long-term operation than the result of a lucky break for the TTP that the group then skillfully orchestrated. The incident marked two important points: that the TTP's skills have been underestimated, and that the cooperation networks of the various jihadi groups in the region are also perhaps stronger that previously assumed.
source_urls: BBC Monitoring, AP, StratFor, Reuters, Al Jazeera

summary:
Unidentified gunmen attacked a convoy of four vehicles carrying candidates, members and supporters of the opposition Nationalista Party in Ilocos Norte province in the northern Philippines. One local politician was killed and six other people were wounded in the attack. Hours later another candidate running for vice-mayor in Taganaan was murdered outside his home by another unknown gunman on a motorcycle.
No group claimed either attack; the police believed the incidents were politically motivated, however other reasons such as business conflicts were also considered possible. The Philippines has experienced a significant surge in such attacks on politicians and candidates in the past month in the run-up to the May 2010 elections.

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated hisexplosives during a Shiite Ashura procession in downtown Karachi. The attack killed at least 43 people and wounded at least 60. According to Pakistani officials the bomber was tackled by a Pakistani soldier before he could reach the center of the procession. Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack. Riots broke out immediately following the blast.
Pakistani officials increased security in the lead up to and during the Shiite holiday of Ashura. Despite these efforts three attacks on Shiite religious gatherings occurred during the holiday. Though the attacks are not directly connected, they are indicative of the growing sectarian tensions that have increased instability and violence in Pakistan.

summary:
On 27 December, a bomb detonated outside of theEthniki insurance building in central Athens. Theexplosion did notcause any injuries but it caused serious damage to the ground floor of the building where a branch of the National Bank of Greece is also located.
The incidentoccurred in the evening at about23:00. According to police reports,the device containedaboutthreekgsof dynamite, whichthe assailants had placed outside the building located in Neos Cosmos toward the northern end of Syngrou Avenue. Police had sealed off the area immediately surrounding the building after an anonymous warning was given to the Eleftherotypia daily newspaper 15 minutes before the explosion.
Greek security services initially believed that the Revolutionary Struggle were responsible for the bombing. However, the Conspiracy Nuclei of Fire (CNF) later released an online communiqué claiming responsibility for the attack. In the communiqué, the group said that it had attacked the company to protest against the "Christmas consumer spirit" and excessive display of wealth.
Over the past three months, CNF has carried out a number of targeted attacks against the homes of the Minister of Economy, Competitiveness, Shipping and former Minister of Education Marietta Giannakou in central Athens.

summary:
Suspected militants blew up a 300-line digital telephone exchange in the Khyber agency of Pakistan's north-western tribal region. Unidentified men planted explosives around the building in Baz Garhai area of Bara subdivision during the night. The explosion destroyed most parts of the building, according to a local official.
Government installations, such as the telephone exchange, have been targeted with growing frequency in the region since the army launched an operation against a local group, Lashkar-e-Islam. However, school buildings have been the main target of these attacks.
Two banned armed Islamic groups, Lashkar-e-Islam and Ansarul Islam and been fighting each other in Khyber for the last few years.

summary:
A late-night explosion occurred in the Hezbollah-controlled Beirut suburb of Dahiya. Initial reports suggested there were three bombs detected under the car of Hamas official Abu Imad al-Rifaai that then detonated as guards worked to diffuse them. The explosion, caused by 30 pounds of TNT planted in an underground office used by Hamas, killed two junior members and wounded two others. A senior Lebanese security official said details of what happened remained unclear, in part because Hezbollah prevented investigators from visiting the bomb site in the immediate aftermath of the explosion.
Some media reported that the targets may have included top Hamas officials Osama Hamden or Ali Barakeh, however security officials refused to speculate on the intended target or who was responsible. Though the attack happened in a Hezbollah-controlled district, Hamas appeared to have been the target. Lebanese President Suleiman said the attack was an attempt by Lebanon's enemies to destabilize the country in the wake of an easing of tensions between the Western-backed government and the Shiite militant group Hezbollah.
Bombings and assassinations are common in divided Lebanon; few are ever solved conclusively. However, a series of recent attacks appear to have targeted Iranian proxies Hezbollah and Hamas.
source_urls: Wall Street Journal, CNN, ESISC, Reuters

summary:

The convoy made up of several trucks was on its way to take part in an anti-terrorist operation in this area. Several other bombs had either exploded or been defused in the Tizi Ouzou area over the previous few days.

summary:
Airline passenger Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab attempted to detonate explosives hidden in his lap twenty minutes before Northwest Flight 253 was scheduled to land in Detroit, Michigan. At about 12:00 passengers reportedly heard a popping noise and smelled smoke. Passengers around Abdulmutallab rushed to subdue him and put out the fire he had started to ignite the concealed explosives. The failed explosion injured the suspect as well as another passenger.
According to a federal indictment the bomb Abdulmutallab allegedly hid in his underwear contained pentaerythritol tetranitrate, the explosive known as PETN, and triacetone triperoxide, or TATP. These explosives failed to detonate when Adbulmutallab ignited them.
According to officials, Abdulmutallab, a 23 year-old Nigerian engineering student, admitted he was an AQ agent, and that he had gotten the explosives in Yemen during his initial interrogation. Days later in an internet statement, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed the attack stating it was retaliation for the US attacks targeting AQAP in Yemen. The statement added that it provided the Nigerian suspect with a technically-advanced device, which failed to go off due to a technical error. How strong the association is between the suspect and AQAP is suspect, however.
Officials believe that Abdulmutallab was first radicalized in London, where he lived from 2005 to 2008 while he studied at University College of London. His links to Yemen are believed to stem from a summer trip to Sanaa in 2005.
Abdulmutallab was already in a law enforcement-intelligence database after his father contacted the Nigerian US embassy over worrying text messages he received from his son in Yemen. Abdulmutallab was denied entry into the UK but was not on the US government's "no-fly" list. Reports also suggest that the CIA and NSA had intercepted Al-Qaeda conversations concerning a Nigerian operative who would enter the US to carry out terrorist attacks. The US intelligence community drew great criticism and skepticism for its perceived failures on the incident.
On 6 January 2010 a federal grand jury officially indicted Abdulmutallab on 6 criminal counts, including attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction and attempted murder.
The incident has raised security levels at airports worldwide.
perpetrators: Saudi Arabia:Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP):Global Islamist

The subsequent fire damaged the building but resulted in no injuries.
The group claimed the attack was in support of the ongoing anarchist hunger strike. While police sources did not confirm this specific attack, media reports did confirm a wave of anarchist attacks in December on foreign-owned banks, a trucking company and other sites in Mexico City.

summary:
Two simultaneous bombs exploded fifteen minutes apart from one another at a bus station in Hillah, the capital of the Babil province at approximately 14:00. No known group claimed responsibility for the act, which killed 13 people and injured 74 others. At the scene, witnesses found a wrecked car and a pair of blood-covered slippers. Authorities later discovered that a provincial councilman and hotel physician Dr. Mohammed al-Zurfi were among those killed in the explosions. They released no further details.
Cities throughout Iraq have experienced a number of attacks linked to the Shiite Ashoura festival taking place. Over this time religious pilgrims have been significantly targeted.

summary:
Unknown assailants detonated an explosive device in a Karbala restaurant, killing one person and wounding five other individuals.
The timing of this incident coincides with the upcoming religious observance of the martyrdom of the Prophet Mohammed's grandson during the battle of Karbala in A.D. 680. This event is one of the main factors that lead to the schism between the Shia and Sunni denominations. Iraqi authorities assert that today's bombings are an attempt to incite sectarian violence.
No group claimed the attack.

summary:
Two soldiers and three civilians were injured when unidentified insurgents detonated a homemade bomb hidden in a motorcycle parked outside a grocery store near the Bannang Sata police station in Narathiwat. The explosion occurred at 10:35 on the Sukhayang Road about 20 metres away from the police station. Allegedly a woman arrived on the motorcycle with a child and parked the motorcycle and walked away to a nearby soi. The bomb exploded shortly afterwards.
No group claimed the attack however Gerakan Mujahedin Islami Pattani (GMIP) is a possible suspect.

summary:
Terrorists from the Animal Liberation Front claimed they left an explosive device outside a BBVA bank branch in the Ecatepec area of Mexico City. The device involved dynamite. According to the group's website, it had planted a similar device outside a building belonging to the Kenworth company, also in Ecatepec. Both explosions allegedly damaged some windows but incurred no casualties, typical of most anarchist and eco-terrorist attacks.
While police sources did not confirm the incident, media have commented on a series of anarchist and eco-terrorist attacks in December in Mexico, particularly around Mexico City.

The explosion slightly damaged the exterior of the building but there were no other casualties. The attack was one of two simultaneous bombings of bank branches of the morning.
Later an anarchist group by the name of Conspira 1970 claimed the double attack, claiming that the group was inspired by Simon Radowitzky, a Ukrainian-born anarchist that carried out attacks in Argentina and Mexico in the early 20th century.

summary:
A suicide bomber carrying a horse-drawn cart full of explosives detonated hisexplosives outside of a guesthouse in Kandahar. The incidentkilled eight civiliansand wounded three others. Afghan police officials initially attempted to stop the suicide bomber from entering the hotel, but upon failing to pay heed to their warnings, authorities opened fire in an attempt to prevent entry.
The bomber succeeded in exploding his device and killed five passers by in a nearby car, as well as three pedestrians. Authorities believed the perpetrator was affiliated with the Taliban insurgency but were unsure of the precise target. Foreigners are known to frequent the local guesthouse where the attack occurred.

summary:
The last of several attacks on Shiite pilgrims in Baghdad took place in the western part of the city. The pilgrims had gathered to prepare for Ashoura rituals. The explosion killed one pilgrim and wounded eight others. No group claimed the attack but Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected.
The bombs targeting Christians and Shiite Muslims in total killed at least eight people and wounded four dozen before coinciding religious observances that were to take place under heavy guard. Insurgents have routinely targeted Shiites and Christians in an attempt to undermine the country's security gains and its Shiite-dominated government. Security forces in recent days have been concerned that the Shiite holy observances known as Ashoura and Christmas gatherings would be targeted by large-scale attacks.
Insurgents have routinely targeted pilgrims on their way to the southern holy city of Karbala during Ashoura. More than 25,000 Iraqi police and soldiers have been assigned to protect pilgrims.

summary:
In the first of several attacks, a bomb exploded targeting the Mar Toma church (Church of St. Thomas) in Mosul. The bomb was hidden under sacks of baking flour in a handcart left 15 yards from the church. The explosion killed two people and wounded five others. The blast also damaged doors, windows and the walls of the 1,200 year-old church. The attack occurred in an area where streets have been closed to vehicles to protect Mosul's dwindling Christan population.
Iraqi defense officials warned earlier in the week that intelligence reports pointed to attacks during Christmas, leading the government to step up security near churches and Christian neighborhoods.
The bombs targeting Christians and Shiite Muslims in total killed at least eight people and wounded four dozen before coinciding religious observances that will take place under heavy guard. Insurgents have routinely targeted Shiites and Christians in an attempt to undermine the country's security gains and its Shiite-dominated government. Security forces in recent days have been concerned that the Shiite holy observances known as Ashoura and Christmas gatherings would be targeted by large-scale attacks.

Construction-related targets, particularly roads, have been a high priority target for the Taliban as it is one of the easiest ways to impede government and coalition forces movements and ability to control areas.

The shells destroyed the building as well. No group claimed the attack, but either Hizbul Islam or Al-Shabaab are suspected. Al-Shabaab has frequently issued threats against media outlets in Somalia.
In the ongoing battles in Mogadishu, the warring parties point accusing fingers at one another for the death of innocent civilians.

summary:
Unknown gunmen shot and killed Ali Jama'a Amay, a prominent security officer for the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) in Beledwenye. Amay was also a prominent community member in the Hiiraan region. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however Al-Shabaab has issued many threats towards the WFP and other UN authorities in Somalia. Its Islamist rival, Hizbul Islam, arrived following the attack and vowed to find and punish the group responsible.
Somalia is one of the most dangerous places for aid workers. Terrorist and insurgents routinely target aid workers in killing and kidnappings. The defunct central government is unable to provide any kind of meaningful security or order outside the capital, leaving the terrorist and insurgent groups to police themselves.

summary:
A suspected Pakistani Taliban suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a club for journalists in the north-west city of Peshawar. A policeman, a Peshawar Press Club worker and a female passer-by were killed in the attack, while 17 others, including a group of journalists, were wounded.
The bomber was reportedly stopped from entering the building by a police official, who stopped him at the gate and blew himself up. The guard room, three motorcycles and a bus on the other side of the road were reportedly all damaged. All the windows of the Peshawar Press Club were reportedly shattered.
The media and journalists in general have been targeted in numerous attacks and Peshawar has been particularly hard hit. More than 200 have been killed in the past 3 months. Hundreds more people have been killed in attacks across the country since the army operation began in the autumn.
targets: Civilians/General Public; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Media/Journalists

summary:
A man tried to bomb the Logemo House in the Onipanu area of Lagos, however the improvised explosive device went off prematurely at about 14:00. The severely injured assailant stated that he had been sent by someone to plant the explosives at the office of the most senior officer at the Super Screen Television Station office. According to police the explosive was wrapped as a Christmas gift and exploded on the fourth floor of the nine-storey building, essentially used for commercial purposes.
Police also carried out a search at the suspect's residence, where more explosive items were recovered and defused. They did not release any information on the suspected mastermind of the attack or motives.

The Republic’s Ministry of Internal Affairs stated that the gunmen approached his house in a vehicle and shot him dead while he was standing at the gate. No group claimed the attack, whcih could equally be criminal or terrorism-related.
The escalation of the conflict in Northern Caucasus over the past months, particularly in Dagestan, Ingushetia and Chechnya, is well indicated by the increasing number of assassination attempts made on police officers and security forces members that occur almost daily.

The slain official, Hussein Akrash, was affiliated with the country's largest Sunni political party, the Iraqi Islamic Party, and was a member of the Turkmen minority. Akrash was driving in a nine-vehicle convoy to a funeral when the attack occurred.
The insurgency, dominated by Sunni Arabs, has often targeted minority groups in addition to officials seen as collaborators with the Shiite-led government.

summary:
A bomb exploded during a tribal gathering in the Al-Mahfad area of Abyan Governorate, southern Yemen. The explosion killed two people and wounded three others. No group claimed the attack.
Tribal leaders were discussing a possible resumption of the armed struggle against the government following the recent air raid against suspected Al-Qaeda (AQ) members in the area that also prompted many angry demonstrations over the weekend. Many tribes have accused the Yemeni army of having killed civilians during the raids.
The bombing again highlights the precarious state of the Yemeni government facing Shiite Zaidi rebels, in the north, local insurgency and terrorism.

summary:
Unidentified assailants opened fire on a bus transporting Syrian labourers to Lebanon on the road between Tripoli and Akkar in northern Lebanon, killing one Syrian and injuring 13 others. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, however it occurred one day after Lebanese Prime Minister Saad al-Hariri completed his two-day visit to Damascus for negotiations with his Syrian counterpart Bashar al-Assad.
While Syrians have not frequently experienced such attacks, the number of incidents linked to Syria has increased. On 3 December there was an explosion on an Iranian bus allegedly carrying Shiite pilgrims;although the government officially ruled out terrorism, the investigation revealed conflicting details. Four days later a terrorist cell was dismantled in Majdel Anjar, near the Syrian border.
Moreover, there have been recent allegations of Al-Qaeda (AQ) elements, such as the group Jund Al-Sham, hiding over the Syrian border to launch attacks in the “Bilad el-Sham” (greater Syria: Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and Palestine). Such incidents suggest an increased scale of threat in the region.

The Colombian security authorities were quick to blame FARC. According to the local press, the governor had requested additional security arrangements, as he feared FARC would target him.

summary:
Suspected Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) terrorists detonated a bomb at the newly-repaired 'Salam (peace) Bridge' near Indanan town in the southern Philippines. The 10:00 bombing was the third of the morning for Sulu province. The bridge is located near the MNLF camp in the village of Bato-Bato and has frequently been targeted by insurgents. The military authorities suspected members of the MNLF group led by Tahil Sali.
The military reported that the MNLF was trying to disrupt ongoing US and Filipino armed forces projects in Indanan by sabotaging the bridge. The Salam Bridge was repaired last month by the provincial engineer’s office after it collapsed following the Abu Sayyaf bombing in October.

There were no reported casualties but all six soldiers were wounded in the incident.

Allegedly five Taliban armed with rifles, rocket launchers, grenades, and two suicide vests seized a building near police headquarters with the aim of storming headquarters. However they were intercepted by police.
According to the governor's spokesman the fight lasted two hours; the two Taliban suicide bombers were killed when fired upon, and 12 people were injured, including four policemen, a NATO soldier, and seven civilians. The Taliban claimed the aim of the operation was to remind the international community that parliament and the Afghan government were not in control.
Eastern Afghanistan has seen some of the worst violence by the Taliban.

summary:
An Iraqi oil ministry spokesman reported that a 55km section of an oil pipeline en-route to the Turkish port of Ceyhan was attacked. The damage caused a large oil spill around 325km north of Baghdad. The oil exports from northern Iraq were stopped completely.
The spokesman announced the company's request for multinational forces to carry out morepatrols to protect the pipeline, which was sabotaged for the fourthtime in six weeks. After an 18 month period of calm, oil pipelines became targets again on October 26. The attack comes as new contracts for the exploitation of oil fields were awarded to international consortiums in Iraq's second auction since 2003.
Future sabotage attacks are expected, particularly in the north.

summary:
Seven people have died and dozens wounded after exchange of heavy shelling between AU peacekeepers and insurgents in Mogadishu. Most of the dead were at Mogadishu's Bakaara market and other parts of the Somali capital. Radical Islamists launched a mortar attack at a former police academy where the national police day ceremony was being marked. It is unclear whether government officials were injured in the attacks by insurgents but sources have confirmed that AU peacekeepers retaliated with shelling.
Separately, fierce fighting between AU backing government forces and insurgents erupted in Mogadishu's Hodan District resulting in the death of two civilians and injuring two others. Meanwhile, stray shells are said to have hit the Radio Shabeelle building in Mogadishu, though there were no reports of casualties.
The attacks come in the wake of recent Somali government announcement that it will launch offensive against insurgents in Mogadishu.

summary:
Members of the Movement for Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) claimed an attack on a pipeline owned by Shell and Chevron near Abonnema, in the Niger Delta. According to a spokesman of the rebel group, some 35 men armed with assault rifles, rocket launchers and machine guns attacked the pipeline at around 02:00.

MEND had warned in November that the ceasefire and peace negotiations were threatened by the activities of the Nigerian military in the Delta. According the MEND spokesman, the indefinite ceasefire ordered by the group on 25 October will be reviewed within thirty days from 19 December.

summary:
A suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) suicide bomber detonated a car packed with explosives in Taimergara, Lower Dir District at Friday prayers killing eleven and wounding 27. The driver rammed the vehicle into the front gates of the town mosque as people gathered there for Friday prayers. A police headquarters located beside the mosque was also badly damaged in the blast.
The attack came several days after the Pakistani Army announced that its operations against extremist militants in South Waziristan were coming to an end. The intensive TTP bombing campaign of the last 2 months was in response to continued Army offensives against militant strongholds in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA).

summary:

The explosion occurred as a military convoy was passing the check point and Russian news reports claim there were at least 18 police officers and civilians wounded in the explosion. Police reported that the explosive device in the car consisted of between 20-40kg of TNT. There was no indication as to who conducted the attack, however the Ingush Jamaat Sharia is suspected.
Suicide attacks are traditionally rare in the North Caucasus, so their occurrence may be a marker of shifting tactics amongst the militants in the region.

summary:
A bomb partially exploded about 03:00 at the Bocconi University in Milan. According to police the bomb consisted of two kilogrammes of dynamite and would have caused significant damage. There were no reported casualties from the partial explosion.
The attack was claimed by an anarchist group that left fliers at the scene that said: 'Operations Eat the Rich'. Bocconi is a prestigious private university and one the the top business schools in the world.
The incident occurred less than 24 hours since another anarchist attack in Friuli-Venezia Giulia by the same group. Several sources attribute the rise in anarchist activity to increasing tensions across Italy.

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated a large device in a crowded market in Dera Ghazi Khan, Pakistan killed 23 people and injured at least 60. The bomb exploded at a taxi stand outside of the residence of the Sardar Zulfiqar Ali Khan Khosa, the senior adviser to the chief minister of Punjab Province. Khosa was not at home during the attack. The bomb caused extensive local damage. Security officials attribute the attack to Taliban insurgents in the area. The insurgents are thought to be retaliating against the Pakistani military for the offensive in South Waziristan.
There are growing concerns that Taliban insurgents are using Dera Ghazi Khan as a base to expand their operations in Punjab province, due to its location on the border with North-West Frontier Province. In November authorities confiscated a truck laden with more than 60 tons of explosives when it entered Dera Ghazi Khan from NWFP.

summary:
A suspected Taliban suicide car bomber blew himself up in a car full of explosives near the gate of the Heeta Hotel in Kabul's Wazir Akbar Khan district. Some witnesses reported that the terrorist slowly drove up to the gate while the hotel's finance manager reported that the attack was 30 meters down the road from the hotel entrance. The morning explosion killed at least eight people and wounded 40 more. Several nearby homes and buildings were damaged by the explosion.
The target of the attack was not immediately clear as the hotel is in the main diplomatic district and houses many government officials and international organisations. Moreover, the attack seemed timed to coincide with an expected visit of President Karzai and many diplomats to the area for an anti-corruption conference at the Afghan Foreign Ministry. Security officials at the scene reported that they believed the bomber was targeting the home of former first VP, Ahmad Zia Massoud. Furthermore, the blast injured many Indian nationals who worked at the guest house next door.
No group claimed the attack although the Taliban has recently carried out several attacks against government targets and hotels used by foreigners in Kabul. Since the attack on the UN guesthouse on 28 October, the UN has relocated 600 non-essential staff outside of Afghanistan.

summary:

Unknown assailants blew up a government grils' primary school in Landi Kotal, Khyber Agency in northwest Pakistan. There were no reported casualties from the overnight attack that destroyed two rooms and the veranda of the building. No group claimed responsibility however elements sympathetic to the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) are suspected. The TTP has destroyed hundreds of schools, especially girls' schools, in the northwestern region over the past two years.
This was the first attack of its kind in the Landi Kotal area; the other targeted schools have been primarily in the Bara area, perhaps indicating an expanding TTP operational area. Another grils' school was blown up in another part of Khyber on the same night.

No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, however the region was a previous Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) strong hold.

summary:
Security forces found two primary explosive devices along a section of the Mozdok-Tbilisi gas pipeline in the Sredniye Achaluki settlement of Ingushetia's Malgobeksky region. Police also discovered several booby-trap mines consisting of grenades. The night-time discovery of the explosives forced the closure of gas transit facilities in North Ossetia and Ingushetia until security officials finished defusing the devices the following morning, cutting off gas to Armenia in the process. The pipeline reopened and full service was restored on 14 Dec.
No group claimed responsibility but the Ingush Jamaat Sharia is suspected. This was the fourth recent attack on a gas pipeline in the North Caucasus, most frequently targeted by radical Islamist separatists in the region.Groups such as the Caucasus Emirate have openly stated their intention to target Russian infrastructure as a means of fighting the 'occupation'. Moreover, the Mozdok-Tblisi pipeline is one of the major gas lines into Georgia and is a source of significant tension between Russia and Georgia, perhaps further indicating a possible motive for the attack if the result was to destabilise Russian interests.

summary:
Police defused two bombs placed outside of the Greek media pension fund (ETAP-MME) in the Neos Kosmos district of central Athens. Each of the bombs contained one kilogramme of explosive but faulty wiring prevented them from detonating. Police had received an anonymous phone call warning of an eminent explosion before the devices were discovered. No group claimed the attempted attack.
The ETAP-MME fund was created in 2008 with a controversial pensions cost-cutting reform initiated by the previous conservative government that sparked strong union opposition and general strikes. The new socialist government has also stated that it will again reform the pensions system, which the unions have again warned that they will oppose. It is possible the motives for the bombs are linked to these political developments.
The incident comes at a time when tensions are high over the one-year anniversary of the accidental killing of a student by security forces which witnessed mass violent demonstrations throughout the country.

summary:
Two suspected Islamist militants on a motorcycle shot into a restaurant in the Paluru area of Sungai Padi district, Narathiwat in southern Thailand. The assailants then set off a remote-controlled bomb hidden in a second motorcycle. The estimated weight of the bomb was five kilogrammes. The nighttime explosion killed three civilians and wounded nine others, two of whom later died from their injuries.
No group claimed the attack but any of Thailand's radical separatist groups could be responsible. Police later reported that the latest violence was believed to be the work of a group run by Amran Ming who is wanted over a string of bombings and attacks in Narathiwat. Ming is the leader of the RKK, a subsidiary of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-coordinate (BRN-C).
The attack came as part of a series of bombings in Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat provinces over two days that accompanied the joint visit of the Prime Ministers of Malaysia and Thailand to the volatile southern region. At least 13 people were killed and 24 injured since 7 December. Security measures have also been tightened on the passenger train services in the south because of the high risk of attacks.

summary:
About 10:25 a car bomb detonated targeting a police patrol at the Technical College checkpoint in the Doura district of Baghdad. It was one of series of significant car bombs that went off in quick succession throughout Baghdad at 10:25. The Doura bombing is reported to have killed three policemen working at the checkpoint and 12 students who were passing by.
According to police the attacks primarily targeted government institutions, including the labour, finance and interior ministries, a court house and a training academy for judges near the Al-Nidaa mosque. Other bombs went off at Shourja market near the health ministry, as well as the institute of fine arts.
At least 112 people were killed and roughly 448 wounded in the series of bomb attacks. The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed the attacks on 9 December.
The bombings came two days after the Iraqi parliament passed a new electoral law paving the way for parliamentary elections on 6 March 2010. They are the third multi-car bomb attack in the city since August, all aimed at government buildings.
source_urls: AP, Times online, Al Jazeera, BBC

summary:
A series of car bombs detonated in quick succession throughout central Baghdad, almost all hitting government targets. The explosions began about 10:25. According to police sources two car bombs exploded near the labour and interior ministries, another targeted a training academy for judges near the Al-Nidaa mosque, a fourth detonated at a police patrol in Dora district outside the Technical College, and a fifth car bomb went off at the Cassation Court. Other targets included the Shourja market near the health ministry, the institute of fine arts and the Rafaidyen Bank in the green zone that was acting as the finance ministry.
At least 112 people were killed and roughly 448 wounded in the series of bomb attacks. The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed the attack on 9 December. ISI is a Sunni umbrella organization linked to Al-Qaeda (AQ) which had claimed similar high-scale attacks in Baghdad in August and October.
Certain aspects of the attacks drew notice: one, there was widespread suspicion that Iraqi security forces had been infiltrated, either by taking bribes to allow insurgents to mount the attacks, or by colluding with militants to undermine Maliki before the March general election. And two, the attacks also suggested a shift in tactics by militants away from softer targets like mosques and markets.
The bombings came two days after the Iraqi parliament passed a new electoral law paving the way for parliamentary elections on 6 March 2010. They are the third multi-car bomb attack in the city since August, all aimed at government buildings.

summary:
Multiple assailants, suspected members of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), attacked an ISI office in Multan, Pakistan. One of the assailants used a rocket launcher to fire towards the ISI complex on Qasim Bela road, followed by others throwing grenades. In the subsequent confusion, police believed that the terrorists then drove a car into the ISI complex where at least two suicide bombers detonated their bombs.
The building was severely damaged and at least 12 people were killed during the attack, 25 wounded. The attack came within one day of twin bombings in Lahore, and a suicide attack outside a court in Peshawar. Also of note is that the attack took place in Prime Minister Gilan's constituency.
The TTP has launched an unprecedented wave of deadly attacks, largely presumed as retaliation for the military offensive in Waziristan. Most of the attacks in recent weeks occurred in the FATA and NWFP areas, particularly Peshawar. However the larger attacks of the last two days were in Punjab province, closer to Pakistan's main government institutions. Intelligence authorities believed that future attacks would generally follow this trend of targeting more central institutions.
If the attack was carried out by the TTP, it would also further underscore its expanding operational range in Pakistan, likely with the cooperation of other radical jihadist groups in the country such as the Lashkar-I-Jhangvi (LJ).

Police believed that FARC's Teofilo Forero unit was behind the attack and that it was possible the attack was in retaliation for the arrest of Ortiz, a senior commander from the same Southern Bloc, the group mostly active in the Huila and Caqueta areas. In recent months AQIM has multiplied its attacks on banks, primarily in Morocco but also in Mauritania. The explosion killed approximatley nine people, three of them police, and injured up to 49 more.
Peshawar has been a regular target of the TTP and the hardest hit areas of the country since the Pakistani military operation started in the Waziristan region. The string of attacks in the city over the past month are unprecedented; more than 207 people have been killed in the city since early October.

According to the police the first bomb detonated in front of a bank and the second exploded in front of a police station 30 meters away. At least one was thought to be a suicide bomber. The explosions also started a fire. A total of 48 people were killed in the incident and more than 100 injured.
No group claimed the attack though it bared the hallmarks of recent Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) attacks in Islamabad, Peshawar, and Rawalpindi. The TTP do not tend to choose to claim attacks with high civilian casualties. The incident highlights the increased targeting of the civilian population in Pakistan's major cities. The attacks suggest the TTP's desire to prove its capacity to act everywhere despite the ongoing military offensive in South Waziristan.

summary:
A large explosion occurred in the morning in the Sayyida Zeinab district of central Damascus. According to Syria's Interior Ministry, the explosion occurred while a bus carrying Iranian tourists refueled at a petrol station approximately 500 metres away from the al-Sayyida Zeinab shrine, a popular Iranian pilgrimage site.
Initial reports from several witnesses suggested that a bomb may have caused the blast and that up to six people were killed and a dozen injured. They noted the possibility of an attack on Iranian pilgrims, or links to the visit by Saeed Jalilee, Iranian national security adviser and chief nuclear negotiator, meeting in Damascus that day.
However the Syrian Interior Ministry officially ruled out a terrorist attack and denied that the bus carried any pilgrims. It reported that the bus had been empty, that the explosion came from a burst tyre, and that the three people killed were the bus driver and two petrol station workers. It stated there were no further injuries. However, the official account that it was not an attack preceded official investigations to establish the facts, and so may be lacking credibility.
On the one hand, bomb explosions in a country with such tight security control are rare, and an explosion at a petrol station while a large vehicle refueled would probably have inflicted more damage. On the other hand, such attacks have occurred. In September 2008 a suicide car-bomb blamed on Sunni militant group Fatah al-Islam killed at least 17 people in the outskirts of Damascus. Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) has also been steadily increasing its presence in Syria over the past year. Moreover, images released from the site seemed to indicate something larger than a burst-tyre, and at least one Syrian journalist on-site stated there had been an explosion on the bus while the driver and his assistant conducted repairs at the back of it.
The conflicting details of the incident between state-run media and other reports give reason to suspect a possible terrorist attack despite the official statements.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Seven civilians were also killed in the attack and 15 others were wounded. No group claimed responsibility for the attack however, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is thought to be responsible.

The bomb exploded near the main electricity generator used by the station because of the power rationing that Ecuador has been managing since early November. Police reported no casualties or material damage.
No group claimed the attack but it comes amid an intense national political debate over a controversial communications bill which several media outlets have criticized because they argue it restricts freedom of expression. The station is also known for being critical towards the government of President Correa, suggesting a possible motivation for the attack.
This is the second attack near the television station in roughly eight months.

summary:

The bomber was a Danish citizen of Somali descent. The hotel was hosting a graduation ceremony for medical, engineering and computer science students from Benadir University that several ministers were attending. The explosion killed several civilians, journalists, and the Minister of Health, the Minister of Education, the Minister of Higher Education, and critically injured the Minister of Sport. At least 40 were injured.
There was no claim of responsibility for the attack and Al-Shabaab denied the allegations made against it. However Al-Shabaab remains the dominant militant group in the city and region, and has conducted similar attacks in recent months including the killing of 30 people in an explosion in June which also claimed the life of the Somali Security Minister. Al-Shabaab likely denied responsibility because of the large number of civilian casualties who it does not want to alienate in its war against the transitional government.

The attack is the latest in a string against military and civilian targets in or near the capital city. The series of TTP attacks are largely considered retaliatory for the ongoing military operation 'Rah-e-Nejat' (Path of Salvation) in the South Waziristan region.

The CPI-M has not formally claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
40 suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) terrorists blew up a girl's school in the Wer Mamond division of the Bajaur tribal area in northwestern Pakistan. According to witnesses the militants came into the Tani area and planted explosives in the school.
Wer Mamond is a stronghold of the militants and educational institutions in the area have been closed for the past three months fearing terrorist attacks. More than 60 schools have been destroyed in the Bajaur area so far.

summary:
Unknown gunmen driving a civilian vehicle fired at municipal council member Waddah Sa'di Salih al-Ubaydi in front of his house in the Al-Ghazaliyah neighbourhood of western Baghdad. He was killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility.
Political leadership in Baghdad and other cities in Iraq have suffered increasing numbers of assassination attempts in the past months since US forces departed from urban areas in June. Most are attributed to Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), though criminal, tribal and ethnic tensions have played a measurable role as well.

The US consulate in Al-Hillah has been frequently targeted by militant groups.

summary:
Police at the Sana'a International Airport arrested a would-be hijacker of a Yemenia airplane destined for Cairo. The 24-year old man was arrested after security found a grenade and a loaded firearm in his bag. The man confessed to the failed hijack saying the attempt was made for personal reasons. However, because the man was from Sa'dah, links to the Houthi / Zaidi rebellion in northern Yemen were not ruled out.
Police continued their investigations. If successful the incident would have been the first ever hijacking recorded in Yemen.

specific_target: School used as election poll station
summary:
Unidentified assailants detonated a bomb at a school in Lempira, western Honduras. The school was to be used as a voting station on the 29 November presidential election. There were no reported injuries from the explosion and no claim of responsibility. Police believed the attack was made to intimidate voters from participating in the elections.
The attack was one of three bombings in the country linked to the elections that day.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified assailants detonated a bomb on a street in the commercial zone of San Pedro Sula, northern Honduras. Some reports indicated the attack was carried out at a school that was to be used as a voting centre, but this remained unconfirmed. There were no reported injuries from the explosion.
Honduras has experienced a marked rise in low-level bombings, frequently homemade devices, over the past weeks largely considered linked to the presidential elections to be held on 29 November. As a city San Pedro Sula was considered a Zeyala-party stronghold, possibly indicating the motivation behind the attack.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) terrorists blew up a government-run girls high school in Kari Gar village, the Khyber tribal district. The two explosions destroyed the 18-room school and wounded four civilians in their nearby homes.
Taliban-linked elements have destroyed hundreds of schools, especially for girls, throughout the semi-autonomous tribal belt along the Afghan border.

summary:
Suspected Taliban members detonated a bomb hidden inside a trashcan in the center of Kabul. The Interior Ministry spokesman described the device as a sound bomb, designed to make a loud noise rather than cause serious damage. A nearby wall was damaged in the explosion but there were no reported casualties.
The explosion went off in the Wazir Akbar Khan district, allegedly the city's most secure, that houses many embassies and foreign companies. Many bombs have gone off in the area over the past year.

summary:
27 people were killed and over 90 others wounded in a Nevsky Express train crash, which the Russian authorities said was caused by a terrorist attack. It was the largest terrorist attack in Russia but outside of the North Caucasus in five years.
Indications that the incident was a terrorist attack stemmed from a crater discovered near the railway track and passengers reportedly heard a loud bang just before the derailment. The driver also reported an explosion under the locomotive, and a large quantity of smoke filling the train immediately after the crash. Remnants of an explosive device were also found at the scene,a spokesman for theofficialinvestigative committee said. Intelligence services believed the explosion was made from a device equivalent to 7kg of TNT. Hours later a second lesser-explosion went off by remote control during the clean-up that injured several investigators, including the head of the Prosecutor's office.
The primary attack occurred at night while the train was travelling on one of the busiest rail routes in Russia, between Moscow and St.Petersburg. The Nevsky Express is a luxury train popular with tourists, business executives and government officials; investigators consider the attack to be on the 'elite' as the train service has increasingly been used to transfer parts of government functions to St. Petersburg. The attack occurred nearthe town of Bologoye, on the border between the Tver and Novgorod regions. Among the dead were several ranking government and local officials.
The same train service was bombed by Chechen terrorists two years before, in an attack that injured 27 people. The attack has been claimed by both Combat-18, a little-known Russian nationalist group, and by the 'Caucasian Mujahedin', part of the militant group Caucasus Emirate led by Chechen Dokka Umarov. The latter appears the more credible claim, and its letter threatened further attacks on Russian infrastructure.
The claim of responsibility highlights that the terrorist threats in the North Caucasus are no longer solely part of a Chechen agenda, and that radical Islamist motivations have become increasingly integrated across the various republics.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Caucasus Emirate, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Adyl-Kerim Tsechoev, the police chief of Karabulak, Ingushetia was killed by a bomb placed underneath his official car on Ulitsa Gubina in Ordzhonikidzevskaya. The blast also injured a bystander. Tsechoev was injured in the explosion and died from his wounds in hospital.
The Investigations Committee under the Russian prosecutor's office reported that the explosion was of considerable force. Early press reports said the blast was the equivalent to half a kilo of TNT. Local Islamistseparatists linked to the Ingush Jamaat Sharia are the most likely suspects.

summary:
A Palestinian terrorist was killed by the Israeli Air Force (IAF) as he was preparing to fire rockets into Israel from Gaza, according to the Israeli Defence Forces (IDF).The IDF said that the rocket launching pad was also hit in the air raid near northern Gaza's Jabalya refugee camp.
In a statement, the IDF said that the terrorist belonged to the Jaljalatt terror organization, a Salafist movement operating in the Gaza Strip and influenced by Al-Qaeda. The statement added that some 770 Kassam rockets, mortar shells and Grad missiles had been fired at Israel since the beginning of 2009.
Gaza emergency services said three other people were wounded, one of them seriously.

summary:
Unidentified assailants threw fragmentation grenades at the Radio America building and two other stations of the Audio Video chain in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. The attack occurred around 22:45. The police reported no casualties.
While the escalating violence in Honduras seems primarily linked to the presidential election on 29 November, security forces expressed concern about the increasingly sophisticated nature of the weapons used. Honduras has primarily suffered from attacks with homemade devices, not military-grade weapons such as the grenades and RPG launchers as have been used in some areas in the past week.

summary:
Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) attacked security forces returning from patrol in Pirakata, West Bengal province. The ambush began at 14:30 and lasted until 17:00. The CPI-M detonated a total of four explosive devices and attacked with firearms in that time, killing two officers and wounding three others.
It is believed the Maoists detonated the first three blasts to initially draw the forces towards the ambush locale, indicating a measurable amount of planning for the attack. West Bengal continues to be one of the most impacted provinces from Maoist activity.

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) killed the chief of an anti-Taliban Lashkar (tribal militia)  in an explosion in the Badan area of Tehsil Warma Mund, Bajaur Agency. Malik Shar Pur was greeting fellow worshipers near the local mosque after prayers when a remote controlled device was detonated killing him and wounding three others.
Bajaur Agency has been the focus of much of the Pakistani Army's efforts in the last year to counter the presence of extremist Islamist groups in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA). Heavy fighting took place in the Tehsil Warma Mund area earlier in the year between Pakistani security forces and Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and it is thought this attack was in response to continued opposition by local lashkars to the TTP presence.

summary:
Suspected Taliban suicide bombers attacked the offices of the district police chief in central Balabolouk, Farah Province, Afghanistan. At approximately 07:30 a suicide bomber driving a stolen police Ford ranger rammed the vehicle through the gates of the police headquarters and detonated its contents. Three policemen were wounded and five parked vehicles were destroyed in the attack. The police chief, thought to have been the principal target, escaped unharmed.
The attack was the second unsuccessful high-profile incident on the first day of Id al-Adha after a Taliban suicide bomber attempted to blow up the District Police Headquarters in Balabolouk, Farrah Province.

Turialay Wisa was travelling in a convoy to Id al-Adha prayers when a roadside bomb exploded at approximately 09:00, narrowly missing the vehicle in which he was travelling. There were no injuries in the attack.
This was the second attempted high-profile attack in the southern provinces on the day marking the start of Id al-Adha.

summary:
Maoists killed two police officers and seriously wounded three other local security personnel in an ambush in Pirakata. The assailants initiated the attack with three explosions and a gun battle followed that lasted for two and half hours.
According to local press reports, the team of Central Reserve Police Force, India Reserve Battalion and State Armed Police personnel left Pirakata camp in the morning to patrol local villages. They were attacked while retuning to base along the same route they had travelled out from, some 2.5km away from Pirakata.
The authorities believe the Maoists saw the patrol leave and planted two sets of explosives on its return route. The first set of explosives initiated the attack and the second were placed where the blasts from the first would force the police into cover.

The Maoists have destroyed dozens of schools in the past week, primarily in neighbouring Jharkhand province. The tactic is commonly used to deter people from participating in elections since many schools are used as polling stations.

summary:
Three unidentified gunmen killed a special forces commander outside of his apartment building in Makhachkala, Dagestan. The gunmen shot him in the chest and face. One of the assailants was killed when another policeman returned fire. Police were unable to determine if the attack was terrorism-related.
Dagestan has experienced a dramatic upsurge in violence and has become one of the most unstable republics of the North Caucasus.

summary:
Unidentified assailants planted a bomb at the 518th kilometre of the Mozdok-Gazimagomed natural gas pipeline in Dagestan, however security forces were able to detonate it safely. The device consisted of a 12-litre bucket of aluminium powder and ammonium nitrate, roughly equal to ten kilograms of TNT. Witnesses reported no disruption to the gas distribution or other casualties. No group claimed the attempted attack but the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia is suspected as it has carried out similar attacks before.
It was the third attack on Dagestan gas pipelines in the past month. Two similar bombs were detonated on 11 November that caused a power black-out for more than half a million people.
The attacks seem to indicate increasing hostility to energy companies in the North Caucasus region. Oil installations and pipelines were frequent targets of terrorist activity during the Chechen wars, as in other parts of the world. Coupled with the recent assassination of an employee of Ingushetia's largest energy company, the incidents suggest that militant groups will continue to target energy companies to impact energy supplies and incite fear among the population.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Zaidi rebels claimed the capture of nine Saudi soldiers from the northern border region of Yemen, near Mount Mamdouh. Saudi Arabia launched a military operation days earlier to push towards Mount Mamdouh as part of its overall offensive against the rebel movement, but had not succeeded. According to the Zaidi, since 25 November they had destroyed three tanks, killed many soldiers and seized weapons. The details remained unconfirmed.
The Saudi military has been involved in the armed conflict in northern Yemen for the past month, including enforcing a 10km buffer zone and running a naval blockade along the Red Sea ports to keep the Zaidi from receiving arms and supplies.

Yusufiyah is part of once restive area, called 'Triangle of Death', a cluster of towns scattered north of Hilla City some 100km south of Baghdad.

summary:
A bomb detonated on a bus as it drove into the city of La Ceiba, Honduras. The bomb wasmade from tubes and wires.  The bus had traveled from San Pedro Sula when it exploded near a fire station. Ten people were on board but only one person was injured in the explosion. Security forces then discovered a second bomb on the bus that they disarmed. No group claimed the attack, but police suspected election-related motivations.
The bus belonged to the Catis Company, a known supporter of the Michelletti regime which ousted president Zelaya, suggesting a possible motivation for targeting the bus. The police expect further bombings ahead of the elections set to be held of 29 November.

summary:
Suspected Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) terrorists detonated two bombs at a restaurant in the central neighbourhood of al-Naqieb near the Imam Hussein Shrine in Karbala, Iraq. The first explosion went off at about 09:00, damaging the Jamaiya Street restaurant; the second bomb rigged to a bicycle went off minutes later after emergency services arrived to deal with the first. According to medical officials, at least thirteen people were killed and 26 injured in the explosions.
Karbala is a holy city for Shiites and has a number of important shrines. The restaurant is also near the building of the Karbala Operations Command. Soldiers reportedly often gather at the restaurant for breakfast.
Iraq has experienced an increased number of attacks on Shiite targets since American forces departed the cities in June.

summary:
Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) patrolling the southern border with Egypt discovered a 15kg explosive device. According to a military spokesman, a suspicious man carrying a bag seemed to be trying to cross the border from Egypt into Israel. Later in the evening when the troops tried to arrest him he fled back into Egypt. A bag thought to be the one the man carried was discovered the following morning with the large explosive in it. The spokesman commented that the IDF believed the man was to meet a contact on the Israeli side to be driven to a large city further north.
According to Israeli sources, terror groups have increasingly tried to cross the border from Egypt to carry out attacks. More security forces have been deployed along the border, particularly around Gaza.

summary:
The second of two explosions in Tegucigalpa, Honduras went off at the offices of television station Canal 10. The explosion caused extensive damage to two floors of the building where the Honduran weekly newspaper 'Hablemos Claro' is located. No group claimed either of the morning's attacks.
Police reported no arrests thus far in a bombing campaign that appears to have intensified as the 29 November presidential elections approach. Analysts believe the series of attacks aim to deter people from voting. Further attacks are expected.
Concern was also raised about the replacement of homemade bombs by sophisticated weapons like RPGs, as used in the attack on the Supreme Court.

summary:
A group of ten Taliban terrorists attacked and destroyed a NATO fuel tanker on a ring road outside of Peshawar, Pakistan. The terrorists ambushed the tanker en route to Afghanistan and wounded the driver and his assistant. They then fired rockets at the truck which set it on fire.

Baghdad has experienced a marked rise in attacks targeting imams and religious leaders throughout the city. summary:
Unidentified assailants kidnapped more than 50 people on their way to file a certificate of candidacy on behalf of Ibrahim 'Toto' Mangudadatu in Buluan town in the southern Philippines. Mangudadatu is expected to run in provincial elections in May 2010.
57 victims were found in mass graves near the area where they were kidnapped including members of Mangudadatu's family, lawyers and several journalists and government workers. No group claimed the attack but authorities suspected supporters of the rival political clan of current governor Andal Ampatuan. Mangudadatu is supported by a number of former Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) members, which may have been part of the motivation for the attack.
The casualty numbers were expected to rise as more bodies were found. The incident underscores the high tension levels in the country regarding May 2010's presidential, legislative and local elections. Election polls are frequently marred by violence as politicians use private militias to intimidate voters or rival candidates.
Authorities declared a state of emergency in Maguindanao to prevent retaliation near electoral offices. However new incidents are expected in the province over the coming weeks.

The schools, besides being easy targets symbolising government authority, are also frequently used as bases for election processes. summary:

Police reported that the bomb consisted of commercial explosives, a fuse and a detonator. No one was injured in the explosion and no group claimed the attack. The pastor of the church is a known supporter of Micheletti's de facto regime, which ousted President Zelaya on 28 June. His political affiliations may have been linked to the attack.
A second bomb was found by a civilian in the El Pedregal neighbourhood, planted under a car. The pedestrian found the bomb and threw it into an empty parking lot.
Honduras has experienced several low-level bombings in the past weeks, likely in connection with the tense political situation and the upcoming elections.

It was the fourth bombing in the country in a period of three weeks, two others at banks and one in a McDonald's in Talca. Bomb threats have also been made against the Metro system in Santiago.
Authorities expect banks and other symbols of the globalised economy to be targeted ahead of the March 2010 election, particularly in the larger cities. Besides the threat from anarchists, police note the tensions between the divided leftist parties as a possible source of future violent attacks.

summary:

As the crowd gathered to assist the injured people, the second bomb went off a few feet away from the first. The second explosion killed five people immediately and injured 55. Two other people later died from their wounds.
Police suspected the United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA), though a caller who identified himself as ULFA denied the group's involvement. Security forces believed the ULFA was desperate to prove its continued strength after the arrests of a few of its high-level members on 4 November. However, the National Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDFB) is also suspect. Attacks one year ago initially blamed on the ULFA and jihadist elements were later confirmed to be the work of the NDFB.

summary:

The bomb partially detonated at around 19:00 on Saturday. According to police, the bomb was substantial and could have caused serious damage and loss of life if fully detonated.
There was also an armed attack on police officers in Garrison, County Fermanagh, on Saturday evening. The attack was reportedly an attempt to assassinate a police officer who lived in the village.
Earlier in November the Independent Monitoring Commission (IMC) reported that the dissident republican threat in Northern Ireland was at its highest level for almost six years.

summary:
Suspected members of the Continuity IRA fired on a police officer in an attempted assassination in the village of Garrison, County Armagh on Saturday evening. Police foiled the attempt. The assailants fired one shot at police, who then returned fire. Nobody was injured.
Police reportedly knew in advance of the plan and were prepared to prevent the assassination on the police officer who lived in the village. It was unclear whether the officer was at home at the time of the attack. Four men arrested after the incident were being questioned by police, while Irish police were holding a fifth man, who was arrested in Dooard, County Leitrim.
In a likely connected incident, Continuity IRA members were also the prime suspects for an attempted 400lb car bomb attack, whereby only the detonator went off, at Policing Board headquarters in Belfast.
 
In early November, the Independent Monitoring Commission (IMC) stated that the dissident republican threat in Northern Ireland was at its highest level for almost six years.
The IMC said the two main dissident republican groups, the Real IRA and the Continuity IRA, were working more closely together to increase the threat posed to security forces.

summary:
Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) planted a bomb in the conveyor belt in Kiribur mines in Jharkhand, India. Police dismantled the bomb before it exploded. Hours earlier CPI-M terrorists had detonated a bomb at the neighbouring Meghatpur mine on the Orissa side of the border. Both mines are government owned, under the Steel Authority of India (SAIL). There were no reported injuries from either attack.
The central government launched a recent military offensive against the Maoists in India's central and eastern provinces, however these attacks indicate that the CPI-M still presents a very potent threat.

The explosion came less than 24 hrs after a suicide bomber targeted the Supreme Court in Peshawar. It was the ninth bombing in the last two weeks, singling out the North West Frontier Provincial capital as the current principal target for Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) attacks.

summary:
Suspected Taliban detonated a roadside bomb in the PAghman district in northern Kabul, nearly assassinating Afghan parliament member Abdul Rasoul Sayaf. The explosion killed four of his bodyguards and injured six others.
Sayaf, an ethnic Pashtun, was one of the mujaheddin leaders during the 1980s war with the Soviet Union who became a parliament member after the Taliban were dispelled. The Taliban continue to target Afghanistan's political leadership in an effort to further destabilise the country.

summary:
Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) detonated a bomb in Meghatpur mines in India's Orissa province. The mines are under the authority of the Steel Authority of India (SAIL), India's largest steel company and wholly owned by the government. Senior officials stated that the Maoists stormed into the loading point of the Meghatpur mines on the Orissa side and set off a bomb damaging the conveyor belt. The explosion severely affected the mine's operations.
There were no reported injuries. On the same day CPI-M also planted a bomb in the conveyor belt of Kiribur mines, about 15km from Meghatpur on the Jharkhand side of the border, another SAIL site. The incidents seem more likely to be attacks on the government than the mining industry itself.

At 09:30 a suicide bomber, who was driving a motorbike, detonated a device in the busy central square of the town. It was not clear what the intended target was, however three Afghan National Police personnel were killed in the attack.
Farah province has traditionally remained free from Taliban influence, however the increased efforts by the movement to extend its influence throughout the country has seen it increase its activities in this remote region in the last year.

No group claimed the attack, but the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has been behind an unprecedented series of attacks in the Northwest Frontier Province over the past two weeks, particularly Peshawar. The explosion took place at night, between Manohar and Posoita on the Tat-Bilaspur line and caused extensive damage to the tracks and electrical systems.
Recent incidents suggest the ongoing Maoist insurgency may intensify in the run-up to state elections. The leadership of Maoists apologised for the attack the following day, stating that it was carried out by 'overzealous new recruits'.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a joint army and police convoy near the police headquarters in Dehrahod district of Urozgan province, Afghanistan at around 15:30. The explosion killed ten civilians and wounded 13 others. According to the Afghan commander, casualties were high because the attack happened near a busy market. The bomber was unable to reach the security convoy and blew himself up among the people.
The Taliban is believed to be behind the attack. Hours earlier it claimed a double suicide attack in neighbouring Zabul province.

summary:
A suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) member killed 20 people and injured 50 when they detonated their explosives outside the Supreme Court building on Kyber Road, Peshawar. A suicide bomber detonated the device at 10:20 at the gates of the Judicial Complex while being searched by security personnel. He had been dropped there by a local taxi. The Judicial Complex is located across the street from the Pearl Continental Hotel that was the target of a truck bomb attack in June 2009 that killed 18 and injured 50.
The attack was the seventh major bombing in central Peshawar in under two weeks emphasising the gravity of Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) threats to continue conducting such attacks for as long as Pakistani security forces continue their operations in South Waziristan. TTP issued a statement the day before warning that it intended to intensify its bombing campaign in the region.

summary:
A stun grenade exploded beneath the vehicle of Imam Adnan Imami, a Muslim cleric, at around 02:00 in Majdal Anjar in the Bekaa valley, east of Beirut. The grenade was attached to 5-meter long fuse. Police released no further details.
The police were unsure of the motivation for the attack, and the investigations undertaken were both criminal and military. The primarily Shi'a Bekaa valley near the border with Syria was once known as a Hezbollah stronghold and was the target of Israeli attacks in 2006. Tribes have frequently attacked security forces, as in April this year, when they killed four soldiers and wounded 15 others. The region has also experienced inter-tribal and sectarian violence. Thus the cleric could have been targeted by a variety of actors.

The government had recently deployed thousands more troops to the Cauca region to try and disrupt FARC drug-trafficking activities there, but the attack indicates that its threat is still potent. The incident is the latest in more than 30 attacks carried out by the 6th Front this year.

The men shot at the pick-up truck with assault rifles and grenade launchers. The attack killed two of the politician's bodyguards riding in the back of the car.
No group claimed the attack, but Sarmiento belongs to the same political party as the ousted President Zelaya, and his brother is a congressman with the National Party. Police believed that the attack was likely related to those political affiliations. Honduras has suffered heightened levels of tension and bombings over the past few weeks linked to the presidential elections on 29 November.

The explosion was caused by a remote controlled device and was claimed by Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LEJ).

While overall violence in Iraq has declined, attacks occur regularly in Baghdad and in Iraq's other major cities.

summary:

Kirkuk has seen continuing conflicts between the Iraqi government, the Kurdish population and terrorists who continue to operate in urban areas.
