summary:
Unidentified gunmen dressed in Iraqi Army uniforms killed 13 people in a pre-dawn attack in the village of Zauba, west of Baghdad. Eight of the victims were initially ordered from their homes and executed in a nearby field. The assailants then entered another house and beheaded five male members of the family including Attala Ouda al-Shuker; a leading member of the Sahwa (Awakening) Movement of Sunni tribesmen who assisted US forces in ousting Al-Qaeda from Anbar Province in 2006. Since 'The Awakening', those tribes involved have become a key target for AQ attacks.
While the security situation in Iraq has improved dramatically, there are still several terrorist and insurgent groups capable of conducting high-profile attacks. There will be an increased frequency to these attacks in the coming months as the country prepares for elections in January 2010.

summary:
On 17 November a radical anarchist group known as the Revolutionary Cell claimed an early morning attack on a Banco Ciudad in the area of Bernardo de Irigoyen, Buenos Aires, the previous day. It claimed the attack was to: 'show our hatred toward the Argentine state for having captured and locked up (comrade) Chilean political prisoners Marcelo Villarroel and Freddy Fuentevilla' since March 2008.
Anarchist groups frequently launch attacks to show support for arrested members of their movement. Police sources did not confirm the incident but Argentinian anarchist and left-wing extremist groups typically target banks with low-level explosive devices.

summary:

No group claimed the attack, however the area is home to a number of active separatist terrorist groups; more local groups include Abu Sayyaf, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), and the New People's Army (NPA), while regionally active terrorist groups include Jemaah Islamiyah and Al-Qaeda. The Moro Islamic Liberation Front appears to be the most likely suspect.

In the last 18 months Farah province has increasingly fallen under the influence of the Taliban, as it extends its operations west from Helmand Province up to Herat, the western capital.

summary:
Suspected Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) threw a number of bombs at the house of Sukurdi Rahman, a local Congress member, in the Kaliachek area of Malda, West Bengal. Rahaman was not at home but one person was killed and five others injured in the attack.
Sukurdi said that a road-construction permit had been awarded to a man who the Maoists then tried to extort money from. Sukurdi had protested the action, which he believed was the reason for the attack. CPI-M in the area however denied the accusation.
The Maoists are known to try to extort money from various contractors in the areas where they operate, threatenting both their lives and businesses.

summary:
United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA) terrorists blew up a train carrying petroleum near Changpool in the Golaghat district of Assam, India. The assailants detonated the explosion about 22:00, which derailed the train of 48 wagons of high-speed diesel fuel and petrol and set it on fire. The fire was not contained until 10:00 the next morning and the police reported extensive damage.
The area is considered a stronghold of ULFA militants who have targeted the railways before.

summary:
The Taliban killed four construction company workers in the Chahara Dar District of Kunduz Province. Taliban fighters attacked the workers, employed by the Sadiqui Construction Company, in the evening. Four of them were killed in the ensuing gun battle. One Talib was also killed in the exchange of gunfire.
The workers were constructing a bridge in the Haji Rahmat Bai area. A Taliban spokesman claimed responsibility for the attack and confirmed the death of one of its members.

summary:
Four people were killed and 26 injured when a suicide bomber detonated an explosive-packed vehicle early in the morning at a security checkpoint in Badhaber, on the outskirts of Peshawar. The explosion occurred as police attempted to search the vehicle. The intended target was reported to have been a nearby Pakistani Air Force base.
Peshawar has been hit by five suicide attacks in eight days and, although this attack was unclaimed, has become the key target for Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) terrorism since the Pakistani Army launched Operation Rah-e-Najat (Path of Salvation) against terrorist groups in South Waziristan in October. Further attacks can be expected as the TTP recently threatened to expand its terrorist campaign in the region.

The bombs exploded at 22.40 and 23.00, causing extensive damage. The devices, made from nitrate-fuel and gas bottles, caused no injuries as the residence was unoccupied at the time. Slogans were painted on the walls of the property referring to a Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) member who was allegedly killed by the state in 1987 and has since been lauded as a hero.

summary:
Suspected members of the Jahm tribe kidnapped a Japanese engineer overseeing the building of a school in the Arhab area, about 25 km north of Sanaa, Yemen. According to local officials, the kidnappers wanted to exchange him with one of the leaders held by the authorities.
Armed tribesman have kidnapped more than 200 foreigners in 15 years, generally freeing them unhurt, to pressure the Yemeni government to stay out of their territories. A British and five German hostages were kidnapped in June in the northern Saada governorate. Also, the Jahm tribe threatened to attack oil facilities and block the road between Mareb and Sanaa the week earlier  if local authorities continued to 'occupy' its land.
There were some reports the engineer was released to the Mediation Committee on 17 November, after the signing of a written commitment to release a member of the clan held at the Political Security Prison. Other reports stated he was completely released on 23 November.

Anarchist groups continue to be active in Chile, conducting a low-level campaign against banks and Western commercial targets.

The number of Abu Sayyaf casualties was unconfirmed.

summary:
An unidentified terrorist detonated a bomb hidden in a motorcycle at around 08:30 outside a second-hand clothes shop in the business area of Rangae district, Narathiwat, Thailand. Police believed the bomb to be homemade and placed inside the fuel tank. The bomb did not go off until six soldiers arrived in front of the shop in a pickup truck. All six soldiers and the owner of the shop were injured in the explosion. It is likely the attack targeted the soldiers rather than the shop itself.
No group claimed the attack but the New Pattani United Liberation Organization (PULO) is a likely suspect. Of the three terrorist groups most active in the southern provinces of Thailand, the PULO is a smaller group that has shown bomb-making skills and is primarily active in Narathiwat.

About 17:30 the assailants shot at his convoy traveling between the Moji area to Wandorya of Equatoria State. Five of his security detail were killed in the attack and seven people were injured including the minister. No group claimed the attack.
Government officials remain a high-priority target for militants in Sudan, though why Kwaje was specifically targeted was uncertain. Police initially suspected a dispute between different ethnic groups arguing over which areas lie in different counties.

summary:
Suspected Al-Shabaab terrorists attacked the Jalle Siad Military Base in the north of Mogadishu, the base of the Burundian African Union peacekeeping mission (AMISOM). According to witnesses Al-Shabaab fired mortars at the military base, that also hit parts of the surrounding residential area. At least seven civilians were killed and 11 wounded in the fighting. Two soldiers were injured when mortars landed inside the base.
The base is frequently targeted by Al-Shabaab and Hizbul Islam terrorists trying to claim control of the city.
Some 5,000 Burundian and Ugandan troops have been deployed to Mogadishu as part of the AMISOM mission since 2007 to restore stability to the city. Their duties are restricted to guarding the presidential palace and a few strategic sites such as the airport and seaport, and to helping the embattled government fight militant groups in the capital.

summary:

The unidentified assailant detonated the 50-60kg bomb in the line of cars when stopped by the police checking vehicles. The explosion killed ten people, including two police officers and injured 25. No group claimed the attack.
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is a likely suspect as it has launched a series of similar attacks in the northwest region, particularly in Peshawar. In the last week more than 50 people have been killed in attacks by the TTP.
Attacks on security forces, civilians and Western targets have surged since the government launched an offensive against militants in the border region of South Waziristan in mid-October.

NATO troop convoys to Afghanistan are frequently targeted by terrorists along the Pakistan supply lines, particularly the Taliban. Over the past months, the supply routes along the Northern Distribution Network from Central Asia have also been increasingly targeted.

A van carrying the CRPF personnel was on its way from Kalimela to Gompagund. The landmine was planted at a culvert and exploded when the van passed over it.
The attack is believed to be part of the Maoist strategy to restrict movement of security forces ahead of their proposed offensive in the region. This was the third attack by Maoists in Malkangiri this month.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked the Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) agency in Peshawar at about 06:45. Up to 300kg of explosives was packed into a medical supply vehicle driven by the bomber. The driver was stopped at the security checkpoint and when unable to force his way through with the vehicle, detonated the explosives. The building was severely damaged in the attack, at least 15 people were killed and more than 40 were injured. Many were still trapped in the debris a day later.
It was not clear whether the target was the ISI or other sensitive military and civilian offices inside the military cantonment. Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack and threatened to conduct further attacks against the Pakistani security services and law-enforcement agencies.

Sporadic attacks occur along the Kosovo-Serbia border due to lingering tensions over Kosovo's indepedence from Serbia. Most terrorist activity is attributed to the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA), an armed group formed to topple Serbian control of Kosovo. However, the Balkan region also experiences high levels of organised criminal activity, as well as inter-group tensions.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen shot dead a spokesman for the Iranian consulate in Peshawar in an early morning attack. Seyyed Abdul Hassan Jaafri, Director of Public Relations in the Iranian consulate was shot dead by two masked gunmen outside his residence in the Gulbahar area of the city. He was a Pakistani national. The assailants fled the scene on a motorcycle.
This is not the first time that employees of the Iranian consulate have been targeted. A year ago gunmen kidnapped the Iranian Commercial Attache and killed his driver. He has been missing since then.
No group claimed responsibility, however Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has recently conducted a series of similar shootings of prominent Pakistani Army officers in Peshawar and Islamabad.

summary:
According to military sources, roughly 80 New Peoples' Army (NPA) terrorists attacked security guards and police at a facility of the Surigao Development Corporation (SUCEDOR) logging company in Lanuza town on southern Mindanao Island, Philippines. The NPA killed three of the security guards and one policeman in the initial attack, then proceeded to burn bulldozers, chainsaws, and wreckers, as well as taking some of the company's employees hostage.
Military troops stationed nearby that were sent to the area were then ambushed with a landmine under their convoy. Eight soldiers were killed along with 11 of the NPA fighters during the counter-attack. Another 10 soldiers, a police officer and the logging company's security chief were wounded.
No reason was given for the attack on the logging company, but the NPA often attacks such sites as punishment for not giving in to extortion demands and to gain weapons from the targets' security details.

Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) have claimed responsibility for a string of attacks across the country in recent weeks, including an attack on a cattle market the previous day in Peshawar that killed 13. summary:
A suspected Islamic extremist attack occurred in Fort Hood, Texas. Nidal Malik Hasan, a 39 year old major and psychiatrist in the US army, killed 12 fellow soldiers and a civilian at Fort Hood. 28 people were injured, including a female police officer who shot Hasan four times.
According to numerous media reports, Malik shouted 'Allahu Akbar!' (God is great) before opening fire. He was allegedly wearing religious attire during the attack. The FBI had been investigating internet postings by a man called 'Nidal Hasan' that appeared to support suicide bombings, but it was unconfirmed if the shooter was the author. He had apparently been subject to harassment for being a Muslim though he was not known for being extreme in his views. Hasan also reportedly resented the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan (where he was about to deploy) and wanted to leave the armed forces. Hasan is a US citizen of Palestinian parentage.
The attack reportedly took place in an auditorium where hundreds of soldiers were queuing up to get their pre-deployment checklists signed off.
Fort Hood is the largest US military base in the world and is home to 40,000 troops.

summary:
About 01:30 a bomb exploded outside a Banco del Estado branch in Santiago, Chile. The explosion was at the bank's Recoleta district office, some two kilometers north of the presidential palace. The bomb was made from a fire extinguisher and started a small fire and damaged windows but caused no casualties.
The attack was similar to the previous day's afternoon bombing of a Banco de Credito e Inversiones branch inside a Marriott hotel in the affluent Las Condes neighbourhood. That attack was claimed by a previously unknown anarchist group called the Efrain Plaza Olmedo Explosives Band, who also vowed to carry out more bombings.

summary:

The attack occurred in a remote area outside the town of Khasm al-Ein as the officials returned from an inspection of a border post. There are concerns that AQAP is consolidating its power in Yemen and may stage more brazen attacks in the future.
The organisation formally claimed responsibility for the attack and announced it was in retaliation for the oppression of Muslims in the Hadramout region. The AQAP communique went on to claim that three of the victims of the attack were senior Yemeni security officials including the regional Director of Security, Director of Criminal Investigations and Director of Political Security.

summary:
Armed Zaidi / Houthi rebels crossed the border from Yemen and attacked the Saudi border post at Jabal al-Dukhan, killing a Saudi soldier and injuring 11 others. A prolonged battle took place in which reports claim the assailants were killed. It is not known how many attackers there were, nor how many were killed.
The Yemeni Houthi Shia separatist group currently fighting an insurgency in the north of the country claimed the attack was in retaliation for Saudi assistance provided to Yemeni government troops in recent counter-terrorism operations in the Jabal al-Dukhan area. The Houthis have been fighting for greater autonomy since 2004 but the conflict has dramatically escalated in recent months as the Yemeni government vowed to crush the insurgency.
Eleven schools were evacuated in the Saudi border region and troops have been massed in the area in response to the attack.
Concern grew recently over increased collaboration between Houthi fighters and Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) which has recently stepped up its campaign against what it perceives to be an increasingly secular Saudi monarchy.

summary:
A previously unknown anarchist group claimed the bombing of a Banco de Credito e Inversiones branch inside the Marriott Hotel in the Las Condes area of Santiago, Chile. The attack damaged the building and injured a security guard. The group, calling itself the Efrain Plaza Olmedo Explosives Band after a 20th century anarchist, sent a message to Bio Bio radio claiming the attack and criticised the hotel's management for not heeding a telephone warning to evacuate the building apparently delivered 15 minutes before the explosion.
The group also claimed that there would be more attacks. Chile has experienced 104 such bombings since 2004, most involving low-level homemade explosive devices, and with no reported casualties. Responsibility is normally claimed by anarchists or anti-globalisation groups.

summary:
Armed gunmen attempted to hijack a plane in mid-air travelling from Boosaaso in Somalia's semi-autonomous Puntland region to Djibouti. During the flight, the gunmen ordered the plane to be landed in the northern Somalian town of Laas Qoorey where it was thought they intended to kidnap several German journalists travelling on the flight. Passengers aboard the plane fought back and overwhelmed the attackers, wounding one in the process.
The plane returned to Boosaaso where the attackers, believed to belong to Al-Shabaab, were handed over to Puntland police. The plane then continued its journey to Djibouti without further incident.

The centre was in a secure zone of the city centre. The explosion occurred close to the Ministry of Defense and the Pakistani Army Headquarters that was stormed two weeks ago by Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) terrorists leaving 23 people dead.
While no group claimed responsibility, the attack carries similar hallmarks to a series of suicide attacks that have been carried out across the country in the last month in response to the Pakistani Army's offensive in South Waziristan against the TTP.

summary:

Sixteen people were injured, including six policemen. The bomber detonated as police attempted to search his vehicle. A second man who was accompanying the suicide bomber died at the scene. The vehicle in which the men were travelling was packed with a larger explosive device which police later defused. It was believed they were attempting to enter the city to carry out an attack on a more central target.
The attack was not claimed, however Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has perpetrated attacks throughout the country in recent months and reports suggest this bore the hallmarks of the group.

Kunar Province is considered to remain a Taliban stronghold, as the mountainous province offers ideal terrain for evading security forces. Eight US servicemen were killed and more than 20 wounded in an assault on their base the previous month, resulting in the withdrawal of troops from the area.

It is unlikely the intended targets were civilians as opposed to military personnel.

summary:
Early in the morning a bomb exploded outside a building of a Greek member of the European Parliament. The bomb was placed outside the entrance of the building where Marietta Giannakou, a former education minister under the main opposition New Democracy Party, lives. The device, found in a bag, smashed windows and damaged the entrance of the apartment. There were no reported casualties.
An unknown individual called in a warning to a local newspaper and television station just before the detonation.
A media report said a little-known group, the Organisation for the Proletarian Popular Self-Defence, claimed responsibility for the attack in a letter to a daily Greek newspaper, but this remains unconfirmed. Police are likely to suspect Revolutionary Struggle as the group has previously targeted political party offices.
Hundreds of police were stationed throughout Athens and other parts of the country this week, stopping and searching vehicles as officials launched a nationwide manhunt after the police shooting days earlier. The attack occurred after Greece's new Socialist government vowed to crack down on the criminal activities of self-styled anarchists and far-left militant groups.

Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid claimed responsibility for the attacks and stated that the group had issued a threat to anyone working on the 7 November runoff election between Karzai and Abdullah Abdullah three days previously. The attack killed nine people, including six UN staff, two security guards and a civilian. According to the US Embassy, one of the UN staff killed was American. Nine other UN employees were wounded. Other nationalities wounded by the attack included German, Indian, Nepalese, and Afghan.
The Haqqani Network claimed the attack in association with an Al Qaeda operative. The three attackers were all from Pakistan's Swat Valley.

The attack was one of three coordinated attacks throughout Kabul; the other two were rocket attacks on the presidential palace and the city's main luxury hotel frequented by foreigners.

summary:
Suspected Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coodinate (BRN-C) terrorists planted a roadside bomb beside a railway near Supae Naebu village in Raman district, Yala province.They detonated the 3kg bomb via mobile phone as a unit of four paramilitary troopers passed by on patrol. One of the soldiers was injured in the explosion.
The explosion did not damage the track and there were no other reported casualties. The attack occurred as trains were not running in Pattani, Yala and Narathiwat provinces. The services were suspended on 15 October. Railway workers claimed they fear the increase in terrorist attacks in and around the railways.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Public Transportation

summary:
Suspected Islamist terrorists buried a bomb near the train station in Narathiwat's Rue So district in southern Thailand. The explosion wounded one soldier. No group claimed the attack.
Thailand's radical Islamic separatist groups have been known to target transportation. The attacks tend to fall under a persistent lower-level of activity, however some of the groups are becoming increasingly brazen in their attacks.

summary:
Suspected Abu Sayyaf terrorists threw a grenade inside a Roman Catholic church along Arolas Street in Jolo, southern Philippines. The attack occurred shortly before 11:00 but there were no casualties. The Filipino troops blamed Abu Sayyaf because it has carried out similar attacks on religious and security targets in the south over the past decade.
On 5 July six people were killed and more than 50 wounded when a homemade bomb went off in front of a Catholic church in the same area.
Currently an Irish Catholic priest recently abducted is also considered to be held by radical Islamist militants.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Abu Sayyaf, perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified gunmen attacked a vehicle carrying a Pakistani Army Brigadier and his relative in the I-9 Sector of Islamabad at approximately 08:00. There were no injuries in the attack and the terrorists escaped.
A similar attack, in which a Brigadier and his driver were killed on 22 October in Islamabad, was claimed by the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). This suggests a possible continued intelligence collaboration between the terrorists and those inside the military.
The attacks were believed to be in retaliation for the Pakistani Army's continued offensive against Islamist militants in South Waziristan.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A combination of Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) and People's Committee against Police Atrocities (PCPA) numbering in the hundreds laid siege to the Bhubaneswar-New Delhi Rajdhani Express train at a small railway station called Banstala in West Bengal, India.
The Maoists encircled the train, held the driver and his assistant, and the passengers hostage for five hours. They then ambushed the security forces that came to resolve the crisis. There was a gun fight before the Maoists and PCPA fled. Two PCPA men were killed and one policeman injured.
The attack comes barely a week after the deadly assault on the Sankrail police station and as part of a general increase in similar Maoist attacks in eastern and central India. Security forces launched an offensive in the region to try to eliminate the Maoists presence but they have met persistent resistance.

summary:
Two unidentifed men killed two police officers checking documents on a local bus on the Kizlyar-Mozdok Highway near Nikolayevskaya of Naurskiy District in Chechnya. One of the suspects opened fire on the officers, after which both men fled. No other casualties were reported. No group has claimed the attack and it is unknown whether the incident is crime or terrorism related.
The North Caucasus republics have experienced an increase in attacks on police forces and political figures over the past months, resulting in a general decrease in stability in the region. Terrorist networks in the region also increasingly operate across the republics' borders.

Unidentified gunmen killed two civilians and wounded two others in an attack on a power generator building in the Al-Ikhaa district of Mosul.
The attack took place in the eastern sector of the city which is predominantly Kurdish, possibly indicating a sectarian motive. Critical infrastructure remains a prime target for terrorists in Iraq.

Mosul has seen widespread low-level violence in recent weeks as sectarian killings appear to be on the increase.

summary:
Unidentified assailants targeted the Kirkuk oil pipeline to Ceyhan, Turkey near Mosul. According to a North Oil Company employee the attackers used an explosive device to sabotage the pipeline. The pipeline was expected to be shutdown for three to four days to repair the damage. Security forces were unable to determine the identity of the saboteurs and no group claimed the attack.
The Kirkuk-Ceyhan pipeline was originally designed in 2007 to avoid the attack-prone areas of Iraq's north by going through Irbil and Dorhust provinces before heading into Turkey. However, despite the intentions it has been unable to avoid all disruptions and Mosul remains one of the most unstable areas in Iraq.

summary:
A suicide car bomb exploded in a northern district of Karbala, killing four civilians and wounding fourteen others. The explosion occurred close to a police check point. It was suspected to have been detonated by the car's occupant when police moved to search the vehicle.
Karbala experiences frequent similar attacks. Conflicting reports of it being a suicide bomb or a remote-detonated bomb indicate that Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) may be responsible.

summary:
Shining Path terrorists attacked the Union Mantaro outpost in the Valley of the Apurimac and Ene rivers, known as the VRAE region in Peru. According to the Defence Minister, the militants mounted the attack at around 17:00 and the gun battle went on for over an hour. Three soldiers were wounded.
The security forces in the VRAE region, Peru's major coca producing area, are often attacked in a similar manner. The defence minister reported that the attacks were designed to distract military forces while drug traffickers tried to move relatively large drug shipments.
Shining Path operates in the heart of the coca production regions, particularly the VRAE and Upper Huallaga Valley, and relies heavily on the drug trade, both in trafficking itself and in providing security to traffickers, in order to finance its activities.

Mohmand Agency experiences frequent terrorist attacks on security points and is considered an area under Taliban control.

summary:
The Governor of Nangarhar Province, Gul Agha Sherzai, escaped an assassination attempt in the eastern city of Jalalabad. An unidentified gunman opened fire on his vehicle as his convoy drove down a central street in the city. Security forces killed the gunman and a second attacker who was found to be wearing an explosive suicide vest and carrying hand grenades. The Taliban is considered the most likely suspect.
Sherzai is one of the most significant Pashtun political leaders in the country and one of President Karsai's key allies. He survived an assassination attempt in 2006, which killed seven people. He allegedly still has strong links with the Afghan opium trade and is a former warlord.

summary:
Suspected Naxalites (Maoists) attacked police forces in four areas of Medinipur, West Bengal in eastern India. The gun battles lasted many hours after an initial, possibly related, assassination of a Communist-Marxist leader near Lalgarh. The Maoists attacked police as they performed a combing operation near Dhedua, then alternated fleeing and fighting with the security forces in Binpur and Laksmanpur forest until 13:30. One person was reported injured.
The incident falls into the recent pattern of low-level violence against security forces in the region. India's government has named the Maoists as the number one threat to domestic security.

Elsewhere in the area, suspected Naxalites (Maoists) attacked security personnel in a gun battle that lasted many hours.

The attack was one of two bombings that occurred overnight in the city, the other targeted a train.

The attack took place at about 09:30, when the black VAZ vehicle the victims were travelling in came under automatic weapons fire. No group claimed responsibility. The radical Islamist seperatists in Kabardino Balkaria have not yet focused on a targeted assassination campaign of politicians, indicating that personal motivations may have been involved.

The attack came just a couple of hours after another overnight bombing in the city that targeted a police bus. Dagestani Jamaat Sharia is suspected.

summary:
Two explosive devices went off in the Kirovsky district of Makhachkala, Dagestan. One while a police bus was passing that injured an officer, and the second under a railroad track as a train passed over it. According the the Interior Ministry, none of the train's crew was injured but the explosion badly damaged the railway.
The police reported no suspects for the attack but the Dagestani Jamaat Sharia is most likely responsible. The North Caucasus has experienced a measurable rise in attacks over the past six months. Violence that was once largely restricted to Chechnya has spread to other republics, notably Dagestan and Ingushetia.

specific_target: Ministry of Justice and Baghdad Provincial Council office
summary:
Islamic State of Iraq, a group linked with Al-Qaeda, terrorists killed at least 155 people and wounded at least 700 others in two coordinated, suicidevehiclebomb attacks on government buildings in central Baghdad.The attacks were the most lethal in Iraq since August 2007, when truck bombers killed over 500 people in villages near Sinjar. One vehicle was a truck loaded with over a tonne of explosives and the other was a car carrying an estimated 700 kgs of explosives.
The bombs exploded at around 10:30, outside the headquarters of the Baghdad provincial administration and the Ministry of Justice, which are about 500 metres apart and near the Green Zone. The attacks occurred during rush hour and seem to have been timed to maximise casualties. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attacks but Al-Qaeda in Iraq and former Baathist insurgents are the prime suspects.
The attacks bearnotablesimilarities to those of 19 August 2009, when suicide truck bombers attacked two ministry buildings, killing at least 100 people and wounding 600 others. Both were spectacular, coordinated suicide vehicle-bombings against government buildings in central Baghdad, which clearly aimed to create maximum casualties and destruction. Islamic State of Iraq claimed those attacks as well.
The US authorities warned of an increasing threat of violence in the run up to the elections in January 2010, and these attacks appear to be aimed at directly undermining central government and the political process.

summary:
At least ten bombs exploded overnight in the Logai area of Kokang, capital of Myanmar's northern Shan State. The bombs damaged a TV station, gambling casinos and other businesses. There were no available reports on casualties.
Government authorities suspected a relative of Peng Jiasheng, a former Kokang leader ousted by the military junta. Others believe that the bombs could have been set off by a disgruntled faction of Kokang troops led by Bai Souqian, the result of struggles over internal power-sharing.
Chinese leadership showed high levels of concern worried about peace along the Sino-Burmese border. The month prior 37,000 Kokang Chinese refugees fled over the border to escape the clashes between government and militia forces.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists planted a bomb beneath an 18-wheeler truck before detonating the bomb near a security checkpoint at Ban Buke Bakong in Narathiwat's Yi-ngo district, southern Thailand. The device exploded when the truck was 80 meters from the checkpoint. There were no reported casualties.
No group claimed the attack but any one of Thailand's three prominent radical Islamist separatist groups could be responsible. The New Pattani United Liberation Organisation (New-PULO) is a smaller group primarily active in Narathiwat province and has demonstrated bomb-making skills and links to other militant groups in the region.

Both sides exchanged heavy weapons fire for forty minutes during the morning. Casualty figures were not released.
Two days previously Al-Shabaab threatened Burundi and Uganda for assisting Somalia's Transitional Federal Government with attacks on its forces in Somalia and targets in their countries. The fact that the attack took place in the predominantly Burundi residences of the AMISOM troops suggests that the militants are making good on their threat.

summary:
Suspected members of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) abducted and killed two former members of a rival organisation, Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), in Chando village, Palamau District.
Approximately 20 suspected Maoists reportedly abducted the men from their houses and shot them on the outskirts of the village. The bodies were recovered on the morning of 25 October. Police said a note left by the killers accused the victims of working as police informants. According to police, the men were not informants but former members of a cadre of another far-left outfit, the TPC, with whom the CPI-M are fighting a turf war.

summary:
A car bomb exploded in the parking lot of the Swan Restaurant in the Evergreen Complex in the upscale area of Hayatabad, Peshawar during the late morning. The complex also included a swimming pool, a health club and a marriage hall. 15 people were wounded in the explosion. No group claimed the attack, but the region's information minister reported that it was likely part of the violence across Pakistan, probably linked to the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP).
The attack was one of three bombings in the northwest area of Pakistan in a few hours. The first was in Kamra against the military complex, and the other was a roadside bombing that killed 17 in a wedding bus in Mohmand.
The attack was the third attack on a Friday in a row in Peshawar. While Friday is Islam's holy day, terrorists may be using it as a psychological tactic to persuade young suicide bombers to give their lives for a 'noble' cause on a holy day. As a result there was a reportedly low attendance in mosques for Friday prayers.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified militants planted a roadside bomb along the highway in Mohmand tribal region. The bomb was remote-controlled and detonated when a bus (on route to a wedding) drove by. The explosion killed 17 people. A government official stated that the militants may have hit the bus mistakenly. No group has claimed the attack though the Tehrik-e-Taliban are possible suspects.
Mohmand tribal area has long been an area of significant Taliban activity, aided by its proximity to the Afghan border. the military has launched various raids in the area to clear it of Taliban militants but trouble still flares.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) suicide bomber blew himself up at the checkpoint outside the Kamra Pakistan Aeronautical Complex (PAC). The attacker was riding a bicycle and detonated the explosives when the guards stopped him. Seven people, including two Airforce personnel were killed and 15 wounded. PAC is the main facility used by the air-force to service, assemble, and manufacture aircraft and unmanned aerial vehicles. Although not confirmed by authorities, it is also reportedly linked to the nuclear weapons programme.
PAC is believed to be a place to store planes capable of carrying nuclear warheads. Both characteristics make it a high profile target for the TTP, since much of the campaign in Waziristan is conducted with air support and successful targeting of a nuclear facility would be considered a significant victory.
This is the second attack on the complex within a year, and it is also the third attack by the TTP against military targets outside the tribal areas in less than 2 weeks.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A small bomb was thrown at the Belfast headquarters of the Territorial Army's Northern Irish Horse Regiment. The attack occurred some time between 01:30 and 02:00. There were no casualties and no significant damage was reported.
Civilian guards were on duty at the time. Members of the Northern Irish Horse Regiment only use the base for training. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Two separate roadside bombs detonated in Mosul during the evening. The first bomb targeted a police patrol in the New Masr neighbourhood in the western part of the city that killed one policeman, while the other targeted a police patrol in al Majmu'a al Thaqafiyah that injured three civilians. Neither attack was claimed.
Elsewhere in the city three civilians were shot by unidentified gunmen in separate incidents in al Majmu'a, Egab valley and Fallah neighbourhoods; none of the attacks were claimed. Also confrontations broke out between gunmen and policemen in Nablus that killed one of the officers. Whether or not the incident was related to crime or terrorist activity is unknown.
Mosul remains one of the most unstable cities in Iraq and is considered by many analysts one of the last remaining cities of consistent, higher level Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) activity. However many of the attacks there are just as likely criminal as they are terrorism-related.
targets: Civilians/General Public; Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces

summary:
A magnetic bomb stuck to a civilian car detonated in the Ameriyah neighbourhood of western Baghdad in the morning. The explosion killed the driver and injured the passenger. No group claimed the attack.
Ameriyah is a predominately Sunni neighbourhood suggesting a possible sectarian motivation behind the attack. Baghdad has experienced a number of similar incidents in both the Sunni and Shi'a parts of the city on nearly a daily basis.

summary:
Unidentified militants attached a magnetic bomb to a Kia minibus that detonated as the vehicle approached the checkpoint in the Jisr Diyala area of southeastern Baghdad. The explosion went off at 14:00, injuring three civilians and once policeman. No group claimed the attack.
Concealed small-scale bombs have become a daily occurrence throughout Baghdad. Some attacks are likely sectarian in nature as they target specific neighbourhoods particular to Sunni or Shi'a populations en masse, others appear to be Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) attempts to impact security in general.

summary:
Suspected Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) militants hid a magnetic bomb to the car used by Sheikh Hussam Aziz. Aziz is the head of the Sahwa, a militia supported by the US military and then turned over to the government to support its forces. The explosion injured Aziz and his driver.
No group claimed the attack but AQI has purposefully targeted militia and tribal leaders supporting American and government forces. The use of such militias was supported by the 'Awakening' policy initiated in 2005 and became one of the most successful means of stabilising the areas outside of the cities. AQI tends to consider these sheikhs as enemies allied with the West and Iraqi government.

Local media report that six people were killed by one mortar shell when Islamists fired on the Bakara Market in central Mogadishu. Fierce fighting continues to take place across the city, both between the radical Islamists and forces from the Transitional Government, as well as in-fighting amongst Hizbul Islam and Al-Shabaab militants.
Bakara Market has lately experienced similar attacks on almost a weekly basis.

Al-Shabaab has not formally claimed responsibility for the attack. Both Al-Shabaab and Hizb-ul-Islam are predominantly active in the southern areas of the country but are thought to be expanding operations into the northern areas of Puntland and Somaliland.

Islamist fighters fired mortar shells at the runway of Mogadishu International Airport as President Sheikh Sharif Ahmed attempted to leave the country aboard a plane leaving for Uganda. Medical sources reported approximately 30 people killed and roughly 60 injured in the attack and subsequent shelling by Al-Shabaab and AMISOM peacekeepers. The President's plane took off safely.
Last week Al-Shabaab threatened the Mogadishu airport and the country's largest airline.

summary:
At least seven people have been killed and two others injured in an attack that took place on Ouadhias, 20 kms south of Tizi Ouzou, Northern Algeria. The attackers targeted security employees of a Canadian engineering company SNC Lavalin that operates in the area. Gunmen opened fire on a minibus carrying employees to work. Algerian Press reports claim there were no Canadian nationals among the dead.
This is the deadliest attack to occur in Algeria in months, however it is of note that SNC Lavalin have been targeted before in the past when Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) claimed a twin car bomb attack in August 2008 that killed 11 Algerian employees of the company. AQIM has often threatened to attack western companies that operate in the region.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a military vehicle in the G-11 District of Islamabad this morning, killing a senior Pakistani Army Officer and his driver. Brigadier General Moin Haider was travelling to work when a single gunman opened fire on his vehicle before joining an accomplice mounted on a motorcycle and making their escape. Several other bystanders were injured in the attack.
This is the second serious incident in Islamabad in three days, after a suicide bomber killed seven people. It follows a succession of attacks in recent weeks across Pakistan, mostly attributable to Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) that have left over 170 people dead.
Pakistani security forces continue to press ahead with their offensive against Militant fighters in South Waziristan. Independant verification of the progress of these operations has proved difficult due to a blanket ban on media coverage.

summary:
An unknown caller announced to police that two bombs had been planted in the High Court building in the F-8 sector of Islamabad. Police subsequently opened fire on an man wrapped in a blanket wearing a suicide vest. The attacker escaped unharmed.
The attempted attack followed a week of violence in the city as a suicide attacker killed seven people and several high ranking Army officers were assassinated by unidentified militants.

No group claimed responsibilty for the attack.

During the Chechen wars, Grozny was an area of consistent terrorist activity and Chechnya still supports a number of militant groups, many linked to separatist and radical Islamist movements such as the Chechen Jamaat or the Caucasus Emirate.

summary:
Unidentified attackers fired upon an Ural vehicle and a lorry full of servicemen in Chechnya's Vedenskiy District. Quoting Chechnya's law enforcement agencies, two contract servicemen from the Russian Defense Ministry were wounded. No group claimed the attack.
There are several possible groups responsible for the attack, though it most likely one of the Islamic militants such as Chechen Jamaat due to the proximity to the Dagestani border and the nature of the target. While all of the militant groups active in the Caucasus attack security forces, the jamaat networks in Chechnya, Ingushetia and Dagestan are known to be linked and operate in the border areas of their respective republics.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists attacked a police-post near the village of Nandare in the Nazranovskiy district of Igushetia around 20:30. The attackers used small arms and a grenade launcher in the attack. Reports of the incident vary. According to one account, the incidentinjured two police officers and two road safety inspectors. Approximately an hour later, a roadside bomb targeted a minibus as it approached the same checkpoint.
No group claimed responsibility for either part of the attack, but the Ingush Jamaat Sharia is a likely suspect as it frequently targets police and security forces.
Ingushetia has recently experienced a significant increase in the number of terrorist, including two of the largest suicide attacks in the region over the summer. The August attack on the Nazran district police headquarters killed 24 and injured 138, while an attack in June attempted to assassinate the Ingush president.

summary:
An explosioncauseda fuel-laden train to derail on the Poti-Senaki railway line in the Samegrelo District of western Georgia. While the blast caused significant damage to nearby houses and power lines, no injuries werereported. Reports suggest that 150 metres of track were damaged and 16 cars were derailed because of the explosion. Investigations revealed the use of a variety of explosives including TNT, cyclonite and platique.
This is the fifth railroad explosion to have occurred in Georgia in the last five months. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. Tensions remain high in the region after war broke out last year between Georgia and Russia after Georgia attempted to retake the breakaway province of South Ossetia.

summary:
Unidentified armed individuals killed two civilians, a man and his wife, inside their home in Mosul's southern village of al-Bousef at dawn.
According to security sources, the motivation behind the attack could be that the victims' son is a policeman.
Attacks targeting police officers are on the upsurge in Iraq, with Mosul remaining the last urban bastion of Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) and the scene of frequent shootings and bombings.

summary:
According to Turkish news sources unidentified terrorists attacked a military base in the town of Cukurca near the Iraqi border. According to reports, the attackers threw ten mortars into the base but were repulsed by the Turkish troops. Theincident injured a soldier. No group claimed responsibility forthe attack and the military has not released any further details about the incident.
Southeastern Turkey is a particularly volatile part of the country and is where the Kurdish population predominates, and is linked to other Kurdish centers in Iran, Iraq and Syria. As such it could be suspected that the attackers were from one of the Kurdish militant groups, such as the Kongra-Gel (PKK/KGK) of the Kurdistan Worker's Party, who frequently target security forces. The conflict between the Kurdish separatists and Turkey has been one of the most bloody in the world.

Al Fallujah was once considered the hotbed of Al-Qaeda activity but was able to significantly reduce the intensity of terrorist activity in 2007 and 2008. The string of attacks and bombings over the past months are thought to be related to the militants' efforts to keep the country destabilized and reignite the sectarian conflict after the American forces' withdrawal in June.

summary:

They found two fragmentation grenades concealed in a package in the men's bathroom in a commercial center. The center is one of the city's largest and is 300 meters away from the Presidential palace and in front of one of the most prestigious hotels.
No group claimed the attempted attack. Honduras is deadlocked in a political struggle between the ousted and incoming Presidents after a coup against the former on 28 June. Tensions have been very high and similar attacks in the future are possible.

According to reports, the troops were inspecting the pipelines after local residents had complained of a disruption to their water supply.
Although the attack has not been claimed, it is synonymous with low-level violence currently being conducted against government forces by separatist Islamist group Abu Sayyaf that has strong ties with Al-Qaeda.

The state-run school was adjacent to a block office building at SangrampurwhereMaoist rebels detonated dynamite blasting the construction on 13 October.
Educational institutions, official buildings, and business establishments remain primary targets of the Maoist insurgency in India's Bihar state.

Small-scale attacks such as the roadside mines are a daily occurrence in many parts of Afghanistan, particularly in the southern regions and along the Pakistan border.

There were no reported injuries or casualties.
This attack is judged as a possible retaliation for recent militarycounter-terrorism operations against Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen, aterrorist group responsible for bombings in August 2005 in which about 500 devices exploded at 300 locations in 63 of the 64 districts of the country. summary:
A series of roadside bombs exploded throughout Baghdad in the morning, wounding 12 people total but reportedly making no casualties.
A first bomb was detonated around 08:00 in al Hurriyah neighborhood in northwest Baghdad, leaving three civilians injured.The device, a magnetic bomb, was stuck to a minibus when it exploded.
Around 08:30, a roadside bomb planted in a car was detonated in al Dula'i neighborhood, part of Hurriyah district, wounding two civilians.
Two other roadside bombs targeted two separate U.S. military convoys, in Baghdad eastern neighbourhood of Obaidi and in Southern Baghdad, wounding three civilians. A patrol of the Iraqi army was also targeted by a roadside bomb in Baghdad's northeastern neighbourhood of Athemiyah, leaving four civilians injured.
The series of bomb attacks represents an additional indication that sectarian violence is likely to continue its upward trend throughout the country.

summary:
Three people were killed and 26 injured when a hand grenade exploded in a state-owned motor pool shop in Marawi City, Cotabato in the Southern Philippines. The explosion occurred between 13:00 and 14:00next tothe office of the Commission on Elections. Those killed are understood to allhave been state employees.
Reports suggest that the attacker was intending to target the Election's Commission Office next door where registration of voters for next years election was taking place. It is thought that due to tightened security the attackers were foiledbut still threw grenades in order to disrupt proceedings.
No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
Militants of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) attacked police at night just outside Kor-al Madina village in the Western Bahr al Ghazal state of southwestern Sudan. The fighting went on for one hour before the police ran out of ammunition. While withdrawing three officers were killed. The LRA subsequently attacked the town, shooting civilians and destroying the central market. An estimated 21 civilians were also abducted.
Police reported they were pursuing the LRA group in the direction of the Central African Republic.
The LRA is one of the longest running and most violent militant groups in Africa and has an extensive operational range across many countries.

summary:
Fifteen vehicles carrying logistical supplies for ISAF troopswere torched by Taliban militants operating in the region. No injuries were reported.
Highway One linking Kabul to the southern capital of Kandahar is the critical supply line to coalition troops operating in the eastern and southern provinces. The Taliban identified the vulnerability of this supply line 18 months ago and has since proven highly adept at targeting logistical convoys. As a result, ISAF has recently signed an agreement with the northern neighboring countries to allow logistical access through Uzbekistan in particular. The Taliban has subsequently expanded its range of operations and violence in the previously peaceful northern provinces has spiked in recent weeks.

summary:
Regional media reported thatapproximately 50 Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) raided the Sankrail Police Station in West Midnapore district, as well as a State Bank of India branch nearby. According to police, the CPI-M arrived in two groups on motorcycles and attacked the police station killing two officers. They then kidnapped the officer-in-charge before stealing all of the weapons in the police station and looting the bank nearby.
The Maoists left leaflets at the scene demanding the release of the People's Committee against Police Force Atrocities (PCPA) leader Mahato and withdrawal of security forces from Llargh. CPI-M spokesman Koteshwar Rao claimed responsibility for the strike before threatening the abducted officer's life if security forces try to pursue his group.
Rao further reported that the Maoists have launched their biggest ever offensive called Operation Venus in retaliation to the West Bengal government's offensive against them. Tensions in Midnapore have been very high since the government launched its offensive against the Maoists in June.

summary:
At approximately 15:00 two suicide bombers detonated their vests in Islamabad's International Islamic University. The suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants detonated the first bomb in the law faculty in the male campus while the second bomb detonated in the cafeteria of the female campus. Reports claim that six civilianswere killed and more than 29 others injured.
The twin-suicide bombing is the seventh major attack in just over a fortnight in the country and the first since the military ground operations in Waziristan began. The educational system has been a high priority target for Islamist militants for years. According to news sources, authorities had earlier defused two bombs at girl's schools in Peshawar.
Authorities believe many of the bombings and suicide attacks in Pakistan, as well as attacks in the West, are being planned in the semi-autonomous tribal area of South Waziristan where the army launched its offensive on Saturday. The TTP has also threatened to conduct attacks in response to the offensive.

summary:
According to Pakistani police, unidentified attackers planted two bombs near a high school in Bhana Mari, Peshawar. However the police were able to diffuse the bombs without anyone being injured. The bomb disposal unit reported that one bomb consisted of 14kg of explosive and bullets inside a pressure cooker, while the other was5kg of explosives and shrapnel inside a tin box.
The private schools and academic institutions in Peshawar were closed on Monday for three days because of terror threats in the wake of the military operations in South Waziristan.
The bombs were defused before the twin suicide bomb attacks at the International Islamic University in Islamabad, showing the commonality of target type.

Three civilians were injured in the incident. The owner of the CD shop reported to have closed his shop four months prior after receiving threats, however on the eve of EidualFitr he has reopened the business. No group claimed the attack.
Pakistan has suffered a significant series of bombings in its cities over the past two weeks, particularly in the northwest areas of the country.

summary:
Indian security sources report that suspected Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) set fire to two vehicles in a forested area of Korchatola in Rajnandgaon, India. The vehicles belonged to a private contractor who was building a road under the Prime Minister's Rural Roads Scheme. There were no reported casualties.
CPI-M are known for such attacks on government and infrastructure-related targets. While small the high volume of such attacks are considered an effective way of fighting against government authority. The group has been named the most serious threat to domestic security by the government.
perpetrators: India:Communist Party of India -  Maoist (CPI-M):Far Left/Revolutionary

summary:
Police officers in Grozny, Chechnya dealt with two attacks from unidentified militants in different city districts. One officer and one suspected terrorist was killed after the police tried to detain two suspects. When the two suspects were stopped they opened fire at the officers.
In the Urus-Martan district unidentified gunmen attacked the home of a police official. According to police sources the attackers planted an explosive device in front of the building and opened fire. The bomb was discovered before it detonated.
Chechnya and the other Caucasus republics have experienced an increase of attacks against police forces and officials. However it is often difficult to distinguish actual terrorist attacks from crime-related violence as governmental sources frequently report such attacks as terrorism-related for political purposes. Nevertheless, the genuine terrorist networks that were once primarily based in Chechnya are increasingly relevant to and active in neighbouring territories.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Civilians/General Public
author: Unknown author

summary:
One civilian was killed and eight others wounded in a sticky bomb attack in a market place of the Al Shaab District, north of Baghdad. Unknown gunmen attached the device to a shuttle bus during the afternoon in the Shi'a district north west of Sadr City. The area has seen an increase in attacks, as have markets in general in Iraq as such a target virtually guarantees a higher number of casualties and a greater psychological impact on the civilian population.
Tit-for-tat sectarian violence has been on the increase in recent weeks across the country as Iraq prepares for general elections in January 2010.

summary:
An improvised explosive device left in a restaurant in the commercial district of Al Bayaa in western Baghdad exploded around noon killing one civilian and injuring up to 10 others. It is reported that the death toll is likely to rise due to the severity of injuries sustained.
The attack comes during a hightened period of violence across the country. Al Bayaa district borders Sunni and Shia areas making it a likely location for a power struggle in an increasingly sectarian conflict.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Head of Bureau of Tribal Affairs
summary:
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Brigadier General Thenoon Younis, Head of the Bureau of Tribal Affairs, about 09:00 as he prepared to drive to work. Two other civilians were wounded in the attack which took place outside Younis' house in the Hadbaa District north of Mosul. No group has claimed the attack.
The assassination comes at the end of a weekend when several other attempts were made on high profile community and government leaders across the country. Sectarian violence is on the increase, notably marked by a suicide attack on a Sunni mosque in Tal Afar that killed 16 and wounded scores more during Friday prayers.
The attack appears to bear the hallmarks of a more calculated approach at destabilising tribal authorities during a period of increased violence and instability in Anbar Province.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomb attack on a police checkpoint in Garma, northeast of Fallujah city, killed at least two persons and injured seven others, including police officers. The attacker was armed with an explosive vest.
Security forces had no immediate indication regarding the motives or the group behind the bombing. For fear of further attacks, authorities in Garma deployed dozens of police and military troops in the main streets and blocked the entrances of the town. 
Relatively calm for more than two years, the once volatile Anbar province has recently witnessed an increase in deadly attacks.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Abu Sayyaf militants kidnapped a High School Principal on the Southern Filipino Island of Jolo in the morning. Approximately 12 gunmen stopped a mini-bus along Km.7 in Barangay Tanum carrying officials to the local school in Patikul and kidnapped Gabriel Canizares.
Abu Sayyaf has strong links with the Al-Qaeda network and was recently responsible for the killing of two United States Marines and numerous Filipino servicemen as it continues its opposition to central authority and demands for an independent Muslim homeland on Jolo and other islands.
*Abu Sayyaf claimed responsibility for the beheading of Gabriel Canizares on the 9th November when his severed head was dumped at a petrol station in the capital of Jolo. It was claimed he was killed as a result of a failure to pay the demanded ransom.

summary:
A remote controlled bomb hidden inside a parked motorbike exploded this morning in a market place in the southern city of Yala in Thailand. Believed to have been planted by Islamist fighters currently conducting an increasingly violent low-level insurgency in the region, the explosion wounded 26 people including three soldiers patrolling the area at the time.
More than 3,700 people have died in a spate of attacks across southern Thailand since 2004, with 340 having been killed already this year. While the attack is yet to be claimed, it bears the hallmarks of groups continuing to fight for a separate Islamic state, of which there are three active in Thailand.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Reports claim that the Al Shabaab Islamic Movement have destroyed three vehicles belonging to Burundian troops operating for the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) near Jaale Siyad Military Academy in Mogadishu. An Al Shabaab spokesman announced that an AMISOM vehicle had been destroyed using explosives, and a further two had been caught up in the attack when they responded to the first. A spokesman for the Burundian peacekeepers also confirmed that several of their vehicles had been caught in explosions but would not comment on casualties.
Heavy fighting took place over 24 hours between Al Shabaab fighters, government troops and African Union forces as Islamist groups continued to attempt to gain control of the southern region.

summary:
A Naxalite leader by the name of Manjitji killed businessman Mahendra Prasad Mittal at his office in Lohardaga district. According to police Mittal had been threatened a number of times by Manjitji, an area commander of the recently formed Chhattisgargh-Jharkland Simant Committee (CJCS)-a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoists.While the attack was claimed there was no indication of why Mittal was killed.
Elswhere in Jharkland CPI-M militants set two vehicles of a local Jharkland Mukti Morcha leader on fire at Kurund village in Latehar district.
The Naxalites umbrella encompasses a number of leftist-militant groups in India, the largest of which is the CPI-M.

summary:
Tajikistan's Interior Ministry reported a gun battle with suspected Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) terrorists during the night in Isfara, northern Tajikistan, in the Fergana Valley. Police killed four terrorists in the three-hour long gunfight, and one police officer was wounded. One other attacker was arrested. Fergana Valley is well known as an area of militant activity with frequent attacks on security forces and border checkpoints.
Over the past few months several clashes were reported between security services and suspected IMU in TAjikistan, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. The incidents fuel concerns that the extremist violence and terrorist networks in Afghanistan is spreading into other areas of Central Asia.

summary:
A car bomb killed at least five people and injured fifteen others in Raghiba Khatoon area, Athemiyah neighborhood, northeast Baghdad. The car bomb detonated at around 18:00 near a crowded electronics store selling SONY playstations.
Separately a roadside bomb detonated at around 15:00 in the Zafaraniyah area, southeast of Baghdad, leaving two civilians wounded. No group claimed either attack. The car bomb was in the frequently targeted Shi'a neighbourhood of Athemiya while the roadside bomb was in the Sunni southeast part of the city.
The bombings were part of a series which killed six civilians and wounded more than 20 others in the city that day. Three months after US troops' withdrawal from the country, sporadic attacks of an increasingly sectarian nature continue in Iraqi cities, particularly in Baghdad.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified militants set off a car bomb at the back door of an amusement park in northern Mosul targeting the motorcade of the Northern Cement Company. The explosion wounded the director and two of his escorts. No group claimed the attack. Mosul experiences daily bombings, however it has not been confirmed why the company was targeted. It is possible the attack was meant to indirectly target the government. The cement industry is covered by the Iraqi Ministry of Industry and Minerals responsible for the rebuilding and renovation of plants and companies.
Currently the industry is grouped into three companies, one each in the north, central and southern regions. The Northern Cement State Company is headquartered in Mosul.
author: Unknown author

summary:
According to local sources, an unidentified suicide bomber attacked a unity meeting of tribal and military Sunni-Shi'a leadership in the Pishin area in Sarbaz District of Iran's Sistan-Baluchestan province at 04:50. 49 people were reported killed and roughly 50 were injured. The casualties included 20 tribal leaders and close to 20 Iranian Revolutionary Guards, five of them senior, including Brigadier General Nur Ali Shushtari, deputy head of the Guards ground forces. A three-day mourning was declared in the province.
Jundullah claimed the attack, a Sunni extremist group. Some govermental leadership quickly accused foreigners for the attacks, including Saudi Arabia and Pakistan, as well as the US and the UK for possible intelligence links to the Jundullah group. The accusation comes at a particularly bad time for the IAEA negotiations in Vienna.
Local media seem to believe that the main goal of the attack was to drive a wedge between the mixed Sunni-Shi'a population of the Sistan-Baluchistan province. The assumption is that the terrorist attack in the Pishin region, one close to Iran's border with Pakistan, indicated a fear of the strengthening of unity between Iranian Shi'a and Sunni Muslims.
source_urls: Fars News Agency, BBC monitoring; IRNA
author: Unknown author

summary:
A bomb exploded at around 08:00 in Al-Jadiriya, central Baghdad, killing one civilian and injuring three others. The bomb was attached to a civilian vehicle when it was detonated near the Baghdad university intersection, killing its owner. According to police sources, the victim was a government employee. The people injured were three of his colleagues. No group claimed the attack.
The attack was one of three in the city for the day in which more than 20 people were injured and six killed. Over three months after US troops' withdrawal from the country, sporadic attacks continue in the cities.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) terrorists kidnapped three councillors and killed two others from the town of Sumapaz, just south of Bogota. At least three heavily armed men showed up to a political meeting where they killed Liberal Party councillors Torres Ramirez and Moreno. The terrorists then took two councillors from the leftist PDA party and a municipal contractor hostage. They set them free a few hours later.
It remains unknown why FARC targeted those particular leaders, or if the incident was simply a general attack on government authority. Similar attacks close to the capital could impact the presidential elections in less than six months.The use of terrorist tactics prior to elections is a common tactic to draw attention to their cause.
FARC has been fighting the government since 1964 and has an estimated 9,000 fighters who operate across a large part of Colombian territory.
perpetrators: Colombia:Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC):Far Left/Revolutionary

summary:
A bomb detonated near the Paharpur border outpost in Kathua district, 60 kilometres southeast of Jammu city, causing damage to a border-fencing pillar. No one was injured in the explosion.
According to security sources, two unidentified individuals infiltrated the Indian side of the Paharpur area on the International Border, in Kathua District, and planted a homemade bomb under a canal ahead of the fencing area. The infiltrators reportedly detonated the device remotely, from Pakistani territory across the border. Border Security Force (BSF) authorities could not determine whether militants or Pakistani Rangers, a paramilitary group performing internal security duties in Pakistan, had planted the bomb.
In another incident, an Indian army officer, Lance Naike N. K. Maruti, was killed in a landmine explosion near the Line of Control at Patrigali, in the Mendhar sector of Poonch district. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.
In recent months, Jammu & Kashmir state has witnessed an increase in cross-border infiltration. The security forces have experience high casualty levels.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified terrorists threw a hand-grenade into the house of Balochistan Information Minister Younas Mullazai in the provincial capital of Quetta. No casualties were reported as the minister was not in his house at the time of the attack.
Security sources reported that the attackers were driving a motorbike when they threw the grenade which exploded in the backyard of the house, causing damage to windows and doors.
Though low-level, the Baloch insurgency has hindered gas exploration and production activity in Pakistan’s largest and resource rich province over the last few years.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
According to police sources, an attack on an Iraqi army convoy just outside of the city of Fallujah killed four Iraqi soldiers and wounded 10 others. The patrol vehicle was hit in the Al-Nainiya area in the southeastern part of the city. No group claimed the attack, but Al-Qaeda in Iraq is a prime suspect as it continues to target security forces throughout the country.
In general the insurgency has waned since the surge and the formation of alliances with Sunni tribal leaders in Iraq's Western provinces. Some observers, however, fear an increase in attacks ahead of national elections in January.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A suicide bomber blew up a dynamite-laden truck as it was crossing a bridge over the Euphrates River in the Ramadi area of Al-Anbar Governorate. The Chairman of the local council has said that militants believed to belong to Al-Qaeda were behind the incident. There were no reported casualties.
The bridge is on the key highway linking Iraq with Syria and Jordan; it is a major highway for local and civilian traffic and has been used by the departing US military. Local authorities reported that they believed the attack was aimed at Iraqis rather than American forces.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) has been increasingly active since the withdrawal of US forces from the cities in June. The attack could be a substantial blow to the flow of development and security operations in the area, as well as the local economies.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified men planted a bomb to an Interior Ministry car in Baghdad's Yarmouk district. The official and three others were injured in the explosion. No group claimed the attack.
Yarmouk is considered a mirror image and opposite of Bagdhad's Shiite-dominated Sadr City, indicating a possible sectarian motivation behind the attack.
author: Unknown author

summary: According to news sources, the Taliban abducted 15 road construction workers in Zadran District of Paktia Province, Afghanistan. Both the Taliban and Sadran officials confirmed the hostage-taking. The workers were working on a six-kilometre long road being constructed from the centre of the district to the Mati area. Some sources report that the Taliban did not want the road to be built.

summary:
A series of Taliban rocket and armed attacks on military camps and security check posts in Waziristan resulted in the deaths of four soldiers, while 12 others were injured. The militants attacked camps in Razmak, Saeed and Mandana.
Early in the day the Pakistani military began its ground operations in South Waziristan against Taliban strongholds, after a wave of serious attacks across the country. The Pakistani army stated that about 28,000 fighters were fighting an estimated 10,000 Taliban, including 1,000 Uzbeks and Arab Al-Qaeda members.

summary:
A car bomb planted by unidentified terrorists exploded in the Kingsdale Park area of eastern Belfast. The car was owned by a police officer whose girlfriend was hurt during the incident. The bomb detonated as she stepped into the soft-top car and started the car. It is believed that the soft top saved her from serious injury as the pressure from the explosion was released.The attack was less than a mile from police headquarters.
Police emphasised the significance of the location of the bomb, as eastern Belfast is far from the areas in which dissidents have been most active over the past years. The location of the attack suggests an 'upping the ante' by dissidents, however no one has claimed responsibility.
Police are investigating any possible links to the similar attack in Londonderry last month.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a Sunni mosque, killing 14 people and wounding 80 inside a Sunni mosque in the centre of Tal Afar, Iraq. The explosion took place as people gathered for Friday afternoon prayers.
Four gunmen in a sedan refused to stop at a checkpoint and were fired at by security guards. Three escaped, while the fourth fled into a nearby mosque. The gunman, wearing an explosive belt, opened fire at Shaykh Abdulsattar Hussein Alou, the Imam and Shaykh of al-Taqwa mosque and one of the Talafar courts judges. While attempting to fight his way out of the mosque, he ran out of ammunition and consequently detonated his explosive vest.
Tal Afar lies approximately 60 km south-west of Mosul, and is considered the one remaining urban stronghold of Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI). The last week has seen a series of large-scale attacks against Shi'a muslims in the region and the targeting of Sunnis as they attend prayers on the holiest day of the week. This is sure to trigger further serious reprisal attacks in the area.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants targeted the Landi Noor army camp in the Shakai area of South Waziristan. Their rocket strike killed three soldiers and wounded four others. Shakai is known as a Taliban and Al-Qaeda stronghold near the Afghan border, where the military is said to be planning a ground offensive to flush out extremists. Fighter jets were used to bomb the militant hideouts in the area, but details of casualties were not immediately available from officials.
Pressure is building on the military to take action against an escalation of terrorist attacks this month. In June the government ordered an operation into South Waziristan, but so far only air raids and occasional artillery strikes have hit the rebel sanctuaries.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Two suicide bombers attacked the Pakistani Special Investigations Unit (SIU) on Friday morning. A female suicide bomber dressed in a burqa, and riding a motorbike detonated her explosives moments before a large car bomb exploded close by. At least 15 people were killed in the attack and 21 wounded.
The attack was part of a wave of violence plaguing Pakistan that has seen over 150 people killed in the last two weeks. Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) terrorists launched three simultaneous assaults in Lahore on 15 October, killing 40.
The attack was not formally claimed, however the TTP are thought to be responsible as they have been the most frequent perpetrators of the recent violence across the country.
source_urls: Al jazeera, Geo News, The Islamabad News (BBC Monitor)

summary:
Suspected NAtional Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDBF) terrorists kidnapped a project manager of Gayatri East Coast Insulation, a private construction company, during the morning in Kokrajhar, Assam. The manager was supervising work at Karigon Joypur. The kidnappers fired three rounds into the air when construction workers at the site tried to resist them.
This is the second incident when an official of the company has been kidnapped from the Bodoland Territorial Council Area. In July 2008 three were taken and were released after the company allegedly paid a ransom.
*He was reported released at 09:15 on 17 November.
