summary:
A mine explosion in the Balaboluk District of Farah Province, western Afghanistan, wounded three policemen. Police reported that a mine destroyed a police Ranger vehicle on its way to the centre of the province from the Farahrod District, in the Darestan area. The Taliban claimed the attack, though claimed higher casualties, as they normally do.
Taliban activity has been expanding in the northern and western parts of the country. Violence is expected to rise again to coincide with the upcoming run-off for the presidential elections.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A suicide bomber driving a car loaded with explosives detonated a large device outside the Investigation Bureau of the Pakistani Army in the Cantonment area of Peshawar. At least 11 people were killed in the explosion, while the individual was being followed by police officers that had been alerted to its suspicious nature. The blast caused significant damage to the Bureau building and victims were still believed to be trapped in the rubble a day later.
The attack occurred at the same time as a second explosion caused by a female suicide bomber driving a motorbike. The female attacker detonated her device when approached by members of the Pakistani security forces.
The attack was part of a wave of violence that continues to plague Pakistan and has seen over 150 people killed in the last two weeks. Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) terrorists launched three simultaneous assaults in Lahore the day before killing 40.
The attack is yet to be claimed but sources claim it bears the hallmarks of the TTP, which have been the main perpetrators of the recent violence across the country.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Two members of a reactionary Hindu group were killed when explosives they were carrying detonated as they were travelling through Goa on a scooter. The men were in a late evening traffic jam in Margao, Goa in India (close to the Grace Church) when the attack occurred. The scooter caught fire after the explosion. Police report the two were carrying five gelatin explosives sticks. They believe they were meant to go off elsewhere, but exploded prematurely as the scooter got delayed on Margao's roads. 
According to local police, the scooter belonged to Nishad Bakhle, an alleged member of Sanathan Saunstha, a reactionary Hindu group which is headquartered in the temple town of Ramnathi. The Sanatan Saunstha, formed 25 years ago and which has been active in the past eight years, is violently opposed to the 'narakasura' festival. The narakasura' is a competition where thousands gather to see several giant effigies being judged for prizes and then set on fire as part of a popular Diwali tradition in Goa. Sanathan Saunstha's motto is: "Evil should be destroyed."
author: Unknown author

summary:
Four police officers were injured in a roadside bombing that targeted their patrol in downtown Kirkuk city around 09:00. No group claimed the attack. Police and other security officials remain a high priority target for all groups of militants in Iraq.
Roadside bombs frequently go off in the morning as they tend to be planted in the evenings and late nights to avoid being detected by security forces.

summary:
A roadside bomb targeting an Iraqi army patrol in the Qahira neighbourhood of northeast Baghdad detonated at around 08:00. One civilian was killed and three people, including two soldiers, were injured in the explosion.
No group claimed the attack, however Qahira is in the predominantly Shi'a area of Adhamiya, where there have been a number of attacks over the past few months. Shi'a targets throughout Iraq has been increasingly targeted after what was considered a substantial drop in sectarian violence towards the end of 2007 and early 2008.

summary:
A series of low-level bombs went off in and around Mosul. Three civilians were injured by an explosive device rigged to a bicycle in downtown during the afternoon. Also a roadside bomb targeted a police patrol in the al Maash marketplace in the western part of the city. One policeman was killed and another was injured along with three civilians. Another roadside bomb targeted a police patrol near the area of Birtilla just outside of Mosul. The explosion killed one police officer and injured four others.
No group has claimed any of the attacks but such attacks have become a daily occurence in Mosul. The aim is likely to generate a general feel of insecurity to weaken the authority of the government.

summary: Suspected members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) opened fire on a plane carrying 15 people in Guaviare province in south-western Colombia. The DC-3 plane, frequently used for transport, was en-route from Miraflores to San Jose del Guaviare when the attackers opened fire just as the plane took off. Bullets hit the fuselage and caused damage to the interior panel, injuring a passenger. However, no other injuries were reported.

summary:
According to local media, fighting erupted between Al-Shabaab militants and Ahlu Sunnah Wal Jamee'a militias in the Mataban district of Hiran region in central Somalia. During the two hour fight at least 22 people were wounded. The militias' leaders claim to have killed two Al-Shabaab leaders in the fighting and locals report that the militias are in charged of the area following the battle. Another ten people were reported killed as well.
Al-Shabaab and Ahlu Sunnah militia have been fighting in the Galgaded and Hiran regions since late 2008. The Al Sunnah is a pro-governmental militia and thus a declared enemy of Al-Shabaab.

summary:
Three civilians were killed and 12 were injured including a police officer when an unidentified motorcyclist threw a hand grenade at a police vehicle at 18:45 in Zaranj, the provincial capital of the south western province of Nimruz.
Nimruz has become a Taliban stronghold due to the absence of Afghan or international security forces. The Taliban have recently taken advantage of the mainly deserted province to transport weapons and supplies from the Iranian border.

summary:
Suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and Lashkar I Jhangvi (LJ) gunmen launched three simultaneous morning attacks on buildings belonging to the Pakistani Police and Intelligence agencies in the eastern city of Lahore. Initial reports indicated that up to 28 people were killed and up to 34 wounded.
Three militants launched an attack on the Manawan Police Academy on the outskirts of Lahore at 09:55, where a similar attack took place earlier in the year. Seven police trainees were killed along with four civilians, while all three of the terrorists detonated explosives strapped to their bodies.
The attacks were conducted in similar style to those perpetrated across Pakistan in recent months and demonstrate a growing confidence within the radical Islamist groups in choosing high value governmental targets.
Despite the attacks being claimed by the TTP, the LJ are known to be linked to Al-Qaeda and the TTP at the highest levels and are held responsible for previous advanced attacks in Lahore. It is likely that they worked together in these attacks.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) gunmen launched three simultaneous attacks this morning on buildings belonging to the Pakistani Police, Army and Intelligence agencies in the eastern city of Lahore. It is reported that 28 people died in the attacks and up to 34 were wounded.
The third attack took place at 09:45 on the Pakistani Elite Training Centre at Bedian near the airport in Lahore, where five assailants attempted to storm the building with assault rifles and grenades. They climbed a boundary wall to gain entry into the compound.  One civilian was killed in the resultant gun battle, two of the attackers were killed by security guards and the three others wearing suicide vests blew themselves up. The attackers briefly took several hostages, before they were overwhelmed by security forces.
The TTP has been responsible for a series of high profile attacks on major Pakistani cities in recent months as they continue to exploit the weakness of central governmental authority. Despite the attacks being claimed by the TTP, Lashkar I Jhangvi (LJ) are known to be linked to Al-Qaeda and the TTP at the highest levels and are held responsible for previous advanced attacks in Lahore. It is likely that they worked together in these attacks.

summary:
Unidentified militants threw a hand grenade at a Frontier Corps vehicle in the Sariab Road area of Quetta, Pakistan. Sources report that two officers and three civilians were injured, and one officer died in the explosion. According to the police the suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) attackers escaped on motorbike after throwing the grenade at the patrolling vehicle. The TTP has not yet claimed the attack.
Pakistan's Balochistan province has witnessed a significant rise in the number and severity of attacks over the past year.

summary:
Police reported that a car bomb exploded near a three-story building in the officer's Gulshan-e-Rahman Colony in Peshawar. A bomb of approximately 60kg of explosives was planted in a car near the residential block and was detonated by remote control. Initial reports indicated that the target was a school inside the area, but later police confirmed the attack was on the residences.
Around 350 families, mostly of government officials, reside in the Gulshan-e-Rahman Colony. The building is reported to have collapsed and several apartments in adjacent buildings were also damaged along with some vehicles parked in the area. One child was killed and 12 people, including two policemen, were injured. No group has claimed the attack but the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected.
The attack is likely part of the series of attacks in the north-western region of the country as the TTP strikes at cities in an effort to inflict damage before the military begins its offensive in the Waziristan areas.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a police station with a car packed with explosives in Kohat, south of Peshawar. The attacker ploughed the vehicle into the police building before detonating the device.
Reports assess that ten people have been killed and scores more injured. The attack is as yet unclaimed, however it bears the hallmarks of Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) who continue to perpetrate attacks across the country. A similar suicide attack in the Khyber Agency during the week killed over 40 people.
The attack comes on the same morning that Tehrik-e-Taliban gunmen launched three simultaneous assaults on Pakistani security service locations in the eastern city of Lahore.

summary:
Suspected Communist Party of India- Maoists (CPI-M) attacked four polling stations in the Gadchiroli district, where re-polling was completed (Aeetalli, Burgi, Tadgaon, and Korchi). The attacks started in the morning and were repeated in the afternoon at some of the stations. Police reported that the Maoists opened indiscriminate fire, but withdrew when the large numbers of security personnel returned fire. No one was injured in the attacks and the polling was completed.
CPI-M has specifically targeted the election processes and security targets throughout India and has been named the most important threat to domestic security by the Indian government.

Police from the Shamilar area of Islamabad arrested two suspected Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) terrorists with suicide jackets, hand grenades and pistols. The targets for the attacks remain unknown. Police report that they are investigating the suspects and possible links to the series of attacks in the region.
Pakistan has experienced a measurable increase in the number of attacks on its urban centers, particularly in the northwestern region, which are suspected to be in retaliation for the upcoming offensive in Waziristan.

summary:
Unidentified gunmen launched three simultaneous attacks on buildings belonging to the Pakistani Police and Intelligence agencies in the eastern city of Lahore during the morning. Intial reports indicated that 28 people may have been killed and 34 injured.
Four gunmen broke into the Federal Investigation Agency (FIA) on Temple Road around 09:30, opening fire indiscriminately and killing five people. Two assailants were killed by security guards in the attack, one of whom was wearing an explosive vest which failed to detonate.
Initial reports indicated involvement by Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), emboldened by the successes of recent attacks on the United Nations World Food Program and the Army General Headquarters in Islamabad. However, it is likely that the attacks in Lahore were accomplished with the operational cooperation and support of Lashkar I Jhangvi (LJ). The group, linked to TTP, Al-Qaeda, and the IMU, has advanced and well-organized capabilities.

summary:
During an evening music concert a grenade exploded in Chisinau's main square in Moldova. The grenade was left in a box and exploded near the stage, injuring an estimated 40 civilians, according to police officials. It is unsure whether the act was one of hooliganism or a terrorist attack. No one claimed the explosion.
Moldova does not frequently experience terrorist activity and its officials do not tend to assume bombings are connected to terrorism. Tensions also exist with the separatist, self-declared republic of Transnistria that broke away after a brief civil war in the early 1990s. Transnistria, a slim ribbon of territory populated largely by ethnic Russians and Ukrainians, has had tense relations with Moldova for years, but since the fighting ended in 1992, relatively few outbreaks of violence occurred and no bombings linked to either side were reported until 2006. That said, over the past year more small-scale bombings and threats have been reported.

summary:
A roadside bomb exploded near Tayaran intersection in central Baghdad at around 15:00. Three civilians werereportedly  injured in the explosion. No group claimed the attack.
Tayaran Square has been targeted a number of times over the conflict due to its status as a central intersection in the city, where there is a near guarantee of civilian injuries and casualties.
Violence has been on the rise in Iraq since US forces withdrew from the cities in June. The attacks are generally a mix of Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) terrorist tactics, an increase in sectarian violence, and a general rise in overall criminality as the government continues to struggle to establish security throughout the country.

summary:
Around 12:00 three mortar shells hit the Jewadin market place in Baghdad's Shaula neighborhood. The bombing was followed by an armed attack carried out by gunmen who robbed three jewelry stores after killing the owners.
Iraqi police sources reported that the attackers opened fire as they were making their escape from the shops where they had stolen some money and gold. They then threw grenades after them leaving the market targeting civilians. Overall eight people were killed and 14 wounded during the incident.
No group claimed the attack however random crime-related violence is gradually increasing in Iraq.

summary:
A roadside bomb detonated targeting the car of Abdul Satar Abdul Jabar at around 08:30. The Imam of the Abu Hanifa Al-Noman mosque in the Athemiya neighbourhood in northeast Baghdad. Both the Imam and his driver were injured in the explosion. No group has claimed the attack.
There have been a number of attacks against religious leaders and scholars in Iraq over the past few weeks, particularly against Shi'a religious targets and Sunnis who denounce Al-Qaeda's extremism. This suggests a shift in tactics from general insurgency to a more targeted terror campaign.
Roadside bombs continue to be a primary terrorist tactic in Iraq.

summary:
Three almost simultaneous explosions occurred in the southern Shiite holy city of Karbala between 16:00 and 17:00, killing at least six people and injuring over 42 others.
Police sources reported that the first explosion occurred at a shopping centre near one of the city's two major shrines, the shrine of Imam al-Hussein,  Iraq's second-holiest site for Shiite Muslims. Two other explosions followed soon after at a police checkpoint and inside a parking garage near the second shrine, Imam al-Abbas.
No one claimed responsibility for the bombings.
Despite the measurable decrease in violence throughout the country, insurgents continue to target Iraqi civilians, especially Shi'a areas and their shrines in attacks likely intended to reignite the sectarian violence that has been largely reduced over the past year.

summary:
According to military sources in the area, another group of Abu Sayyaf members fought with its soldiers when they crossed paths near the Barangay Masjid-Baila area of Jolo Island in the southern Philippines about 13:30. Three of the militants were killed and a reported five marines were injured in the exchange of fire.
Jolo has experienced an increase in attacks on military targets over the past few weeks.
Later in the evening, another group of Abu Sayyaf militants burned down a Smart Communications cell site in Indanan town on the Philippine island of Jolo at 22:15. The group frequently targets telecommunications towers and is most active in the southern part of the country.

summary:
Two days of shelling in Mogadishu's Bakara Market resulted in the death of at least five civilians and injured at least 16. Bakara Market is a consistent, almost daily target in Mogadishu as it is considered an area where militants hide out to attack the AMISOM peacekeepers. Both sides accuse the other of purposeful targeting of civilians in the market area with their shelling though AMISOM vehemently denies it.
Al-Shabaab claims virtually all attacks on peacekeepers around the market.

summary:
An early morning gunfight occurred between Saudi security forces and suspected Al-Qaeda militants in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) militants in the town of Darb, Jizan province near the southern border with Yemen.
Two suspected Al Qaeda operatives were killed and another was arrested during a gunfight with Saudi security forces at 06:00. One security officer was killed and another was injured when the militants opened fire on them at a security checkpoint. Dressed in women's attire and travelling in a car, the occupants opened fire when the guards demanded to search them. Police reports claim all three men were wearing explosive belts and carrying grenades, assault rifles and other explosives.
The two attackers that were killed are believed to be of Yemeni origin and were on the Saudi Interior Ministry's list of 85 wanted terrorism suspects.
The attack was the latest in a series of incidents, including the assassination attempt on Prince Mohammed bin Nayef on August 28, and highlighted Al-Qaeda's determination to carry out attacks in the kingdom.
Last month the Saudi Interior Ministry announced the arrest of 44 suspected Al Qaeda militants and suggested there is on-going activity on the Arabian Peninsula to recruit and finance extremist terrorist groups both regionally and globally.

No group claimed responsibility for the attack however, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) frequently targets Awakening Councils.

summary:
Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) militants set fire to a bus, a taxi, and two other private vehicles on a highway in Petrolia, a small rural area near the border town of Tibu, Colombia close to Venezuela. Police reported that roughly ten FARC were involved in the attack though there were no casualties.
The attackers painted slogans on several other vehicles and used them to block the highway. FARC is Colombia's oldest and largest leftist guerrilla group and has an estimated 8-17,000 fighters still operating in the country. The group primarily relies on drug-trafficking, extortion, and kidnapping for ransom to finance its operations which target government and security forces, oil installations, and civilians.

summary:
Suspected Barisaon Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) separatist militants planted a bomb under the car of Army Staff Sergeant Surachai Chansoongnerm that went off in the morning at the military checkpoint in front of Wat Khao Khem Thong. Police report the bomb was detonated by remote control. The attack occurred in Narathiwat's Waeng district near Thailand's southern border with Malaysia. Both the soldier and his wife were injured by the homemade bomb.
Southern Thailand has a number of separatist Islamist militant groups who have been increasingly active over the past few weeks. The BRN-C is the most widespread and well-developed, however the New PULO is making a name for itself in Narathiwat and has shown bomb-making abilities.

Also in the Karan and Shibis districts of the city Hizbul Islam members attacked Somali government forces. Four people were killed including one civilian, and medical sources report at least 11 people were wounded.
The fighting comes after a week of uneasy silence in Mogadishu and Al-Shabaab and Hizbul Islam militants have been fighting each other near the southern port of Kismayo since early October.

summary:
Communist Party of India- Maoists (CPI-M) attacked a number of telecommunications towers in Gaya and Sheohar districts. There are some reports that three towers were set on fire in the Banke Bazaar area of Gaya district: two in Hussainganj village and the other in Baltharwa. Gaya police however say there were only two towers attacked. According to sources, a few dozen CPI-M attackers carrying sophisticated weapons took oil from the generators of the stations and used it to light the sites on fire.
Separately an estimated 45 militants bombed a tower of Airtel company, a private telecom firm and set ablaze a truck at Brindabazaar in the Sheohar district during the late night of October 12th.
There have been no reported casualties. This activity is perceived as part of the two-day bandh (meaning 'closed' or a general strike) which the CPI-M declared for the area. Telecommunications infrastructure is a common target choice of the CPI-M, though it does not always mean the targeting of the industry as opposed to inflicting general instability in an area.

In a separate incident, the Maoists raided a newly-built block office at Bandu Bagicha, and set fire to the building. There were no reported casualties.

summary:
A homemade bomb exploded at the army barracks of Santa Barbara, near the San Siro football stadium, in Italy's northern city of Milan, injuring two persons. One of the two men injured was the attacker who planted the bomb, the other wounded was an Italian carabinieri officer.
According to security sources, the man responsible for the explosion was a 39 year old Libyan national identified as Muhammad Game, who was stopped at the entrance of the army barracks when he set off his device. The man mostly suffered serious injuries to his hand and his face.
While the police had no immediate indication of the motives for the attack, Italian news agencies reported that the man shouted “Out of Afghanistan!” before detonating the bomb, which was rudimentary and not very powerful.
Italy, which currently has 3,100 troops deployed in Afghanistan, remains a potential target of Islamist terrorism.
However, the name of the attacker never emerged in any investigations into terrorism. Game is reportedly a legal Libyan immigrant, who lived in Italy since 2003 and is married to an Italian woman. He reportedly prayed regularly at the main mosque in Milan. Italian police are trying to determine whether the attack is an isolated episode or whether it is part of a broader strategy.

The hostages were later released.
Pamphlets were left at the scene claiming responsibility.

summary:
A bomb exploded in a marketplace, near a police station, in Shangla district near Pakistan's Swat valley, killing up to41 people and injuring 45. The explosion occurred at Alpur Chowkawhile a military convoy was passing by and military sources reported that members of the security forces were among the casualties.
The bombing, a suicide attack carried out by a 13-year-old boy, occurred the morning after Pakistanifighter jets bombed Taliban strongholds in South Waziristan near the Afghan border,in advance of animminentground military offensive in the tribal region.
The Pakistani Taliban (TTP) claimed responsibility for the attack. Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility on Monday morning for the weekend siege on army headquarters near Islamabad and vowed to activate militant cells across the country for more attacks.

summary:
Militants of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) killed three police officers in Orissa's Mayurbhanj district during a football match at Bandap village.
Among the casualties were a sub-inspector, a village guard, and the security guard of senior Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) leader and former Member of Parliament, Sudam Marandi. The party leader was about to hand over the trophy after the football tournament when CPI-M militants began firing at him.
CPI-M continue to target security forces thorughout India's eastern provinces, increasingly brazen attacks which have made the group a high priority for government forces in their planned upcoming offensive to clean it out of the region.

A roadside bomb targeting a police vehicle in Tikrit, Iraq killed a ranking officer and injured three others. No group has claimed the attack.
Tikrit, Saddam Hussein's hometown, is a predominantly Sunni city and has been the target of a number of attacks since 2005, frequently sectarian in nature. Police forces remain a high priority target throughout the country.

summary:
Two roadside bombs went off targeting civilians near the market area of Al-Mahmoudiya, roughly 20 miles south of Baghdad. The explosion killed one civilian and injured eight others. No group claimed the attack, though Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) was once heavily active in the area.
Al-Mahmoudiya has been a frequent target of attackers throughout the conflict in Iraq. The town is predominantly Shi'a while the surrounding area has a sizable Sunni population, likely impacting its selection as a target for sectarian violence that was once very high in the area; the market itself has been targeted by similar attacks as recently the last two months.

summary:
A suicide car bomb detonated in a parking lot near police headquarters in Ramadi, Iraq and the provincial council building in Ramadi. The vehicle reportedly detonated after driving into a wall at the police headquarters.
This was then followed by a first responder attack by a suicide bomber on a motorbike. A third attackinvolved a car bomb detonating outside the hospital where the wounded had been taken.
Reports of the total number of casualties varied, but there were thought to be 22 dead and 61 injured in all the attacks. No group claimed responsibility, although Al-Qaeda in Iraq is believed responsible.

summary:
A suicide bomber on a motorbike attacked a crowd of people and emergency services at the scene of where a suicide car bomb had detonated near police headquarters in Ramadi, Iraq. The second attack took place as crowds had begun to gather to assist those injured in the first blast.
A third blast then occurred when a static car bomb exploded outside the main hospital where the majority of casualties had been taken.
Reports on casualty numbers differed, although they suggested that 22people were killed and 61 injured in the attacks.
No group claimed responsibility, although Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected since the tactical sophistication of the attack bears its hallmarks.

summary:
25 heavily armed gunmen kidnapped 12 people from an improvised football field in the town of Chururu, western Venezuela near the border with Colombia. According to witnesses, the men drove up to the football game, asked the referee for the list of players on the Los Maniceros (The Peanut Vendors) team, then kidnapped them. Included were ten Colombians, one Venezuelan and one Peruvian. 12 days later the ten Colombians were found executed near the Colombian border.
Initially it was believed to be a Venezuelan guerrilla group called the Bolivarian Armed Liberation Forces. Analysts noted that the kidnapping may have occured because the members of the football team refused to join the leftist movement. Witnesses also reported that the incident may be debt-related.
A number of violent organizations, including guerillas, paramilitaries and drug traffickers operate in the border area where numerous kidnappings and other crimes occur.

summary:
A notorious pirate leader 'Samal' took Michael Sinnott 78, an Irish priest, hostage in Gatas District in Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur in the southern Philippines. It is believed the priest was kidnapped as part of a ransom plot and was handed over to allegedly Muslim rebels once belonging to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). MILF denies this and there are conflicting stories between the police and military sources.
Six gunmen entered the house in Pagadian City, Zamboanga Island and took the priest away at gunpoint. They then reportedly transported the priest to a waiting boat via a minivan and headed towards Tukuran. Sources suggest he is being held 30 kilometres from Pagadian in a remote area adjoining the Zamboanga Peninsula which is a MILF stronghold.
Samal was identified as being behind the abduction through one of his high-powered speed boats that was involved in a major gun battle in April between his criminal group and the Filipino military.
The MILF leadership has since firmly denied any involvement in the abduction.
At least 15 church figures have been kidnapped in Mindanao since 1993 including eight foreign nationals and seven Filipinos. The acting prelate of Marawi City was kidnapped in 1997 and held for two weeks before being released through the intercession of local Muslim and Christian religious leaders. In 2001 a Colombian missionary, Rufus Halley was kidnapped and murdered in Malabang.
*Father Michael Sinnott was released by his captors on the 12th November. No ransom was paid.
source_urls: The Philippine Star, BBC, Kidnap news

summary:
Members of Shining Path attacked a counter-insurgency base in Vizcatan, Peru during the night. One soldier was killed and another wounded during the attack and it is unknown whether the terrorists sustained any casualties.
The Shining Path has a presence in the Upper Huallaga Valley and the VRAE region (Valley of the Apurimac and Ene rivers). It is blamed for an increase in violence in the country's interior over recent months and the government is planning to send additional troops to the region to bolster security. Since the beginning of its activity in 1980, it is also charged with an estimated $25 billion in economic losses.

summary:
Gunmen dressed in military fatigues stormed the Pakistani Army GeneralHeadquarters in Rawalpindi, near Islamabad on Saturday. The attackers killed six Pakistani soldiers and losteight of their own men in the assault. The ring leader was captured alive and identified as Aqeel, alias Dr. Usman ofTahrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) and was believed to be the planner behind the attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team in Lahore on the 18th June, 2009. The gunmen have been identified as being highly trained and using tactics similar to those identified in the Manawa Police Academy siege in Lahore and the attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team.
The terrorists reportedly approached the military base in a whitejeep with military licence plates, and were wearing uniforms. They opened fire and threw a grenade at the main gate of the base. They were reportedly engaged in a firefight with the security forces for around forty minutes.
This initial attack was the prelude to the taking of 10 to 15 security forces personnel as hostages, including what were reportedly senior officers.
The attack came as the Pakistan army were preparing an incursion against Islamists in South Waziristan. The Pakistani Taliban announced their new strategy the previous week, when new leader Hakimullah Mehsud, warned that the Pakistani military would be the group's main target.
author: Unknown author

Pakistani police reported thatarmed motorcyclists opened fire at the truck using automatic weapons, killing two helpers aboard the vehicle.
Although no group claimed responsibility, the Taliban is suspected as it frequently carries out attacks on NATO supplies leaving from Pakistan.

summary:
Pakistani Taliban (TTP) members took 10-15 Pakistani security personnel hostage following an armed attack on the army headquarters in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. There were believed to be senior Pakistani army officers among those being held hostage.
The standoff continued into the night before Pakistani security forces stormed the base. In the ensuing firefight, three hostages, two soldiers and four terrorists were killed. Another terrorist was badly wounded and later arrested. The terrorist is believed to be the mastermind of the armed attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team in Lahore.
The TTP recently issued statements threatening the Pakistani army over previous confrontations and an imminent campaign against the militants in the Swat valley.

summary:
One person was killed when a bomb was detonated in the city of Derbent in the North Caucasus republic of Dagestan in the early hours of the morning. It was unclear whether the victim was a civilian or the militant who had planted the device near a town park. The explosion was the equivalent of about 4 kilogrammes of TNT. No group has claimed the attack, however Mayoral elections are due in Derbent on Sunday 11 October. It is possible the bomb was related to the upcoming elections. Dagestani Jamaat Sharia may have been involved.
Terrorist attacks and networks that were once largely centered in Chechnya have spread through other northern Caucasus republics; violent attacks have been on the rise especially in Ingushetia and Dagestan.

Local law enforcement sources said that a suspected militant, Akhmed-khan Aushev, was driving the car. He was killed in the explosion.
In what appears to be the same incident, Russian media reported a car explosion in the Magasskiy Krug district of Nazran city. However, the man who died in the explosion was identified as Mukharbek Bekov.
Terrorist incidentshave been on the rise in Ingushetia prior to the municipal elections due on Sunday 11 October.

The grenade explosions injured three policemen but there have been no other reproted casualties. No group has claimed the attack but Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) are possible suspects. AQI frequently targets police forces in the capital and throughout Iraq as a means of trying to counter government influence and authority.

summary:
A magnetic bomb was stuck to the underside of the car of the imam of Abduqadir Mosque in the town of Saqlawiyah, north of Fallujah. The imam and two of his security personnel got into the car after Friday prayers and the bomb exploded, killing all three.
The imam, Jamal Humadi, was a Sunni cleric who denounced insurgents in Iraq and was known for his opposition to Al-Qaeda and Sunni extremists. This is the second attack on such a figure in two weeks. Last week Sunni cleric Bashir Al-Juheishi was killed when a bomb attached to his car exploded in Mosul.
Activists and clerics who speak out against Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) and other insurgent groups have been attacked with some regularity. This tendency suggests the possibility of the waning insurgency shifting to a more targeted terror campaign. Military spokesmen for Baghdad security warned that insurgents were using booby-trapped cans of food and toys to carry out such targeted attacks as they are easily attached.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A vehicle packed with approximately 100 kg of explosives exploded near Khyber Bazaar in Peshawar. Reports differ as to how the attack was conducted. Some reports suggest that the device was hidden on a passing bus, others that it was hidden in a parked vehicle next to the market. Other accounts suggest that it was remotely detonated or conducted by a suicide bomber. Several other vehicles were destroyed in the explosion. It has been confirmed so far that 54 people were killed and over 100 injured.
No group has claimed the attack, although evidence suggests that the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is the group most likely to be responsible. The attack is most likely to be in response to the upcoming offensive of Pakistani troops in the Waziristan region.
Local officials and police report that it is the second substantial attack in the past few months after the bombing of the Pearl Continental Hotel in June that killed 18. Also of note is that following the attack on the WFP building in Islamabad earlier this week that Peshawar was not considered one of the necessary security zones. This attack thus suggests that higher security measures will be taken in more of Pakistan's major cities.
Security forces have made gains against the TTP this year who have set off bombs in towns and cities, but the attack shows that despite the measurable successes the TTP is still a significant threat to the country.
source_urls: Al Jazeera, ESISC, Indian Express, BBC, AP
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) militants ambushed seven pickup trucks carrying soldiers back to their base in Ban Santi village in the Bannang Sata district of Yala province in southern Thailand. The attackers set off a roadside bomb at a bridge on the Krong Penang-Bannang Sata road at 11:45. The bomb damaged the fourth truck in the convoy and then the attackers opened fire at the soldiers for about five minutes before retreating. Ten soldiers were injured in the attack.
The BRN-C are the most widespread radical Islamist group in the region as well as the most developed, specializing in roadside bombs and armed attacks on security forces.
This incident seems to come as part of a series of attacks over the past few days in multiple provinces in the southern region where a number of radical Islamist movements are active.

summary:
An estimated 200 Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) militants in western India's Maharashtra State ambushed 45 police patrolmen during the day near the city of Gadchiroli, an area known for Maoist activity. 17 police were killed in the attack and several more wounded. According to police the gunfight lasted three hours before the CPI-M took the weapons of the slain police and fled back to the forest.
The ambush was one of the bloodiest attacks by the Maoists at a time when India's central government is preparing for a major paramilitary offensive against them. Earlier in the day, police allege the Maoists attacked a government office in the same region.
The ambush comes two days after the CPI-M beheaded an officer elsewhere in a nearby province and serves as reminder of their increasingly brazen tactics.
The attack is likely to intensify pressure on the government to take action against the group . Prime Minister Singh has described the CPI-M as the gravest internal threat to India's security. In recent months, as Maoist violence has steadily risen, paramilitary soldiers have been training for an offensive that could begin as soon as November.

summary:
During morning rush-hour a suicide bomber blew up a car outside the Indian embassy in Kabul. The car was packed with +100 kgs of explosives and the detontationwas large, flattening walls and rattling windows up to a mile away. The head of Kabul's hospitals announced that at least 17 people were killed and another 67 were wounded in the attack that occurred on the busy road which also houses Afghanistan's Interior ministry. The Taliban is believed to be responsible for the attack.
It is reported that two Afghan guards (who died in the blast)were responsible for stopping the vehicle having identified it as suspicious. Had the vehicle gained access to the embassy compound experts suggest the damage would have been worse than the July 2008 attack as the quantity of explosives carried by the vehicle was much larger than the previous device.
In July 2008 the Indian embassy was the target of the deadliest attack in Kabul since the invasion started in 2001, in which 58 people were killed and 141 were injured. The bombing today, similar in size to the one in July, is thought to be the fourth large attack in Kabul since August.

It is reported the attacker, dressed as a Frontier Corps paramilitary officer blew himself up between the finance department and the lobby. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack but the Taliban is highly suspected. About eight kilograms of explosives were detonated.
UN spokesman Ishrat Rizvi said that the UN offices in Pakistan would be temporarily closed but no further threat had been received. The attack is one of the most serious incidents to have taken place in the capital since July and police forces have tightened security across the city and alerted security throughout the country.
The attack is the latest in a recent series of suicide bombings in Pakistan as the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) vow to carry out retaliatory attacks across the country for the killing of their leader Baitullah Mehsud in a US missile strike on 5 August 2009.

Since the kidnapping the Orgun police have increased security around expatriates in the state.

Close to 45,000 people have been killed in the 25 years since the PKK took up arms against the government to establish self-rule in the Kurdish south-east. It is considered a terrorist group by Turkey, the US and the EU.

One of the vehicles was damaged in the attack, and one policeman was killed and four others wounded. No group has claimed the attack.
However Al-Mashtal is a predominantly Shi'a area, possibly indicating yet another sectarian attack in the city that has been on the rise since June. On the other hand, security and police forces remain a high priority target for all radical militant groups in the country.

summary:
It has been reported that around 09:00 a fuel truck exploded near Abbas Ibn Firnas square close to Baghdad International Airport. According to Interior Ministry sources an adhesive bomb was stuck to a fuel truck and was detonated while a convoy of fuel tankers were queing to cross a checkpoint on the main road leading to the airport. Others state that the source of the explosion was an accident.
There are conflicting reports on the incident. There is confusion about whether the truck was heading to US military base Camp Victory or instead to the airport, or if it was part of a convoy. Some report there were five people were killed, others make no casualty claims. It seems consistent that at least five civilian drivers were injured by the explosion. Three trucks and other civilian vehicles were also burnt in the fire.
No group has claimed the attack but Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is the most likely suspect if the incident is deemed an attack. Along those lines, it is likely that the bomb aimed to disrupt military forces arriving and departing from the airport.

The explosion occurred moments after a package was delivered to the residence and neighbours reported a strong smell of gunpowder after the explosion occurred.
Other causes for the explosion were ruled out after gas cylinders were discovered intact in the house.
Police are continuing their investigations but have no clear suspected attackers.

Local official sources said the attack was a retaliatory act for the villagers' refusal to pay the extortion demands of the NDFB militants. The NDFB is blamed for a string of bomb attacks across Assam last year that killed approximately 87 people.
Tribal violence and separatist insurgencies are a significant concern for a number of India's northeastern states.

An unidentified individual planted an adhesive explosive device on the window of the bank and hastily fled the scene before the device exploded. The front window of the bank was damaged by the explosion and later investigations determined it to have been caused by a small quantity of plastic explosive.
On the 20th November 2003 a bomb attack was organised against the HSBC Bank in Istanbul's Levent District killing 17 and injuring hundreds more.

summary:
Approximately 300 Taliban fighters hiding in a village and mosque in Kamdesh District of Nuristan Province, Afghanistan attacked two remote security outposts at first lightnear the Pakistani border. Fighting lasted for six hours. Eight American and seven AfghanNational Army (ANA) soldiers were killed, and 24 US soldiers were woundedin one of the fiercest battles of the war so far. The Taliban also took 15 police officers hostage including the local police chief and his deputy when they breached the heavy perimeter defences of the combat outpost. Over 100 enemy were claimed to have been killed during the battle when US forces called in multiple strikes from close air and aviation support.
The complex attack was launched from three separate directions and a combination of Taliban mortars, rockets and heavy machine gun fire succeeded in destroying a significant proportion of the combat outpost.
US military sources report that it was a complex attack in ahighly mountainous and difficultarea. In July 2008 a similar complexraid in Nuristan claimed the lives of nine American servicemen where militantsused a similarcombination of heavy weapons.
Afghanistan's Nuristan and Kunar provinces are considered Al-Qaedastrongholds among othermilitant groups.
Reports claim US forces were just days away from pulling out of the combat outpost. A full US withdrawal has now been carried out from the Kamdesh region since the attacks took place.

The MFDC attack, one of the most deadly in recent years, was the third since early September to occur in the Casamance region which is separated geographically from the rest of Senegal to the north by Gambia.
The MFDC began an armed uprising in the early 1980s over the question of independence for the Casamance region and increasingly targeted civilians through attacks on farmers and looting.

Military sources reported that the MNLF used assault rifles and mortars in the attack.
Although the MNLF signed a peace agreement with the Philippine government in 1996, clashes between military troops and militants remain frequent in the predominantly Muslim island of Jolo.
According to government sources, the Panamao attack is not related to a land mine attack that killed a Filipino marine and two U.S. soldiers Tuesday 29 September in Jolo's Indanan township. summary:
In the early hours, Al-Shabaab launched an armed attack on Hizbul Islam strongholds in Somalia's southern port town of Kismayo. After several hours of fighting, Al-Shabaab took control of Kismayo's northern neighborhoods where Hizbul Islam fighters had established their positions earlier in the week. Hizbul Islam is reported to have withdrawn from the town in the evening.
More than 30 people were killed during the attack, including 10 civilians. Local medical sources reported 70 injured persons and said that the Kismayo's main hospital was rapidly overcrowded.
Senior commanders of Al-Shabaab and Hizbul Islam were reportedly killed during the fighting, including Aden Dhagoweyne, Al-Shabaab's commander for the Jubba regions, where Kismayo is located. According to local reports, the commander of the Anole fighters, one of the four groups that merge in February 2009 to form Hizbul Islam, was also killed.
Hizbul Islam and Al-Shabaab both seek to overthrow Somalia's interim government in Mogadishu but disagree over control of the Jubba regions.

The explosion killed one civilian and wounded two others. No group has claimed the attack but the Taliban is suspected.
While the Pakistan-Afghan border has been an area of continuous instability, Khost Province has experienced heightened levels of militant activity in the past months likely due to the military offensives against the Taliban launched in the northwestern areas of Pakistan. summary:
20-30 heavily armed New People's Army (NPA) rebels set fire to nine pieces of heavy equipment of a construction company hired to build the Baguio city-Bontoc road in Mountain province. No casualties were reported.
Identifying themselves as NPA militants, the attackers woke up the RUA Construction firm’s employees before dawn to lecture them about the delay of their wages, low salary, and corruption allegedly committed by the contractor. Meanwhile, other NPA guerrillas were setting on fire six transit mixers and three Komatsu backhoes.
Due for completion in December 2009, the project is part of the government’s SONA (State of the Nation Address) and involves the seven-kilometer Package 5 of the Baguio-Bontoc Road (Halsema Highway). RUA Construction is also carrying out other concreting projects, including those on the Bontoc-Tinglayan (Kalinga) Highway.
Opposing the foreign ownership of Philippine’s resources, the NPA continues to call for "revolutionary taxation" on foreign companies and attempts to disrupt their operations in the area.

summary:
A IED landmine blast near the city of Indanan killed two American soldiers and a Filipino soldier and injured two others in Jolo, Philippines while they were traveling in a vehicle near a marine outpost. It is believed that Abu Sayyaf was behind the attack, trained by bomb experts of the regional terror group Jemaah Islamiyah (JI). The attack is the first to exact American deaths since 2002 when one serviceman died in an bombing in the port city of Zamboanga, also in the south of the country.
The US has about 300 soldiers in the southern Philippines advising the local security forces in fighting insurgents.The Philippines' military said last week that it had captured Indanan after heavy fighting, a stronghold of Abu Sayyaf rebels. The use of the IED indicates direct contact between Abu Sayaf and radical militants in Indonesia.
Abu Sayyaf is one of the smallest but deadliest Islamist militant groups in the largely Roman Catholic Philippines. Established in the early 1990s, it has kidnapped dozens of foreign aid workers, missionaries and tourists in the south and was blamed for the country's worst terrorist strike, the bombing of a ferry in 2004 that killed more than 100 people.

specific_target: Minister of Water and Power Esmail Khan
summary:
A Taliban suicide attack targeted the convoy of the Minister of Water and Power, Esmail Khan in the Enjil District of western Herat Province.
The attack took place near a police checkpoint on a road between Herat city and the airport in Enjil District. The bomber was pretending to check his tyre when he detonated car bomb as the Minister's convoy drove past.
The Minister was unharmed but the attack killed four civilians and injured 17.
The Minister is a high-profile target. He is well known for having been a prominent Jihadi commander against Soviet rule before establishing a secure administration in Herat province. He was targeted following a public speech made the day before urging fellow former Jihadi commanders to cease fighting against the Afghan government and foreign forces.

summary:
A Head of Administration in the Chechen Republic, Ali Artamov, and his son were assassinated in Achkhoy-Martanovskiy District, Chechnya, Russia.
Artamov was the Head Administration in the settlement of Staryy Achkhoy, in the Achkhoy-Martanovskiy District.
Artamov was shot by two unidentified gunmen, with automatic weapons, as he got out of his car. His son was killed as he ran out of his school building to stop the gunmen from driving away.
The gunmen's car was later found near the village of Yandi. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Chechen Jamaat is suspected.

summary:
Al-Shabaab reportedly hijacked a plane carrying Somali MP's arriving from Nairobi, Kenya, as it landed at No. 50 Airstrip in the Lower Shabeelle Region. Local sources report that armed members of the group surrounded the airplane, hijacked it, but soon released it.
Other reports claim that Al-Shabaab attempted but failed to hijack the plane before it originally took off.
The administration of the airport is said to be concealing the incident.

summary:
A bomb, described by the police chief as a locally-made device, exploded in a busy market area in Gilgit in northern Pakistani Kashmir, killing one and injuring four others. All victims worked at the market.
Angry street demonstrations followed the attack. Police used tear gas and aerial firing to disperse crowds with one policeman killed.
No one claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A mini-truck exploded in a suicide attack against the Mandan police station in Bannu district, Peshawar, killing 12 people and injuring 65. Those killed were inmates at the prison and those injured included 30 policemen and 35 civilians.
Police claim the mini-truck used contained 320kg of explosives and the impact left an eight feet deep pit at the site. Areas damaged include the police station, a mosque, several houses and 20 shops.
Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility for the attack to avenge the killing of their leader Baitullah Mehsud in a US drone attack. The bomber is believed to be a teenage boy of 14-15 years.
The city has been put on high security alert following this attack and a similar attack some hours later, also in Peshawar.

summary:
A car bomb exploded at the Saddar Bazaar in Peshawar Cantt, killing 11 and injuring 88. The car was parked on the main Fakhar-e-Alam road. The target is thought to be the Askari bank, which is run by an army welfare trust. This bank was the target of a bomb last year.
The car was carrying 100kg of explosives. The suicide bomber first threw a hand-grenade towards the bank before detonating the car bomb.
This attack is thought to be linked to an attack on a police station in Bannu district, Peshawar, a few hours earlier. The city has been put on high security alert following the two attacks.
Though unconfirmed, Tehrik-e-Taliban Paksitan, who claimed responsibility for the earlier attack, is thought to have also carried out this attack.

The building was demolished with rocket fire but there were no casualties.
Two years earlier, Taliban destroyed a tower of another mobile company, Roshan, in the same province.

summary:
A group calling itself the Subversive Alliance for the Liberation of the Earth, Animals, and Humans (ASLTAH) claimed an attack on a Banamex bank branch in the Milpa Alta area of Mexico City. The explosive device, consisting of four butane canisters, was set off about 02:00. The explosion damaged the front of the building but incurred no casualties.
The bombing was the seventh of the month reported for Mexico City, five of which targeted banks. The ASLTAH, a group with a confluence of anti-imperialist, anarchist and eco-terrorist motivations, claimed several other recent IED attacks. This wave of attacks is thought linked to the fact that September is considered the 'patriotic' month as it marks Mexico declaring its independence for Spain.

The explosion, which occurred just nine days before Greece's parliamentary elections, targeted a socialist candidate to the upcoming elections and a former minister. None of them was injured.
No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
While Greek authorities reported that attacks from leftist militant groups have diminished since the 2002 dismantlement of the country's major anarchist group, November 17, Greece has a long history of far-left terrorist activity.

summary:
Unidentified armed men shot at police in Yanbu, Saudi Arabia. Initial reports suggest that five policemen were injured. When the police fired back, they killed two attackers and injured one other.
Saudi authorities do not believe the attack is linked to Al-Qaeda, despite a message released by Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula earlier in the day threatening more attacks on the Kingdom.
Terrorist attacks are rare in Saudi Arabia, however this is the second notable attack in the past two months. Earlier, a suicide bomber concealed explosives in his body and attempted to assassinate Prince Nayef, the head of Saudi security affairs. The Prince was only slightly injured in the attack.
Yanbu was previously attacked in 2004. At least four militants used security passes to access a local petrochemical plant on 1 May. The armed men attacked the Texas-based ABB Lummus facility and killed seven people.

On Friday 17 September, the AU headquarters in Mogadishu was hit by two suicide car bombs, killing 17 peacekeepers. The attack, launched by Al-Shabaab, was to avenge the death of Saleh Ali Saleh Nabhan, a suspected Al-Qaeda member killed during a raid by US special forces on 14 September.

summary:
Unidentified men shot and killed a Muslim cleric in his car in Karachayevo-Cherkessia, Russia. Islamil Berdiev was the deputy chairman of the Muslim spiritual board of the republic. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. The cleric's son was injured the the attack.
This was not the first attack on him. In 2006 three masked men broke into his home and attacked him. He was injured in that incident.
This most recent attack took place outside the normal area of operations for terrorists in Russia. However, the group Jamaat Karachai has been known to operate in the area. This may indicate a possible spill-over of terrorist activity from Dagestan, Chechnya and Ingushetia. Muslim clerics in other conflict zones such as Iraq and Afghanistan have been targeted for their disapproval of terrorist tactics by groups. Berdiev was actively against Wahhabism; he had urged all Muslims to unite against it.

summary:
Members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) and suspected members of the Abu Sayyaf attacked and killed eight Philippine Marine soldiers. Nine other troops were injured in the ambush staged by the terrorist in Sulu, southern Philippines, in the periphery of Indanan city.
Reportedly, three Abu Sayyaf terrorists were killed during the attack and five others were wounded. Military sources stated that the attackers came from the Abu Sayyaf camp at Sitio Talibang in Barangay Buansa, which the Marines had seized the day before, on Sunday 20, September. The Philippine military stated that they expected more attacks from Abu Sayyaf.
Abu Sayyaf is based in the Phillippines and seeks a separate Islamic state for the country's Muslim minority. The group is suspected to have ties to the Al-Qaeda network, as well as the Indonesian network of Jemaah Islamiyah and now to the MILF.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists shot dead two Special Police Officers (SPOs) near Shikri Top in Marmat area of Doda District of Jammu and Kashmir.
The Senior Superintendent of Police of Doda District said that three SPOs, who were on way back home at Gajot, were intercepted by a group of five to seven militants at Shikri Top at around 17:00.  He stated that the militants had laid a ‘C' type ambush from thick vegetation. Two SPOs were killed on the spot while a third managed to survive by taking cover behind the crops. As back-up, security forces responded and the militants escaped with weapons and communications equipment they had seized.
Security forces subsequently launched a search operation in the area to arrest the militants, who they said they were suspected Lashkar-e-Toiba members.
According to media sources, the killing of SPOs may have been a retaliation by the militants to the elimination of their over 20 top associates in Doda District during last three months.

According to reports, the bomb exploded in a street near the Darwaza-e Khosh area of the city. The local police commander said the bomb had been placed in a hand bag. He added that the elder who was wounded was an influential figure, Khowja Hajji Soltan, and was the likely target of the attack. Hajji Soltan had previously served as a member of the Taliban and was a close friend of a prominent Taliban commander, Gholam Yahya Akbari, in the Gozara District of Herat Province.
The Taliban did not release a statement regarding the incident.

Five of the explosions were in Hlaingthaya at the Maz Beverages factory, a cigarette factory, and an excavator rental site. The explosion in Shwe Paukkan was near Jonah Garment Factory around midnight. The bombs caused some minor damage but no casualties.
The bombs are thought to be linked with some form of political protest against the ruling military junta. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

The attack sparked confrontations between African Union forces and Al-Shabaab militia scattered throughout Mogadishu.
The two trucks were stolen UN vehicles and were allowed onto the base due to their UN markings. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack claiming that it was revenge for the killing of an Al-Shabaab recruiter killed in southern Somalia on Monday.

summary:
Terrorists from the Animal Liberation Front claimed left an explosive device outside of a MaxMara store in the Polanco area of Mexico City. It claimed the attack was to protest the clothing company's use of furs. MaxMara has been targeted in several countries by other animal rights groups. The attack resulted in no casualties, but it was one of seven attacks by related groups in Mexico for the month of September.
In the last year attacks by anarchist, animal rights and ecological terrorist groups have increased in Mexico; they have also steadily increased their use of explosive devices as opposed to more low-grade sabotage and arson attacks.

summary:
A security guard stopped three men wearing burqas in the Shell oil depot in Karachi, Pakistan. The three started shooting at the security guard and then fled. The security guard died of his injuries. No damage to the Shell facility was reported.
It is unknown if the men were attempting to carry out an operation or leave supplies for a future attack. Police recovered three Kalashnikovs, 10 loaded magazines, 10 hand grenades, three burqas and three purses.
This is an usual incident. Attacks on extractive facilities are uncommon in Karachi. It can be inferred that the group planning on attacking this international business facility has international as well as domestic goals. It would also require substantial planning and resources.
Security sources suspect that the attack was a retaliatory act for the anti-Taliban operations carried out in the north-western provinces of the country to eradicate Baitullah Mehsud's network, linked to Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). Karachi has long been a centre of activity for Taliban and Al-Qaeda linked groups who are believed to have staged bank robberies, kidnapping for ransom and other criminal activities to raise funds.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

The motivation for the attacks is not fully known although police had recently been involved in raids on suspected terrorists' homes. Following the end of the Gulf war, there was a large influx of Arab civilians into the Kirkuk area. This has led to increased tension between Arabs and Kurds in the region.

summary:
Unidentified terrorists ambushed India Reserve Battalion (IRB) personnel, killing four of them, in an ambush on a hilly road of Ngakha hill, Imphal East on the morning of 12 September. The security forces were reportedly deployed at Maphou dam on a tri-junction of Imphal East, Thoubal and Ukhrul districts. The soldiers were in a bullet-proof truck and a 'gypsy' vehicle when they came under heavy fire from terrorists positioned on Ngakha hill.
The terrorists, who reportedly numbered 100, had rocket launchers, guns and other sophisticated weapons on them. The first attack involved the militants firing the rear of a truck, which was following the other vehicle.
The police believe the People's Liberation Army (PLA) was behind the attack.

summary:
A car bomb detonated outside Srinagar's main jail, killing at least two policemen and a civilian. The attack, outside a prison, injured ten other officers, some critically. The car bomb exploded as a police bus drove past.
The car bomb was reportedly triggered through the use of a remote controlled device. Initial police investigations revealed that the terrorists had used nearly 50 kg of highly explosive material, suspected to be RDX.
The attack coincided with a recent upsurge in violence in the region, with three policeman killed in attacks in the past three months.
No group claimed responsibility, though separatist Islamist groups have waged an insurgency in Srinagar for decades. In particular, Indian police believes Lashkar-e-Toiba (LeT) militant Muddasir, also known as "Doctor Saheb" to be the mastermind of the attack. Police is also on the look out for a Pakistani national identified as Rahman, who is alleged to have planted the bomb outside the prison.

summary:
Police in Armagh, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom found a 600 pound bomb in the Forkhill area. It was hidden in a hedge alongside a road. A detonating wire ran to a firing point across the border in Ireland. A bomb disposal squad defused it and no injuries were caused. The smallest republican dissident organisation, Oglaigh nah Eireann, was behind the attempted attack.
The target of the attack could have been local police, as recent dissident republican attacks have targeted security forces. Security authorities stated that this bomb was larger than the one which exploded at Omagh. If the bomb exploded, it is unlikely that the damage would be contained to the intended target.
The explosives were fertiliser-based and were home-made. A telephone warning call was made to a local newspaper.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Oglaigh na hEireann (ONH), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Amerli, Iraq. It killed the chief of counter terrorism and three of his security guards. One other was injured. No group claimed the attack.
The Iraqi provinces most afflicted by terrorism continue to be Diyala and Anbar along with the capital, Baghdad.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Tirkit, Iraq. It targeted the motorcade of the first deputy of the governor of Salahuddin province. The deputy governor was not injured, however one policeman was injured. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
Government officials continue to be frequently targeted by terrorists in Iraq. The number of terrorist attacks in Tikrit has declined in the past year.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Tuz, Kirkuk, Iraq. It was planted in front of the house of a judge. No casualties or damages were reported. No group claimed the attack.
Attacks on legal figures remain rare in Iraq.

summary:
Suspected members of the Kongra-Gel (PKK) ambushed Turkish soldiers in Siirt, Turkey. A total of five soldiers and five PKK members were killed in the attack. Five Turkish soldiers were also wounded.
The PKK has carried out sporadic terrorist attacks against Turkish military personnel throughout the summer months.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Kongra-Gel (PKK/KGK), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A local councilwoman was found dead in her home from a number of knife wounds around her head and neck. Police believe that members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) may be responsible. FARC is known to be active in Huila province and has targeted members of local councils in the past.
No group has claimed responsibility for this attack.

Suspected members of the Gerakan Mujahideen Islami Pattani (GMIP) shot and killed a teacher in Pattani, Thailand. The man taught at the Islamic school of Amanasak. He was attacked as he was driving to work on his motorcycle.
Teachers are commonly targeted by Islamic groups in the area. They represent symbols of the state.

summary:
Members of the Taliban attacked a logistics convoy in the Sayedabad area of Wardag, Afghanistan. The convoy was carrying supplies for foreign forces. Three security guards were killed and three vehicles were set on fire.

The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack. The group frequently targets logistics convoys, particularly in Wardag province.

summary:
A suicide car bomber drove into the main gate of Kabul airport's military base in Afghanistan. He killed two Afghan civilians and wounded six others. Afghan security sources stated that the car drove into a foreign military convoy.
No group claimed the attack, however the Taliban is suspected. It carried out a previous suicide bombing against the airport in 2007. Kabul airport is used by both military and civilian aircraft.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Unidentified men kidnapped eight doctors working in the Baghlan-e-Markazi district hospital in Afghanistan. The doctors were kidnapped as they were en route to the hospital. No group claimed the attack. The Taliban has not previously kidnapped this many doctors from one hospital.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified men attacked a convoy of NATO oil tankers in Quetta, Pakistan. A total of eight oil tankers were destroyed. The tankers were parked at the time of the attack. After the armed men fired indiscriminately at the tankers, they set them on fire.
Attacking oil tankers is a frequent tactic by Islamist terrorist groups intent on attacking coalition forces.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Oil tankers with fuel for coalition forces
summary:
Unidentified armed men attacked two oil tankers on the Peshawar Ring Road in Pakistan. The oil tankers were supplying fuel to foreign forces in Afghanistan. Two armed men shot at the tankers. The attack injured three civilians. No group claimed the attack.
A majority of the attacks on supply trucks take place in the Peshawar area in the early morning.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: A bomb exploded in Baghdad, Iraq. It targeted the convoy of health minister Dr. Ali Al-Fartosi. Dr. Al-Fartosi is in charge of eastern Baghdad's medical facilities. One ministry employee died in the attack, but the doctor was unharmed. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

specific_target: Civilians and police at a checkpoint in Ramadi
summary:
A suicide car bomber attacked a checkpoint in Ramadi, Iraq. He killed three policemen and five civilians. Approximately 16 other people were wounded. The car bomber targeted a line of vehicles at the checkpoint near a bridge in Ramadi.
While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, there has been a string of suicide bombings by Sunni groups in the area. Many of the attacks target Sunni Awakening groups or leaders.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Civilians/General Public

summary:

Baquba is a predominately Sunni city. Multiple suicide attacks on Shi'as have taken place there. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected.

summary:

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Taliban is suspected.

summary:

No group claimed responsibility for the incident. Similar attacks have taken place in the Zugdidi area before. The attacks targeted the railway and central train station in June 2009.

summary:

Terrorist groups such as Chechen Jamaat operate in the area. Policemen have become almost daily targets in Chechnya, Dagestan and Ingushetia. A majority of the attacks are small scale bombings or armed attacks.

Unidentified armed men shot at the head of the Charsada district in Khost, Afghanistan. He was in a car on his way home from a mosque after evening prayers. Neither he nor his security guards were injured.

Al-Qaeda and Iraq and the Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility for the two large truck bombings of Iraqi ministries in August 2009. The attacks were some of the largest in Baghdad in terms of damage and casualties in the last few months.

The Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) blew up a mobile phone tower in Malkangiri, Orissa, India. Sanchar Nigam Limited, a state-owned company, owned the tower. In addition to attacking the mobile phone tower, the CPI-M also blocked roadways nearby with trees.
The CPI-M often carry out such attacks during their imposed 'shut-downs' or strikes. The group called the strike to demand employment for tribal youths.

A New York Times reporter and his translator were kidnapped by suspected members of the Taliban in Chahar Dara, Afghanistan. The reporter went to the area to investigate a NATO airstrike on a Taliban captured oil truck which allegedly killed over 90 civilians.
The reporter was rescued on 9 September by British and Afghan forces. During the rescue operation, the reporter's interpreter was killed.

summary:
A bomb exploded in Ingushetia, Russia. It killed three police officers on patrol in the area. Two others were wounded. The bomb was believed to be a remote-controlled one. No group claimed responsibility, however Ingush Jamaat Sharia operate in the region.
Attacks on police have become almost a daily occurrence in Ingushetia. Recently, the rise in the number of suicide bombings prompted authorities to increase security in the region.

summary:
Members of the Earth Liberation Front (ELF) toppled two radio towers in Snohomish, Washington, USA. The towers belonged to a family-owned radio station: KRKO-AM. One of the towers was 349 feet tall. The towers were taken down via a piece of construction equipment which was already on site.
A spokesman for the ELF said that the towers had to be taken down due to environmental concerns. A banner with the ELF initials was left at the scene.

summary:
A 'sticky bomb' exploded in Amil, Baghdad, Iraq. It wounded three civilians. The bomb was attached to the underside of the car. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
The number of attacks on Shi'as has increased in Iraq. A majority of these attacks are more than likely carried out by Sunni groups hoping to decrease the stability of the government by inciting sectarian tensions.

summary: A 'sticky bomb' exploded in Dora, Baghdad, Iraq. It injured the leader of a Sunni Awakening group and his three bodyguards. Attacks in Basra are rare. A majority of the terrorist attacks in Iraq take place in Baghdad and in the provinces of Diyala and Anbar.

summary:
A car bomb exploded outside the Rukn al-Aza'im restaurant in Baquba, Iraq. It killed two civilians and injured ten others. Authorities suspect that the restaurant was targeted because it was open during the day. During Ramadan, Muslims fast during the day.
No group claimed responsibility, however Al-Qaeda in Iraq has carried out operations in Baquba.

A bomb exploded at a Shi'a shrine in Mussayib, Babil, Iraq. It killed four civilians and wounded 24 others. The bombing took place as Shi'as were arriving at the mosque after breaking the Ramadan fast. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however radical Sunni groups are suspected.
Sunni groups continue to attack Shi'a in order to insight sectarian conflict and destabilise the country.
