attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Buddhists at a restaurant in Pattani
summary:
Two bombs exploded near a restaurant in Muang, Pattani, Thailand. One of the bombs was concealed in a motorcycle. They killed one Buddhist civilian and injured 28 others. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, the Gerakan Mujahideen Islami Pattani (GMIP) is suspected. The restaurant was targeted because it is where Buddhist villagers have their lunch.
There has been an increase in attacks targeting Buddhists in Thailand. A 50kg bomb in a pickup truck exploded outside the Suan Kluay restaurant on Thammawithi Road in Narathiwat, Thailand. It injured 42 civilians and damaged five vehicles and six houses. The bombing targeted a group of Buddhist politicians having lunch in the restaurant. Among the injured was the district chief of Narathiwat. The Runda Kumpalan Kecil (RKK) is suspected.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Gerakan Mujahidin Islami Pattani (GMIP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Members of the Taliban attacked and stole two fuel tankers in Konduz, Afghanistan. They killed two of the drivers. The Taliban claimed the attack.
One of the fuel tankers was blown up by a NATO air strike in Konduz province. Authorities believe that multiple Taliban members were killed. However, international news agencies reported civilian casualties. The fuel tanker became stuck after an attempted river crossing. The Taliban then told nearby villagers to take the diesel. The exact number killed is unknown.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in front of the Athens Stock Exchange in Greece. It injured one civilian and damaged the building and six nearby cars. The bomb was concealed in a stolen van and blew out several windows of the building.
An anonymous warning call was made to a Greek newspaper 40 minutes before the explosion.
At the same time, a second bomb exploded in Thessaloniki outside a government building responsible for the northern Greek provinces of Macedonia and Thrace. It caused minor damage to the government building and to a car dealership nearby. No casualties were reported.
Revolutionary Struggle claimed the attack. Its adherence to far-left ideology prompts them to attack symbols of capitalist culture such as financial institutions such as banks and symbols of the Greek government such as police facilities and political parties.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Revolutionary Struggle (RS), perpetrator_type: Far Left/Revolutionary,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Thessaloniki, Greece. It caused no injuries but damaged the Ministry for Macedonia and Thrace and a car dealership. The bomb was planted in a telephone box behind the government building. A warning call was made to a newspaper before the bombing.
The bomb exploded around the same time as one outside the Athens Stock Exchange. That incident caused one civilian injury and damaged the building. The stock market was open for trading on 2 September.
No group claimed responsibility for either incident. However, the far-left group Revolutionary Struggle is suspected. It has carried out similar bombings in Athens and Thessaloniki before. Its adherence to far-left ideology prompts them to attack symbols of capitalist culture such as financial institutions such as banks and symbols of the Greek government such as police facilities and political parties.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Revolutionary Struggle (RS), perpetrator_type: Far Left/Revolutionary,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a traffic checkpoint on the Kavkaz motorway in Makhachkala's Kirovskiy district in Russia. The attack killed one civilian and wounded nine others. Among the wounded includes six officers from the Dagestan Interior Ministry and three staffers from the Dagestan centre for disaster medicine.
The bomb's explosives were the equivalent of 40kg of TNT. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
Two other car bomb attacks took place in Makhachkala on 1 September. The first targeted a police station and wounded three policemen. The second was a suicide car bombing in the outskirts of the city. It killed one and wounded 14 others. The intended target of this second attack was unknown. Russian authorities believe that the suicide bomber was planning on detonating his explosives in the city centre. However, when he was stopped by Russian traffic police at a checkpoint, he detonated his explosives.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Armed men entered a mosque in Mosul, Iraq. They shot and killed two men inside it. The identity of the civilians killed has not been revealed.
Sunni terrorist groups such as Al-Qaeda in Iraq operate in the area. They often target civilians who work with or support the Iraq government. Sunni groups in Iraq have been attacking Shi'a civilians in places such as Baghdad and Mosul possibly to reignite sectarian tensions and destabilise the present government.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Adhamiya, Baghdad, Iraq. It wounded two civilians. The bomb was attached to the underside of the car. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
The use of sticky bombs continues to be a preferred tactic among terrorist groups operating in the area. Many of the attacks in Baghdad target Shi'a civilians as well as Iraqi police and military personnel.

summary:
Suspected members of Shining Path shot down a Peruvian army helicopter in the Ene and Apurimac River Valleys (VRAE) region. The incident killed two soldiers and wounded one other.
The helicopter was going to the VRAE region to rescue three soldiers wounded during a counter-terrorism operation in the region. The soldiers had engaged in a skirmish with the rebels. It is possible that the Shining Path members set up the skirmish to lure the helicopter rescue team to the area and then strike the helicopter. The rebels would have either used a long range machine gun or a shoulder-launched missile.
Shining Path has carried out similar attacks against other Peruvian army helicopters in the region.

summary:
Suspected members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) attacked a police force escorting teachers in Yala's Kabang district in Thailand. They hid a bomb in a motorcycle parked alongside the road. It was detonated as an armoured car passed by. No injuries were reported, however the vehicle was damaged.
The BRN-C primarily operates in Yala province. It has attacked teacher escort convoys before. Teachers are attacked in the southerns provinces because they are symbols of Thai government authority and Buddhist and Thai culture. .

While no group claimed the attack, the minister was a critic of the Pakistani Taliban.

The deputy chief was among other Afghan officials, including a provincial council head and two public representatives, inaugurating a new mosque in the city. A total of 21 others were killed and 35 injured.
The Taliban claimed the attack. A group spokesman said that the Taliban would continue to target government officials throughout the country.

summary:
Suspected members of the Taliban killed four employees and a driver from a private security company near Asmar in Konar, Afghanistan. The men were driving towards Ghaziabad when an ambush took place.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked the Saudi Ministry of the Interior office in Jeddah. The man entered the building under the pretense of surrendering to authorities and detonated explosived hidden within his body near the office of Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the current leader of the Saudi Arabian counterterrorism strategy. He was injured in the attack.
The terrorist and his brother are on the Saudi government's list of 85 wanted militants. Both are Saudi citizens. The bomber was identifed as Abdullah Hassan Tali Assiri and is 23. His brother, Ibrahim, was believed to be the one who recruited him to Al-Qaeda. His brother had been arrested in 2006 when he tried to travel with a group of young men to Iraq to carry out jihad. He was put in prison for nine months.
The day of the bombing Assiri checked into an apartment on Sari street in Jeddah at 07:00. He was with one other man. They stayed at the apartment for an hour, left, and returned again an hour later. They left later on and never returned.
Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the attack. The attack followed an announcement by the Saudi government claiming the arrest of 44 high-ranking AQAP members earlier this month. AQAP has made previous threats against government targets in Saudi Arabia, however this is the first attack which has been carried out on one.
The group has also threatened to attack oil facilities, international hotels and civilians throughout countries such as Kuwait, UAE, Qatar and Bahrain. Counterterrorism operations in Kuwait and Bahrain have led to the arrest of terrorist cells and in turn have stopped terrorist plots coming to their fruition. Possible targets in Kuwait included the US Arifjan military base and the internal security agency. Targets in Bahrain included US Navy ships and personnel in Mina Salman.
perpetrators: Saudi Arabia:Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP):Global Islamist

A bomb exploded in Kohat, Pakistan in the offices of a cable network TV channel. The bomb was located near the entrance to the station. One employee was injured and the entire office was destroyed. Shops and a nearby bank were also damaged.
While no group claimed the attack, the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has carried out attacks in the area. The group also banned the channel's telecast in Kohat some months previously. The TTP banned television and music in some areas which they control. They view the mediums as un-Islamic.

An unidentified man threw several petrol bombs at the Slovak Embassy in Budapest. The attack caused no damage.No group claimed responsibility.
Authorities suspected the attack was in response to the Solvak government's recent language laws and the government's recent refusal to allow the Hungarian president to attend a statue unveiling in Komarno.

summary:
Suspected members of Chechen Jamaat attacked a group of policemen in Vedeno, Chechnya, Russia. They killed one policeman and injured one other. The group did not claim responsibility for the incident.
The numbers of terrorist attacks on police personnel and facilities in the area has increased. Since May 2009 there has been a rise in terrorist activity in the neighbouring provinces of Dagestan and Ingushetia. In the past few weeks, there has also been an increase in terrorist activity in Chechnya. There have been six terrorist attacks in Chechnya in August 2009.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a group of policemen Mesker-Yurt, Chechnya, Russia. He killed four policemen and two civilians and injured one other. The bomber attacked the policemen at a petrol station. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
There have been four suicide bombings in the past month- three in Chechnya and one in Ingushetia. Suicide bombings indicate a radicalisation of the Islamist groups operating in the area. While there were incidents of suicide terrorism in the area in 2007 and 2008, the attacks were rare.
Currently, the attacks have been directed against police and security forces, however, it is likely that with the radicalisation of the organisations in the area, attacks on Russian civilians may take place in the future.

summary:
A bomb exploded in the centre square of San Vicente del Caguan in Arcenio Novia, Colombia. It killed three civilians and wounded 18 others. The bomb exploded near a police patrol, however, no policemen were injured.
Colombian authorities suspect that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is responsible. There has been a decrease in FARC activity. It has only carried out eight attacks since June 2009. It carried out seven attacks in April 2009 alone.

summary:
A 50kg bomb in a pickup truck exploded outside the Suan Kluay restaurant on Thammawithi Road in Narathiwat, Thailand. It injured 42 civilians and damaged five vehicles and six houses. The bombing targeted a group of Buddhist politicians having lunch in the restaurant. Among the injuredwas the district chief of Narathiwat.
A man parked the truck outside the restaurant and then left via a motorcycle. Five minutes later the bomb exploded. The bomb exploded downwards instead of upwards, indicating that the attackers intended tothreaten lives and injure rather than kill.
The vehicle belonged to officials at the Narathiwat Land Survey Office. It is believed the vehicle was stolen by Islamists a few days prior to the bombing.
Multiple terrorist organisations operate in Narathiwat, including the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C), the New Patani United Liberation Organisation and the Runda Kumpalan Kecil (RKK). Each group is capable of carrying out car bombings and target government officials. Thai authorities arrested two men believed to be connected to the RKK and to this incident.
This is one of the largest terrorist attacks in Thailand in 2009.
author: Unknown author

No group claimed responsibility for the attack.

specific_target: A Japanese construction company, a guest house used by foreigners, a UN compound and government intelligence offices
summary:
A remote-controlled truck bomb exploded in Kandahar City, Kandahar, Afghanistan. It killed 43 civilians and injured 65 others. The attack occurred near Shita - a Japanese construction company - a guesthouse used by foreigners, a UN compound and government intelligence offices. The Taliban has previously targeted construction companies, hotels, international aid groups and government offices in Afghanistan. A wedding hall and nearby civilian homes were also destroyed.
The bombing occurred after the Independent Election Commission announced figures from ten percent of the polling stations nationwide. The results place President Karzai and his rival, Abdullah Abdullah, at almost even.
While the Taliban deny responsibility of the attack, the claim should be taken with caution. The Taliban have targeted all of the above mentioned targets before. Additionally, the group considered Kandahar its spiritual home. Kandahar is also the home town of President Karzai. The Taliban also fired rockets at Kandahar on the day of the election.
This is not only the largest attack in Afghanistan in 2009 but it is also one of the largest terrorist incidents to take place during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.
targets: Civilians/General Public; Humanitarian; Tourism/Hospitality; Government/Political ; Construction/Real Estate

Suspected members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) attacked a railway station in Sundargarh, Orissa, India. They blew up the train station and kidnapped three employees. They also set fire to 15 vehicles including eight trucks and heavy transport vehicles. The train station is primarily used for iron ore transport.
The station manager was released on 27 August.
The CPI-M had called a strike in Orissa for 48-hours. Members of the group also attacked a community centre and a mobile phone tower in Bihar.

The Taliban is also suspected of carrying out a truck bomb attack in Kandahar City. It targeted a Japanese construction firm, international humanitarian offices, a guest house popular with foreigners and government intelligence offices. The attack was the deadliest bombing in Afghanistan in 2009.

It is unknown if the man was planning to carry out a terrorist attack at the train station or was on-route to another location.

There has been a rise in the number of terrorist attacks in Iraq in the past few months. A majority of the attacks take place in Baghdad and Mosul. specific_target: Bureau Chief for Afghanistan's Shamshad TV channel
summary:
Unidentified men shot dead the bureau chief for Afghanistan's Shamshad television channel in Jamrud, Pakistan. The journalist, Janullah Hashimzada, was travelling in a bus from Afghanistan. Militants stopped the bus and then went inside and shot Hashimzada. One other passenger was wounded.
Shamshad TV broadcasts to both Pakistan and Afghanistan. Hashimzada often appeared on the channel. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected. The group was given negative coverage by Shamshad TV and Hashimzada was a critic of the group. The TTP often operate in the Khyber agency.

Suspected members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) attacked a police checkpoint in Tak Bai, Narathiwat, Thailand. Approximately ten militants in two trucks threw bombs at the officers at the checkpoint. They then fired automatic weapons at the officers. Two police officer were killed and three others were injured.
After the attack, police removed two fake bombs left on the road. The suspected BRN-C members also left spikes along their retreat route so that vehicles could not follow them.
The BRN-C is one of the most widespread Islamist groups in southern Thailand. Their attacks mainly consist of small bombings and armed ambushed. They mostly operate in Narathiwat and Yala.

summary:
A large truck bomb exploded outside of the Iraqi Ministry of Finance in Baghdad's Waziriyah district. The explosion killed 35 civilians and wounded 228 others. There was significant material damage to the building and the surrounding area.
The explosion caused 50 metres of one side of the Mohammed al Qassim Traffic Bridge to collapse.
The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed responsibility for the incident as well as a senior Iraqi Ba'th official. In a communique, the ISI stated that it would attack more Iraqi government facilities and warned civilians not to go near them. Ba'th party member Wisam Ali Kazem confessed in a video that members of the Ba'th party were behind the attacks. He had been asked by Ba'th officials in Syria to carry out an attack in Baghdad a month ago. Both claims should be treated with a degree of caution.

summary:

There was considerable material damage to the surrounding intersection. The blast left a crater three meters deep and 10 meters wide. Forty-four cars were damaged. No group has claimed responsibility for the incident.
This attack followed a similar truck bombing at the Iraqi Finance Ministry in Waziriyah District.
The Islamic State of Iraq (ISI) claimed responsibility for the incident as well as a senior Iraqi Ba'th official. In a communique, the ISI stated that it would attack more Iraqi government facilities and warned civilians not to go near them. Ba'th party member Wisam Ali Kazem confessed in a video that members of the Ba'th party were behind the attacks. He had been asked by Ba'th officials in Syria to carry out an attack in Baghdad a month ago. Both claims should be treated with a degree of caution.
Levels of violence in Iraq have declined recently however attacks continue with relative frequency in Baghdad, Mosul and Kirkuk.

summary:

The attacks are possibly linked to a double truck bombing in Khaznah, northern Iraq. Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected of all four bombings. The group often targets Shi'a civilians and carries out multiple bombing attacks in one area.

summary:
Two truck bombs exploded nearly simultaneously in Khaznah, Iraq. They killed 30 civilians and injured 155. Approximately 30 homes were destroyed. The attack targeted Shi'a civilians who make up a majority of the town. The Shi'a civilians belong to the Shabka community, a sect with Kurdish origins. Each truck carried 1,500kg of explosives. The explosives used were RDX and DNT - military grade explosives.
While no group claimed responsibility for the incidents, Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected. The group frequently targets Shi'a civilians and is known for carrying out double bombings in civilian areas.
The attack may also be linked to a double bombing in Baghdad. Day Labourers were targeted in Amil and in Shurta Arbaa.

specific_target: Government and police buildings in Logar
summary:
Six members of the Taliban attacked government buildings in Pul-i-Alam, Logar, Afghanistan. They fired rockets from an unfinished tower block towards the police headquarters and the governor's building in the city centre. The governor was having lunch at the time of the attack and was not injured.
After the rocket attack, some of the Taliban attempted to enter the governor's office. However, the governor's security team repelled them. Two policeman were killed during the attack. The number of Taliban killed is unknown.
One of the Taliban was a suicide bomber. He detonated his explosives outside the local police station.
The incident is similar to the Taliban attack on government buildings in Kabul and in Ghazni City. The Taliban warned that it would increase attacks on government facilities in the run-up to the national election.

summary:
Policecarried outa controlled explosion on anETA bomb inBar Encoon the beachfrontof Palma de Mallorca.ETA had phoned in a warning regarding the bomb and claimed responsibility for the incident.
The bomb was one of four planted on the island by ETA. ETA isbelieved to have planted a fourth bomb, which police were searching the island for.
ETA'srecent campaignis aimed atdeterring tourists from visiting the popularisland destination. ETA hopes that this will disrupt the local economy and force the government to negotiate with it. Negotiations are currently suspended.
The previous week the group killed two civil guards when they detonated a bomb at their barracks on Mallorca. Police had launched a large-scale operation totry and find the perpetrators of the attack,which included shutting down the island's airports and ports.

summary:
A bomb exploded in Garmser, Helmand, Afghanistan. The attack killed 21 civilians and injured six others in a wedding party. The civilians were all travelling in the Darwhishan area of the Garmser district in a tractor. Travelling via tractor is common in Afghanistan's rural districts. While no group claimed responsibility, the Taliban is suspected.
The Garmsir district is considered a Taliban stronghold. The Taliban commonly carry out similar bombing attacks against military troops and government officials.
This is one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in the past month. The Taliban has increased the intensity of their attacks due to the upcoming Afghan elections. On 4 August Taliban members fired rockets at northern Kabul.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Members of the Communist Party of India-Maoists (CPI-M) set fire to the battery rooms of two cellular telephone towers belonging to the Reliance and Airtel companies in Dangabadi and Ramgiri villages in Koraput District, Orissa in India. There have been no reported casualties.
The Maoists have caused damage to more than a dozen such towers the the three southern districts of Koraput, Malkangiri and Rayagada in the past month.

summary:
A bomb exploded in the Pachir Agam district of Nangarhar, Afghanistan. It killed six civilians, including two tribal elders and four security guards. One guard was wounded. The elders were en route to check on the progress of work, which had stopped due to security reasons.
While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, the Taliban is suspected. The group often targets tribal leaders who oppose them.
Nangahar Province has traditionally been a Talibanstronghold on account of its impenetrable topography. The Tora Bora cave complexes that housed Osama Bin Laden in 2001 have recently been re-occupied by Taliban forces.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A sticky bomb exploded in the Mansour district of Baghdad, Iraq. The bomb targeted a generator in front of the Iraq mobile phone company AsiaCell. No casualties occurred. Attacks on critical infrastructure facilities were frequent during the height of the Iraqi insurgency. The number of attacks has since decreased.
AsiaCell was one of the first mobile phone companies launched in Iraq. It has approximately six million subscribers.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary:
A bomb exploded in the Harthiyah neighbourhood of Baghdad, Iraq. The bomb targeted an AsiaCell convoy. No casualties occurred. The bombing took place a few hours after a bomb targeted an AsiaCell generator in Baghdad's Mansour neighbourhood.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident. Multiple insurgent groups targeted Iraq's critical infrastructure during the height of the Iraqi insurgency.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary:
A group of four Nicaraguan politicians traveling to the Honduran border were attacked by alleged Sandinista and Zelaya supporters roughly 12 miles before Ocotal. The politicians were traveling to the border to protest the ousted Honduran president Zelaya's 'occupation' of northern Nicaragua.No other details were released.
After his overthrow, Zelaya escaped to northern Nicaragua where he is thought to be organising forces to challenge for power again. His presence has resulted in increased political polarisation of Nicaraguan politics.

specific_target: LAN Airlines ticket office in Buenos Aires
summary:
A bomb exploded in front of the LAN Airlines ticket office in Buenos Aires, Argentina in the early hours of the morning.
There were no casualties, however the exterior of the ticket office was damaged. CCTV showed a hooded man in a pick-up truck drop off a package in front of the office. Four minutes later it detonated. The owner of the pickup was subsequently arrested.

summary:
Suspected members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) attacked a police patrol in Bannang Sata, Yala, Thailand. One policeman was wounded. The police and the militants engaged in a 10 minute firefight.
The BRN-C is one of the most prolific militant Islamic groups in southern Thailand. They often carry out raids on police patrols in the area.

specific_target: Moderate Islamic leader in Guri Ceel
summary:
Unidentified men tried to assassinate the spokesman of a moderate Islamic group in front of his home in Guri Ceel, Somalia. A landmine was placed near the gate of his house. No injuries occurred. A Puntland government spokesman stated that three people had been arrested in connection with their involvement in the attack.
Moderate Islamic leaders are often targeted by more radical Islamist groups. They are viewed as enemies to their cause. A majority of the terrorist attacks in Somalia take place in Mogadishu and in the southern regions.

summary:
A suicide bomber killed six people and wounded 17 others in a bazaar in Shah Joy, Zabol, Afghanistan. The bomber targeted a vehicle of Afghan Intelligence officers. The attack killed two intelligence officers and four civilians. While no group claimed responsibility, the Taliban is suspected.
The Taliban has previously targeted government officials and employees with suicide bombers in urban areas. The Taliban has intensified attacks in the previous weeks due to the upcoming national elections. They have urged Afghans to boycott the election.

summary:
A bomb exploded in the Arghandi area of Kabul, Afghanistan. It targeted the convoy of the governor of Maydan Wardag province. Neither the governor nor any of those travelling with him were injured. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident.
The bomb was concealed under a small bridge alongside the road. It was detonated remotely.
The governor survived a previous assassination attempt in Chek district. No one was wounded in that attack either.

specific_target: US Embassy in Kabul and government buildings
summary:
The Taliban fired eight rockets at various targets in Kabul, Afghanistan. Two of the rockets landed in a residential area near the US Embassy. It is believed the embassy was the target. One rocket landed outside an apartment block, wounding three civilians. The other landed near a hospital. A third rocket landed near a senior Afghan General's home.
The main target point appeared to be the northern section of the city. The other five rockets landed on empty ground and caused no damages.
This type of coordinated rocket attack has not taken place in Kabul for over a year. The Taliban claimed responsibility and stated that similar attacks will follow. A Taliban spokesman said that the bombing is a warning for the 20 August elections.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A bomb exploded in Shalinskiy, Chechnya, Russia. It injured one policeman. The bomb targeted a police vehicle passing by. It is believed the bomb was triggered remotely via a radio device. The bomb was made out of an artillery shell. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, Chechen Jamaat is suspected.
Suspected members of Chechen Jamaat attacked another Russian police patrol in Itum-Kale, Chechnya on 2 August. They killed five police officers and wounded six others. The armed men threw grenades at the patrol and fired at them with machine guns.

Fallujah was previously considered a stronghold for Sunni Arab terrorist groups. While there continue to be terrorist incidents in the province, the overall trend is declining.

The areas most afflicted by terrorism in Iraq are Baghdad and Diyala provinces. In July and August 2009, there has been a severe increase in terrorism in Anbar province.

AQIM is the most active militant group in northern Algeria. It normally targets security forces and government officials. Shootings and ambushes are among the group's most favoured tactics. The group did not claim responsibility for the attack.

USPI convoys, vehicles, managers and employees have been attacked by the Taliban throughout Afghanistan. The Taliban has also used suicide bombers against the company's office in Kandahar. specific_target: Police station in San Jose de Secce
summary:
Suspected members of Shining Path attacked a police station in San Jose de Secce, Ayacucho, Peru. They killed three policemen and two civilians and injured seven others. The armed men threw grenades into the police station and then fired automatic weapons.
Shining Path was most active in the 1980s and 1990s. During this time, they presented a credible threat to the state. Presently the group's 200 members received the bulk of their support from neighbouring drug traders in the Ayacucho province.
Suspected members of Shining Path attacked a Peruvian military base in Sanabamba, Ayacucho, on 5 June. They killed one soldier and injured four others.

The GMIP primarily operate in Pattani. It is an Islamist group which carried out attacks on both security forces and civilians.

summary:
A car bomb exploded near the Civil Guard barracks in Palmanova, Majorca, Spain. The explosion killed two officers and injured seven others. ETA claimed responsibility for the incident.
This attack is outside ETA's normal area of operations. The group usually carries out attacks on the Spanish mainland.
While this was the first major attack on a Spanish tourist destination this year so far, ETA usually conducts a campaign in the summer. In 2008 ETA carried out four attacks at tourist resorts in northern Spain. Following the attacks, the authorities closed both the airports and ports, probably in a bid to prevent the terrorists from escaping.
ETA carried out a similar attack on a barracks in Burgos, Spain on 29 July. A car bomb injured 40 people and damaged the barracks.
2009 marks ETA's 50th year. In 1959 the group was founded to create an independent Basque homeland.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: ETA (Basque Fatherland and Liberty), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. It injured the deputy chief of police. The bomb was planted inside the injured policeman's car which was parked outside the Korvon market. It exploded when he opened the door.
This is the third bombing to take place in Dushanbe in one week. Two other bombs targeted the Hotel Tajikistan and Dushanbe International airport. No injuries were reported in either incident. No group claimed responsibility for any of the attacks.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected members of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) ambushed Yemeni soldiers in the Sirwah district of Marib, Yemen. Two soldiers were killed in the attack and seven wounded. The soldiers were travelling through the province towards the city of Marib. The AQAP members also seized ammunition and military equipment. Two AQAP members were killed and three others wounded.
The incident was part of what AQAP referred to as the 'Battle of Marib'. Yemeni forces had launched an operation against AQAP in the province with local sheiks, however the operation did not go smoothly. First a Yemeni supply truck was captured by AQAP forces, then the militarily accidentally shelled a tribal house rather than an AQAP safe house, inciting a violent reaction from the tribesmen. According to AQAP sources, in the 'Battle' its forces captured five military tanks, a number of dead and wounded, and at least seven Yemeni soldiers captured.
Many of the details remained unconfirmed, however the incident marks the difficulty and complexity that the fight against AQAP has become in Yemen.

Three bombs exploded in a building used by theReform and Development Movement in Baqubah, Diyala, Iraq. The explosion killed seven civilians and wounded ten. The building was severely damaged. Nearby homes, shops and cars were also damaged. The Reform and Development Movement is a Sunni-backed political group.
Terrorist attacks continue throughout Diyala province. No group claimed responsibility for this incident, however Al-Qaeda in Iraq is active throughout the region.

summary:
A bomb exploded in Bish Ara village, Aqcha, Jowzjan, Afghanistan killing four civilians and injuring two others.
The bomb was hidden by the side of the road and was set to be triggered by a passing vehicle. Although no group claimed responsibility, the police suspect the Taliban.
There has been a rise in Taliban activity due to the upcoming national election. The Taliban urged all Afghans to boycott the elections. They also stated that their members have been told to carry out attacks on election facilities.

summary:
A car bomb exploded near the Spanish National Guard barracks in Burgos, Spain. It injured 64 people and damaged the 14-story barracks. Approximately 90 houses in the vicinity were damaged as well. A majority of the injuries came from flying glass. Many of the injured were Civil Guard police officers and their families. Authorities believe over 200kg of explosives were used in the incident.
ETA claimed responsibility for the attack. Unlike previous ETA attacks, this bombing was not preceded by warning calls to the police or emergency services.
The last ETA bombing took place on 10 July. A home-made bomb exploded in the offices of the Partido Socialista Obrero Español - PSOE, (the ruling Spanish Socialist party) in the town of Durango, Spain. No casualties were reported. However, the building was severely damaged.
The last ETA bombing to cause a fatality took place on 19 June. A car bomb exploded in the Santa Isabel neighbourhood of Bilbao, killing a senior police inspector.
This is one of the largest ETA car bombings in months. The group was believed to be in decline due to the arrest of key leaders in Spain and southern France.
author: Unknown author

The group targets police personnel and government members throughout Ingushetia. Their most common tactic is small scale bombings. The group has become more active since May 2009.

Defence force volunteers provide security for school teachers in Yala. Teachers are often targeted by Islamist militants in the area. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) is suspected. The group often uses small bombs in their attacks. The BRN-C operates in the Yala area.

summary:
Members of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) ambushed and killed 20 Algerian soldiers in Tipaza, Algeria. Seven soldiers were wounded.
  
The terrorists attacked the convoy with both bombs and firearms. While no officials confirmed the number of terrorists killed, newspapers indicated that five terrorists were killed.
This incident follows another AQIM ambush on Algerian soldiers in Mansoura, where 24 paramilitary policemen were killed on 18 June.
AQIM claimed responsibility for the incident. AQIM has recently expanded its area of operations to include parts of Mali, Niger and Mauritania. The group primarily operates in northern Algeria and targets security forces and police.

specific_target: Shi'a muslim lawyer in Dera Ismail Khan
summary:
A remote-controlled bomb exploded in the parking lot of a court in Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan. It killed the two guards of a Shi'a Muslim lawyer and wounded four other civilians. No group claimed responsibility for the incident. Multiple terrorist groups operate in the area, including the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan.
In June 2009, members of the TTP killed Baitullah Mehsud's rival in Dera Islmail Khan. Qari Zainuddin Mehsud, a clansman of Baitullah, stated Baitullah's targeting of the Pakistani stat was against Islam. Zainuddin was another Taliban commander who had taken over for Abdullah Mehsud.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Armed men on a motorcycle threw a grenade at a checkpoint on Sairab road in Quetta, Pakistan. No group had claimed responsibility at the time of writing, but jihadists operate in the area.

summary:
Unidentified men attacked a vehicle carrying civilians in Mohmand, Pakistan. They killed two civilians and injured six others. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however one of the militants was killed.
Terrorist attacks are still common in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas and the North West Frontier Province. The most active group in the area is the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan.

specific_target: Campaign office of Dr. Abdollah in Urgun
summary:
A bomb exploded next to the campaign office of a presidential candidate in Urgun, Paktika, Afghanistan. The election campaign office of Dr. Abdollah was damaged, however no casualties occurred. The office was located in a market place in Urgun, and therefore nearby shops were damaged due to the explosion.
While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, the Taliban is suspected.
Dr. Abdollah's campaign rally was attacked by suspected members of the Taliban in the Dar-i-Nur district of Nangarhar, Afghanistan. Two civilians were injured. Approximately 500 people were at the rally.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A group of approximately 50 Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) militants assassinated Khalilur Rehman, a pro-government militia leader, at his home in Shangla district, Northwest Frontier Province, Pakistan. Rehman was the head of the Lashkar tribal militia, which provided support to groups fighting the Taliban.
Local militias have played an increasing role in fighting the Taliban.
author: Unknown author

specific_target: President Karzai's campaign office in Gozara
summary:
A bomb exploded at President Karzai's campaign office in Gozara, Herat, Afghanistan. No casualties occurred, however the office was damaged. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Taliban is suspected.
The Taliban issued a communique calling on their members to attack campaign offices and voting facilities to prevent Afghans from taking part in a US sponsored election. The Taliban urged Afghans to boycott the elections.
In the past month, the number of attacks targeting campaign offices and rallies have increased.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Unidentified men kidnapped a prayer leader in Mashogagar, southern Peshawar, Pakistan. The man was found dead in the same area on 2 August. Three kilograms of explosives were found with his body. It is believed that militants meant to target security forces with the explosives. Bomb disposal experts defused the bomb. No injuries occurred. No group claimed responsibility.
A similar tactic is used by Islamists in Thailand's southern province. Militants kill civilians and then hide explosives underneath or near their bodies. When security forces arrive, the explosives are triggered.

summary:
A bomb exploded in Zeray, Afghanistan killing two civilians travelling in a mini-bus towards Helmand province. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Taliban is suspected.
Recently, the Taliban has directed many of its attacks on election facilities or personnel. Campaign offices, managers and rallies have all been attacked. Afghans vote in the presidential elections on 20 August. The result of the vote is made official on 17 September.

summary:
Members of Boko Haram attacked security forces along the outskirts of Potiskum, Yobe, Nigeria. The forces were on patrol in the area when the attack occurred. The number of security force casualties is unknown, however 43 members of Boko Haram were killed.
Nigerian security forces have increased security in northern Nigeria. They have also carried out multiple counter-terrorist operations against Boko Haram. They shelled the home of the group's leader, Mohammed Yusuf, as well as a mosque. Yusuf's whereabouts are unknown.
Members of Boko Haram launched several attacks on police stations and policemen on 26 July in Yobe state. It was one of the first recent terrorist attacks carried out by Islamists in northern Nigeria.

summary:
Unidentified men set fire to the New Democracy (ND) party office in Kaminia, Athens, Greece. No casualties occurred, however the building was damaged. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
The attack was part of a campaign of seven arson attacks on political party offices in the Athens area. ND party offices in Koukaki, Drapetsona, Kaminia and Halandri were attacked as well as the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) offices in Votaniko and Goudi and the Popular Orthodoz Rally (LAOS) office in Aghioi Anargyroi.
 
The last major terrorist attack in Athens took place on 17 June. A member of Sect of Revolutionaries shot and killed a police officer in Patisia. The policeman was in his car outside the home of a witness under police protection. The witness was to testify in a trial against the People's Revolutionary Struggle (ELA). This was one of the first incidents where a policeman was deliberately targeted and killed.
source_urls: ESISC, Athens News Agency, AP, Kathimerini

summary:
A bomb in a cafe exploded in Kesra, Baghdad, Iraq killing two civilians and wounding 15 others. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected. AQI is active in Baghdad and has attacked similar targets.
While a large number of terrorist attacks in Iraq take place in Baghdad, there has been an increase in the number of terrorist attacks in Anbar province. The area became relatively stable following the US 'surge' strategy was enacted, however there has been a spate of suicide bombings in both June and July.

summary:
A bomb concealed in a motorcycle exploded in the New Baghdad district of Baghdad, Iraq. It killed eight civilians and wounded 13 others. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
A large number of the terrorist attacks which take place in Iraq occur in Baghdad. The number of attacks in Anbar province has increased in the past two weeks. There were three attacks in Anbar in the past seven days.

summary:
Suspected members of the Gerakan Mujahideen Islami Pattani (GMIP) killed a Buddhist couple in Khokpho, Pattani, Thailand. The two were on a motorcycle heading to their rubber plantation at the time of the attack.
The GMIP then hid a bomb underneath their bodies and detonated it when security forces arrived at the scene. The bomb injured two police officers, an army officer and two civilians.
This tactic has been used before in the area. Both Buddhist civilians and security forces are often targeted by Islamist terrorist groups in Thailand. A majority of the terrorist activity takes place in the three southern-most provinces.

summary:
Members of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) attacked the Girdi Rogha Fort in North Waziristan, Pakistan. They kidnapped ten members of the paramilitary Frontier Corps (FC) and injured three others. . The TTP used automatic weapons as well as RPGs. The attack lasted for a few hours.
FC and other security forces are present in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA), however there is a high casualty rate among troops. The forces are common targets for terrorist organisations operating n the area. The TTP remains one of the most active terrorist groups in Pakistan. FATA continues to be an area prone to terrorist attacks. There have been suicide attacks in all seven agencies.

specific_target: Employees of the Humayun private security firm
summary:
Two bombs exploded in the Yakhchal area of the Greshk district, Helmand province, Afghanistan. They killed eight and wounded four others. The casualties were all employees of the Humayun private security firm. They were travelling through the area in two vehicles when the attack occurred.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident. Greshk has been at the centre of some of the fiercest fighting by Afghan and coalition forces in Helmand Province.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded near the Hotel Tajikistan in Duchanbe, Tajikistan. No casualties occurred however a parked car was damaged. The hotel is located in the vicinity of the presidential palace. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Hizb ut-Tahrir (HT) is suspected. Tajik authorities have arrested HT members in the country before. It is believed that HT along with the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan operate in the region.
This is the second bombing in Dushanbe in two days. The first bomb exploded near the airport. It caused no casualties.
The bombing comes two days before a meeting between the leaders of Afghanistan, Pakistan and Russia in Duchanbe.
Counter-terrorism operations have increased along the Tajik border with Afghanistan. Security forces believe that some militants may be crossing into the country from Afghanistan. In the month of July there has been an increase in the number of gun battles between security forces and militants along this border.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A 'sticky bomb' exploded in Mosul, Iraq killing a tribal leader and wounding three civilians. The bomb was planted underneath the car of the tribal leader.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident. Tribal leaders are normally attacked for their cooperation with the Iraqi government or foreign forces.
After the departure of US troops from major cities, terrorist attacks continue throughout Diyala province and Baghdad.Anbar province has also seen a recent increase in terrorist activity. Al-Qaeda is Iraq is suspected to be involved in the attack because a number of the group's cells remain active in and around Mosul.

Terrorist attacks in Baghdad targeting civilians remain at a high number. A majority of the attacks which take place in Iraq occur in Baghdad.

Iranian security forces found and defused a bomb planted near apharmacy in Mashhad, Iran. The bomb targeted a ceremony honouring veterans in the Iran-Iraq war. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
In May and June of 2009 there was an increase in terrorist activity in Iran. A total of eight attacks occurred. They mostly took place in Zahedan. The targets varied and included banks, religious sites and campaign offices.

summary:
A bomb concealed in a bag exploded in front of the Samaniego police station in Colombia. It killed one civilian and injured six policemen. The civilian was handed a bag by suspected members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). They detonated the bomb as the civilian walked past the police station. It is believed the civilian was a beggar.
The number of FARC attacks have decreased in the past few months. There has only been one other FARC attack in July and two others in June.

Suspected members of Al-Shabaab fired mortars at the Somali parliament in Mogadishu. Somali MPs were at the parliament at the time of the attack. No casualties occurred. The president had left the building prior to the shelling.
The Somali parliament has been attacked before by Al-Shabaab. Al-Shabaab continues to be the most active groupin Mogadishu. It has also carried out attacks along the Kenyan border.

Suspected members of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) bombed the Al-Khurram CD shop and Internet Cafe in Manshera, Pakistan. The bomb was left outside the shop and was hooked up to a timer. The TTP oppose Western music and have targeted CD shops in the past. However, not many of the previous incidents targeting CD shops resulted incasualties. The TTP remains very active the the North West Frontier Provinces.

summary:
Suspected members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) triggered a landmine in Dantewada, Chhattisgarh, India. A total of two Central Reserve Police Force members were killed and four others injured. The policemen had finished a daily patrol at a market in Geedam village and were passing through the area in a van.
The CPI-M did not claim responsibility for the incident, but has carried out similar attacks in the area before. The group frequently targets police officers in the region.

Suspected members of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) shot and wounded three policemen on patrol in Peshawar, Pakistan. The policemen were in a mobile police van at the time of the incident. No other injuries occurred.
The TTP continue to target police and police facilities in Peshawar. The group also targets NATO supply convoys and depots in the outskirts of the city. specific_target: Security forces in Maiguguri and police station
summary:
Suspected members of Boko Haram attacked security forces, police stations and a prison in Maiguguri, Nigeria. The number of casualties is unknown, however news agencies estimate that over 100 people were killed. A majority of the casualties are members of Boko Haram. The attack occcurred at the same time as another Boko Haram attack in Potiskum, Nigeria.
The members separated themselves into groups and simultaneously attacked multiple police stations, security forces and a prison in Maiguguri. The attack on the state police headquarters resulted in a shoot out which lasted over three hours. The other police station in the city was set on fire. A total of eight police officers were killed.
The attack on the prison killed two soldiers and three prison officers. Several prisoners were freed.
The group previously attacked another police station in Bauchi, Nigeria on 26 July. The attack prompted the retaliation of security forces on the Boko Haram base on the outskirts of Bauchi. Nigerian police sources estimate that over 40 were killed and over 150 arrested in the operation.
The Boko Haram group is an Islamist group inspired by the Taliban in Afghanistan. The group wants Sharia law for all of Nigeria and opposes anything Western.
These attacks illustrate a rise in Islamist activity in northern Nigeria. This attack is one of the first against police by Islamists in the country, and one of the few not associated with Niger Delta militant movements. summary:
Asuicide bomber detonated his explosives at a concert hall in the Chechen capital, Grozny, killing six police officers. The dead included a Lieutenant Colonel, five other officers and the suicide bomber. The attack occurred at around 17:00.
The attack was quickly condemned as being the work of Chechen rebels in their 'death throes' by the President, Ramzan Kadyrov. He vowed that the government would not stop until they had all been 'eliminated'.
There has been a recent increase in terrorists targeting the Chechen republic, with Dagestani Jamaat Shariathe most prolific group.

summary:
A bomb exploded near the luggage storage facility of Duchanbe airport on Titov Street in Tajikistan. No casualties occurred, however nearby homes were damaged.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Hizb ut-Tahrir (HT) is suspected. Group members have been arrested in Tajikistan and in turn the group is suspected to have recruited there as well. The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan also is suspected of recruiting in the area.
The bombings come two days before a meeting between the leaders of Afghanistan, Pakistan and Russia in Duchanbe.
Counter-terrorism operations have increased along the Tajik border with Afghanistan. Security forces believe that some militants may be crossing into the country from Afghanistan. In the month of July there has been an increase in the number of gun battles between security forces and militants along this border.

specific_target: Funeral for Iraqi policeman in Khaldiya
summary:
A suicide bomber killed three civilians and wounded nine others at a funeral in Khalidya, Anbar, Iraq. The bomber tried to avoid the guards, who were searching people before they entered the funeral tent. When he could not enter the tent, the bomber detonated near the guards.
The funeral was for an Iraqi policeman killed by a bomb in a roadside market on 25 July. Iraqi police said the suicide bomber was 17 or 18 years old.
There has been an increase in terrorist attacks in Anbar province in the past month, some of whichhave been suicide attacks. While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected. The group has carried out suicide attacks before and targets civilians.

summary:

This is the second attack on a mayor in the Philippines on 26 July. The former mayor of Candelaria was shot and killed outside a church in Candelaria.
The two main terrorist groups operating in the southern Philippines are the Moro Islamic Liberation Front and the New People's Army.

summary:

This is the second attack on a mayor in the Philippines on 26 July. The Mayor of Malangas in Zamboanga was shot and killed outside a shopping mall in Pagadian.
The two most active terrorist groups in the southern Philippines are the Moro Islamic Liberation Front and the New People's Army.

A mine exploded in Nahr-e-Saraj, Afghanistan killing three workers of a private company and wounding two others. The mine was placed in the car of the workers. The name of the company was not released.
No group claimed responsibility, however the Taliban is suspected. The group often targets foreigners and those that cooperate with the government.

Members of the Balochistan Liberation United Front (BLUF) attacked a group of rice traders from Punjab province in Quetta, Pakistan. The militants, who were on motorbikes, shot and killed one and injured three others. The traders had come to Quetta sell their goods at a market.
The BULF members typicallyconduct theseattacks to discourage other ethnicities from travelling and selling goods in the province. The group alsoclaimed responsibility for the kidnapping of American UN worker John Solecki.

Multiple terrorist groups operate in Balochistan including the Balochistan Liberation Army and the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan. Both groups have a history of attacking gas pipelines in Dera Bugti.

specific_target: Dutsen Tanshi Police station in Bauchi
summary:
A group called Boko Haram attacked the Dutsen Tanshi Police station in Bauchi, Nigeria. The men were allegedly armed with explosives and firearms. A total of 10 were killed - six militants, three civilians and one soldier.
The group said it attacked the police station because authorities had been arresting its leaders.
Police retaliated against the group by attacking its base along the outskirts of the city, resulting in 39 deaths and 150 arrests.
Boko Haram ('Western education is sin') is an Islamist group that wants Sharia law in Nigeria. They oppose Western style education and government. The group was founded in Nigeria in 2004 and is inspired by the Taliban in Afghanistan. It has been recruiting young men in the area for months.
Police in Bauchi stated that they arrested members of the group because they were investigating reports that Boko Haram was arming itself.
Sporadic conflicts between the Muslim and Christian communities in the area do occur, however this is one of the first attacks by Islamists in Nigeria. Since the group has a number of members, there may be an increase in terrorist attacks in northern Nigeria in the next weeks.
source_urls: BBC, Reuters, Bloomberg, Times of Nigeria
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Boko Haram, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Unidentified terrorists detonated a car bomb at the headquarters of Vice-President Tareq Hashemi's Islamic party, a Sunniparty,in Fallujah, Iraq. The attack killed four people and wounded23. The offices were almost completely destroyed.
Another bomb reportedlydetonated as the wounded were being taken to hospital, but no further injuries were reported.
The city of Fallujah was until recently the bastion of the terrorist group, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) and other Islamist terrorist groups. The US 'surge' strategycombined withdeals with tribal leaders improved the security situation greatly. However there was a marked increase in attacks in Spring during the run up to the US military's partial withdrawal from Iraq's major cities.

The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP)is suspected responsible for the attack. The TTP have previously carried out suicide bombings in the area. They also often target police.

summary:
Taliban members, including several suicide bombers, attacked government buildings in Khost. The terrorists, armed with automatic weapons, battled security forces until six of the group detonated their explosives beltsand one was shot dead. Theterrorists were reportedly allwearing suicide belts, and were armed with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. Reportedly 14 civilians and three police officers were wounded.
There were conflicting reports on the number of people involved in the attacks. The Taliban stated that four attackers entered the city, whereasa government spokesman statedthat eight terrorists were involved, and only one of them managed to get away.
The increased violence is blamed on the upcoming presidential elections, due on 20 August.

summary:
A suicide car bomb exploded in Hilla, Babil, Iraq killing 26 civilians and wounding 70 others in a market place. This is one of the largest car bombings in Iraq in weeks. This is also one of the first suicide attacks.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident. However, since the target of the attack was Shi'a civilians and the method of the attack was a suicide car bombing, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected. The group frequently targets Shi'a civilians and has carried out car bombings of market places in the the past.
The number of suicide bombings in Iraq has decreased. This could be due to a lack of recruitment for terrorist groups. The number of terrorist attacks in Iraq is high. The areas with the most attacks are Baghdad and Diyala province.

He is the sixth academic to be a victim of targeted killings in Balochistan in the last couple of months. The motive is unclear but is thought to be a sectarian motivated attack.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident. Members of ETA are known to operate in this region of France. Plans to build a high speed train link through the Basque region caused an increase in ETA activity. Several high level members of ETA have been arrested by French and Spanish authorities in this region of southern France.

There has not been a car bombing on Corsica in over three years. A majority of the attacks on the island involve arson or small scale bombings of financial targets such as ATMs and second homes under construction. This may indicate an escalation in terrorism over the summer months.
The group on the island which carries out a majority of the attacks is the Front di Liberazione Naziunale di a Corsica (FLNC). The group claimed responsibility for the attack on 9 August. Two men who had their faces covered, read a statement in front of the group's flag. The group is opposed to foreigners settling on the island and wants an independent Corsica.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Ingush Jamaat Sharia is suspected. A majority of the group's attacks target police and police facilities. Since May 2009 the group has been suspected of carrying out over 15 bombings in the region.

Shi'a pilgrims, including Iranians, have often been the target of attacks during religious ceremonies in Iraq.

summary:

Although no group has claimed responsibility for the killing, it seems the latest incident in the series of attacks against Muslim clerics who have come out against the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan(TTP). TTP leader Baitullah Mehsud had issued a warning to such clerics a few weeks ago and subsequently these killings began.
A majority of the terrorist incidents in Pakistan occur in the North West Frontier Province, the Federally Administered Tribal Areas and Balochistan. However, parts of Punjab and Sindh are becoming more afflicted with terrorism. The major cities such as Islamabad and Lahore are experiencing increased and more lethal attacks. The increase of terrorism in the cities indicates a rise in jihadi activity and capability.

The bombs exploded almost simultaneously. The first bomb was concealed in a food stall and the other was hidden in a pile of rubbish.

specific_target: Wedding party of relative of former Fatah member
summary:
A bomb exploded at a wedding party in Khan Younis, Gaza. The wedding party was for the nephew of former Fatah leader Muhammad Dahlan. Police sources stated that 52 civilians were wounded in the attack. The explosion took place under a stage that had been set up for the bridal party.
Dahlan was the Fatah member in charge of Palestinian National Authority security forces in Gaza. He was not at the ceremony at the time of the attack. The population of the Khan Younis area is known for its support of Dahlan.
While no group claimed responsibility for the incident, Hamas is suspected. The two groups are still rivals and their members occasionally clash in the region. Dahlan and his associates have been previously targeted by Hamas. In 2007, members of Hamas attempted to kill Dahlan's bodyguard. Also in 2007 one of Dahlan's relatives was kidnapped by Hamas.
Hamas spokesmen denied involvement in the attack on the wedding party. One added that three people have been arrested in association with the incident.

In a complex attack,members of theTalibanconducted an armed attack againstthe governor's compound, the police headquarters and the National Directorate of Security offices in Gardez, Afghanistan. According tomilitary sources, five suicide bombersalso tookpart inthe attack.
The Taliban fired a rocket at the the National Directorate of Security and killed three offices.
At the same time,a suicide bomber triggered his explosives in front of the Gardez police headquarters, killing two police. A second suicide bomber was shot and killed before he could detonate his explosive vest in the same location.
Three suicide bombers were alsoshot and killed while trying to detonate their explosivevestsat the governor's compound. Two of them were wearing burqas.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack. Coordinated attacks targeting multiple locations in the same area is a common tactic for the Taliban; the group carried out similar attacks in Kabul.
source_urls: Al Jazeera, CNN, CBS, Reuters, AP

summary:
Two suspectedTaliban suicide bombers, who were travelling by motorcycle, were shot by police as they attempted to obtain access to the airport in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. The airport is used by Afghan and foreign troops. Police shot both of the suicide bombers before they had the opportunity totrigger their explosives. However, a police officer was killed by Taliban gunfire.
The two men were on a motorcycle and carried AK-47s and a rocket propelled grenade.
This attack is believed to be linked to the Taliban assault on government and police buildings in Gardez. Taliban suicide bombers killed five people in Gardez.

This was the first grenade attack in Kashmir in the past few months. Shopian continued to remain at a heightened state of alert.

summary:
Unidentified men blew up an 18-inch piece of the gas pipeline running from Pirkoh Gas field towards the purification plant near Dera Bugti, Balochistan.
According to the police, the men had strapped the explosives to the pipeline. The explosion caused a suspension in gas supply to the plant and any further production. The blast also damaged a three-foot long section of the pipeline and caused six feet long ruptures in another part of the pipeline.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Balochistan is suspected as they have been active in the region in the last few months. Gas pipelines are commonly targeted by separatist groups in Balochistan.

Attacks in the Balochistan region are becoming increasingly common. The Tehrik-e-Taliban Balochistan is suspected as they have been very active in the last few months.

specific_target: Afghan Intelligence Directorate and Military Facility
summary:
Taliban suicide bombers disguised as women stormed government buildings and a military instalationin the eastern Afghan cities of Jalalabad and Gardez. SixTaliban dressed in wigs and burqas and armed with assault rifles, RPG'sand suicide vestsstormedthe regional Intelligence Directorateinthe centreof Gardez in Paktia Province. Three were shot dead beforeentering the building, onedetonated his device while being pursued by police, killing two policemen, and two escaped. In addition four children,one woman and one policemanwere wounded.
In Jalalabad, Nanagahar Province, two Taliban were shot dead during a shootout withlocal police. Armed with assault rifles and suicide vests they were attempting to fight their way into the Jalalabad City Airport. One policeman was reported to have been killed.
Nangahar and Paktia Provinces continue to be plagued by violence ahead of the presidential elections due on August 20th. Nangahar in particular has seen increased Taliban activity in the last seven months since their strategic decision to begin targeting coalition supply convoys passing through the Kyber Pass and on to the Afghan capital Kabul.

The plot has been blamed on the members of the previous administration of Madagascar headed by Marc Ravalomanana.
Another bombing earlier in June was also attributed to Ravalomanana's aides and associates.
It is unclear at this stage whether this is merely political rivalry or a separatist movement. Meanwhile peace talks between the two rival factions have collapsed following these events.

AQIM carried out a suicide car bombing on a naval barracks in the same area in 2007. That incident killed 15 coastguards and one civilian.
AQIM recently expanded its area of operation to southern Algeria, Mali, Niger and Mauritania.

The head of the company is also the head of the Khost provincial council, which may have been a factor in its targeting.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Taliban is suspected. Attacks targeting construction workers and supplies continue to be claimed by the Taliban.

summary:

At least 24 people were killed in the attack, most of them civilians.Five rebels were reportedly killed and four of them wounded, while sixteen civilians were killed, including the wife and two children of soldiers. Three soldiers were killed and four were wounded.
The rebel force attacked late on Monday and were still fighting government forces in the early morning. The base is located in a remote part of the country.
The attacks are part of a campaign of vengeance for joint Rwandan and Congolese attacks against local gunmen in Congo's eastern provinces.

specific_target: Suspected to be local Sahwa figures
summary:
A roadside bomb inAl-Karma killed two people and wounded two others. The attack was the second of two attacks in Al-Karma in which a total of five people were killed, including the son of a senior Sunni Arab militiaman. Eight people were injured.
The attacks followed a bombing a day at the Fallujah home of a police lieutenant colonel and ex-Sahwa (also known as Awakening) leader, in which his two sons were killed and six people were wounded.

summary:
A Sunni triballeader, Naeem Saleh al-Halbusi, was wounded in a targeted roadside bomb attack in Al-Karma, a town 15 km (10 miles) east of Fallujah. Three other people,including Al-Halbusi's son,were killed and five others wounded in the explosion.
Al-Halbusi is a localleader of the Awakening Council, an alliance of Sunni tribes and former resistance groups that have turned against Al-Qaeda.
The attack was one of two that occurred on the same day in Al-Karma and alsocame as hundreds of thousands of people poured into Baghdad to visit the shrine of Imam Moussa al-Kadhim, for one of the most important festival dates in the Shia religious calendar.
Such events have been a key target for Al-Qaeda and other sectarian terrorist groups, and this particular festival marked the first major security challenge for Iraqi security force since the US military withdrew from the country's towns and cities at the end of June.
In 2005, at the same festival, rumours of a suicide bomber went through the crowd, causing a stampede that killed around 1,000 people.

Kidnappings are not uncommon in the region and most of the people abducted are released unharmed in exchange for a ransom.
An Al-Shabaab deputy leader claimed responsibility for the incident in an interview with the Kenya Times.

summary:
A special task force deputy chief and his aide were killed and five other people wounded in a car bomb attack in Yaha in Yala province, southern Thailand.
Major Pansak Thongsuk, the deputy chief of the Yala 14th special task force, and his aide were killed, and four other soldiers and a bystander were wounded, when a 15kg improvised explosive device hidden in a pick-up exploded as their vehicle  drove past.
Police said Maj Pansak was taking his team to Baju village in Padae sub-district after the task force had been alerted that a bomb had been planted in the village. The bomb was detonated as the team's vehicle was en route.
Police said the bomb was made from a gas cylinder and triggered by a radio transceiver. An intelligence source was cited in local press reports that it was the first time militants had used a transceiver to detonate a bomb in Yaha district.

specific_target: Marriott Hotel and Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Jakarta
summary:
Two suicide bombers from a Jemaah Islamiya splinter cell group calledTanzim Qaaedat al-jihad  attacked the Ritz-Carlton and Marriott hotels in Jakarta, Indonesia. Indonesian authorities stated that seven civilians were killed along with the two bombers. Over 50 were wounded.
The first bomber detonated his explosives in the Sailendra restaurant at the Marriott hotel during breakfast. The restaurant is located near the lobby of the hotel. CCTV footage showed him carrying a backpack on his chest and rolling luggage towards the restaurant.
When he was stopped by security, he told them he was delivering a case to his boss. Seven people, including the bomber were killed.
The second bomber detonated shortly after in the Airlangga restaurant in the Ritz-Carlton hotel next door. He went into the restaurant and was seated. When he was asked his room number, he said 2701, even though the Ritz only has 26 floors. He then said he was not staying at the hotel and offered to pay cash. The bomb detonated as the waiter went to get his coffee. The bomber and one other were killed.
The bombs contained nails, bolts and ball bearings. The contents remain similar to previous attacks by JI.
A total of seven civilians and two terrorists were killed in the attack and approximately 50 others wounded. The wounded are nationals from Australia, Canada, Hong Kong India, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, South Korea and the United States.
Police stated that a third bomb was found and defused on the 18th floor of the Marriott hotel. The bomb was set to explode in room 1808 before the attacks in the lobby of the hotel. Authorities believe that this bomb was meant to send people in the hotel down to the lobby where the suicide attack occurred. Police suspect that the two suicide bombers were guests at the hotel and used the room to construct the explosives.
The Marriott hotel was previously attacked in 2003. A car bomb was detonated in the front of the hotel during the afternoon. A total of 12 people died and 150 were injured.
The attack was claimed by Tanzim Qaaedat al-jihad, a suspected splinter group of Jemaah Islamiya.
The Jemaah Islamiya is an Al-Qaeda affiliated Islamist group which had declined in activity due to increased counterterrorism measures in the past year. The group had attacked the Marriott in 2003 and was responsible for the Bali nightclub bombings in 2002 which killed 202 people.
One of the bombers is believed to be Nur Hasbi. He is a graduate of the Al-Mukmin Islamic boarding school - many alumni of the school have joined JI.
The Marriott and the Ritz-Carlton are next door to each other in Jakarta's business district. The hotels are popular with Western tourists.

summary:
The Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) bombed the Atlas Cove Jetty in Lagos, Nigeria. In an emailed statement to international media, MEND claimed the attack. Oil pipelines owned by the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation were damaged and the facility was temporarily shut down. The Atlas Cove Jetty is a loading place for oil tankers.
MEND attacked the facility from boats and shot indiscriminately. They killed three guards and damaged some of the facility. They then planted dynamite across different sections of the oil installation and detonated them.
This is is one of the first attacks carried out by MEND on the oil industry outside of the Niger Delta region. The group issued a statement warning oil companies that it would extend its activity to other areas of the country.
By carrying out this attack, MEND proved that it has the operational capacity to stage a large scale attack outside its normal area of operations.

specific_target: Police officer in Tal Afar and private citizens
summary:
Two suicide bombings occurred within minutes of each other in a crowded part of Tal Afar, killing 35 civilians and injuring 61 others. The first bomb targeted the home of a local anti-terrorism investigator and was carried by an individual in a police uniform. When the investigator answered the front door, the bomber detonated his explosives killing the police officer and his family.
The second attack occurred minutes later when people gathered to rescue the victims of the first blast. A second bomber rushed into the crowd of people who had gathered and detonated his explosive belt causing a significant number of casualties. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, however, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is known to be active in nearby Mosul.

A nearby marketplace filled with civilians, including a large number of school children, bore the brunt of the explosion, causing significant casualties as well as material damage.
The attack remains unclaimed, however the Taliban is suspected.

specific_target: EnCana gas pipeline in Dawson Creek
summary:
A bomb exploded in Dawson Creek, British Columbia, Canada. It targeted an EnCana gas pipeline. This is the second attack on an EnCana pipeline in four days. There were no casualties, however the explosion damaged the pipeline and caused a gas leak.
The company received anonymous warnings to stop producing gas in the area in October 2008. After the letter, there were multiple bombings along various stretches of the pipeline in the Dawson Creek area. None of these attacks caused any casualties, however they did damage the pipeline.
No group claimed responsibility for this bombing, but environmentalist groups are suspected.

Some reports indicate that there were approximately 100 militants involved in the attack, about 30 of whom were killed after troops called in air strikes.
Many of the US installations and personnel were targeted particularly as it was the fourth of July.

None of the dead or injured persons had been identified and no group claimed responsibility for the attack. The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan is suspected. The incident is considered retaliation for the military offensive in the tribal regions and other parts of the NWFP.

summary:
Two bomb attacks and a mortar barrage in Baghdad killed an Iraqi police officer and injured seven people. In a separate incident a roadside bomb in al-Hurriyah Square in Karrada district wounded two more policemen. Meanwhile, three mortar rounds landed on residential buildings on Abu Nauwas Street, wounding two civilians.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected for the attacks that come a day after one of the most deadly attacks in Sadr City, eastern Baghdad. The attacks are likely linked to the impending US withdrawal from Iraqi cities and towns in an effort to re-ignite sectarian fighting and instability.

summary:

One Afghan soldier was killed and another injured in the incident. The Taliban spokesman on the other hand claim to have killed 19 ISAF and Afghan soldiers. These numbers remain unconfirmed.
Afghan forces have been carrying out an operation codenamed Tofan (Storm) in Bala Morghab District since last month, which aims to clear the area from Taliban presence before the elections in August.

MEND has recently attacked a series of foreign oil installations in Rivers and Delta States as part of the 'Hurricane Piper Alpha' offensive. Oil output in the region has fallen due to the increase in attacks against facilities.
