summary:
A roadside bomb hit a vehicle traveling in the Ashozo area of Arghandab District, Zabol Province in Afghanistan. The explosion killed eight civilians and wounded another 13. The civilians were on their way to funeral prayers for militant commander Mullah Hekmatollah when the IED hit the vehicle. According to police sources, the dead include the dead militant's parents.
The Taliban are suspected to be responsible for the IED as it has claimed its practice of planting landmines on some highways in the district to prevent foreign soldiers conducting search operations in the area. However, the incident also points out that the Taliban's tactics frequently harm Afghan civilians as much as its intended security forces targets.
The southern provinces of Afghanistan continue to be the most unstable and largest problem area for security forces.

The CPI-M killed five Central Reserve Police Force personnel and injured 10 others. Seven CRPF personnel later died from wounds incurred during the explosion. During the exchange of fire seven insurgents were also killed. The police were travelling in a truck through the district when the incident occurred. They were returning from a patrol.
The CPI-M continues to target police personnel throughout eastern India. The group has now started to carry out more ambush attacks. Despite an increased police and military presence, the CPI-M continue to be active and stage multiple attacks per week.

This marks a change from ETA's normal tactics. ETA's recent attacks have not resulted in any casualties. The last fatal ETA attack took place in December 2008 when two armed men shot and killed a Spanish businessman in Azpeitia.
Despite speculation among security sources about the group's decline, ETA carried out three property damaging attacks in May of 2009. They targeted the base of a television relay station in Cantabria on 13 May, a mobile telephone tower in Vitoria on 12 May, and bombed another television relay station in Castro Urdiales, Cantabria on 6 May.

This is the second incident on 18 June which targeted the construction sector in Afghanistan. In Kandahar, a bomb strapped to a parked bicycle exploded near another construction office, killing one employee and one child, and wounding four other employees.

The witness was to testify in a trial against the People's Revolutionary Struggle (ELA). The ELA was a far-left terrorist organisation that dissolved in 1995.
The group claimed responsibility for the incident via a CD sent to the daily Ta Nea newspaper in Greece.
Far-left terrorism has been on the rise in Greece. There have been over 30 attacks carried out in Greece since January 2009. summary:
Suspected members of Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) killed 24 Algerian paramilitary police and injured 14 civilians in an ambush on their convoy.
The attacktook place on a stretch of highway between the settlements of El Meher and El Mansourah, 180 km (110 miles) east of the capital. The convoy was returning to barracks after escorting Chinese construction workers to a motorway project.
AQIM first detonated two bombs and then opened fire on the convoy. Approximately 30 armed men were hiding in a truck that had been following the convoy. After the attack, the suspected AQIM members took arms, weapons and six police off-road vehicles.
Security sources say that the route taken by the convoy is used daily by paramilitary police to escort foreign workers to and from Hamam Elbibane. The convoy usually travels at the same time each day.
The attack is considered tobe the deadliest single attack in months.

summary:

The militants claimed via email to the media that the attack was part of MEND's 'Hurricane Piper Alpha', its campaign to cripple the entire oil and gas export market of Nigeria.
MEND further warned the media on 16 June that it would extend its attacks to other states, and that Shell should take cue from Chevron and vacate the Niger Delta to avoid collateral damage to their investment and death to staff.
The Nigerian government's Joint Military Task Force has experienced increased hostilities with MEND since May, when MEND began stepping up its attacks on Chevron facilities. MEND has sought its agenda with tactics that mix kidnappings for ransom, and attacks on oil infrastructure and security forces.

An improvised explosive device (IED) planted on a scooter parked near the canteen inside the complex exploded causing damage to the canteen and injuring two people. The KCP claimed the bomb was a warning against illegal liquor business.
The main objective of the KCP is to 'restore' the independence of the Manipur kingdom and to bring about an egalitarian society, as well as revive the indigenous culture. summary:
Suspected members of Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) fired an anti-tank rocket at a convoy carrying the local leader of an anti-Al-Qaeda militia in Tarmiya, Iraq. The rocket killed two of the leader's body guards and wounded three others in the convoy. The leader of the militia was unharmed.
The area is prone to AQI attacks. The group has targeted Sunni militias against AQI before. AQI remains active in Baghdad and Diyala province despite security measures.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Suspected members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) ambushed the staff of a town councilor in South Upi, Maguindanao, Philippines. One civilian was killed and three others were wounded. The civilians were all travelling in a vehicle through South Upi when the incident occurred.
MILF is very active in Maguindanao. Security sources in the Philippines believe that MILF is in decline due to the number of counter terrorist operations conducted in the area. However, the group's activity in the Philippines remains constant. Since January 2009, MILF has averaged one attack per week.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Taliban militants attacked the Kharkai check-post in Mardan, Pakistan late in the evening. The attack resulted in the death of two and injured three police personnel. The Northwest Frontier Province is one of the most restive of Pakistan's provinces as its proximity to Afghanistan's tribal areas allows for easy infiltration into either country of militants. Police and security checkpoints in these areas are frequent targets of the Taliban.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A landmine explosion killed one civilian in the Lamahi region of the Dang district of Nepal. This is located close to the base camp of the Nepal Defence Army near Arjunkhola.
The Nepal Defence Army was very active during and before the elections, but their activity levels have since decreased. Their main aim is to reinstate the Hindu monarchy in Nepal. Most incidents are mainly aimed at government installations or disruption of infrastructure and day-to-day functioning of private citizens.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A police sub-inspector was shot down in a gun battle between the police and members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) in a forest near Tampargarh in the Sambalpur district of Orissa.
The police are currently stepping up their activities to curb the violence perpetrated by CPI-M.

The CPI-M members used dynamite to destroy the buildings. There were no casualties reported.

summary:
An explosion on the campus of Nangarhar University wounded two students. The bomb had been planted between the buildings housing the faculties of literature and theology. No group has taken responsibility for the attack, however the Taliban is suspected.
There were no casualties, however, damage to some of the buildings nearby occurred.

specific_target: Civilians that houses police and army personnel
summary:
Members of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) set fire to four houses in Bahrain, Pakistan because the families housed police and army personnel. The TTP in the area told civilians not to support the government during the military operation it is carrying out. No casualties occurred.
The TTP is very active throughout the North West Frontier Province (NWFP). It carries out these type of intimidation tactics to enforce its control of the civilian population in the area.

summary:
Members of the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) attacked the Abiteye flow station near the Escravos oil terminal near Warri, Nigeria. MEND detonated explosives at four oil wells at the flow station. The flow station is operated by Chevron and supplies oil to the Escravos export terminal. There were no casualties.
MEND claimed the incident and stated that it would move on to attack oil facilities in Bayelsa and Rivers states once the oil infrastructure in the Delta state was destroyed.
MEND previously attacked and damaged Chevron's Makaraba-Utonana-Abiteye pipeline, also in Delta state.

summary:
Suspected members of Dagestani Jamaat Sharia attacked a police checkpoint in Makhachkala, Dagestan, Russia. The policemen were conducting an identity check when the armed men began firing automatic weapons. One civilian at the checkpoint was killed.
There have been over 40 attacks in this region of Russia since the beginning of May 2009. A majority of them have targeted police and government facilities and personnel. The most active terrorist organisations are Dagestani Jamaat Sharia and Ingush Jamaat Sharia.

summary:
Suspected members of Ingush Jamaat Sharia attacked the mayor of Nazran's convoy in Nazran. Government sources stated that armed men shot at the convoy and damaged one of the vehicles. There were no injuries. The armed men left the area after firing a few rounds.
Terrorist groups in Ingushetia and Dagestan have increased their activity. This attack illustrates that Ingush Jamaat Sharia is targeting higher profile government officials.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A Qassam rocket hit the beach in Ashkelon, Israel. It was allegedly fired from inside Gaza. No injuries occurred and there was no damage. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
The has been a slight increase in activity around Israel's borders with Gaza. On 8 June a group of approximately ten armed men shot at an Israeli Defence Force patrol (IDF) at the Karni cargo crossing, just north of Nahal Oz, Israel.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A bomb attached to the underside of a car exploded in Dora, Baghdad, Iraq. The car belonged to a member of a pro-government militia. No casualties occurred because the car was empty at the time. However, the car was destroyed.
Although no group claimed responsibility, Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected. The group had carried out previous incidents in the Dora district and commonly targets government supporters and Shi'as throughout Baghdad.

summary:
A bomb exploded in South Waziristan, Pakistan killing three civilians and injuring two others. The civilians were transporting supplies for NATO forces in Afghanistan. Two of the civilians killed were Afghans, the other was Pakistani.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is believed responsible. The TTP targets NATO supply convoys throughout northwestern Pakistan.

summary:
Suspected members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) killed a doctor in West Singhbhum, Jharkhand, India. The doctor practiced medicine in the rural areas of Jharkhand.
The CPI-M often carry out similar acts of intimidation against civilians in rural areas. The group is very active in Jharkhand and Manipur.

specific_target: Shop of Pakistan Muslim League - Nawaz leader and civilians in Pir Market
summary:
A bomb exploded in the Pir Market market in Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan. It killed eight civilians and wounded 50 others. The bomb was hidden in a rickshaw and exploded during the market's busy hours. The bomb was near a shop owned by the Pakistan Muslim League - Nawaz leaders Raja Akhtar Ali. The bomb weighed approximately five kilos.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Tehrik-e-Taliban is suspected. The group carried out attacks on Pakistan Muslim League - Nawaz leaders before. The group is also willing to accept civilians as collateral damage. They frequently target Shi'a civilians.

summary:
Suspected members of the United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA) attempted to bomb the house of a local government official in Imphal East, India. They tried to detonate the explosives, but the explosives failed to explode.
No injuries occurred and there were no damages.
The ULFA operate in the Manipur area and have targeted government officials before.

specific_target: Office of Communist Party of Nepal-Unified Marxist Leninist in Manma
summary:
Members of the Young Communist League (YCL) set fire to the party office of the Communist Party of Nepal-Unified Marxist Leninist in Manma, Nepal. The group also attacked 25 of its members. The YCL stated that they carried out the attack because the people did not follow the strike call given by the the Bheri-Karnali Mukti Morcha.
The YCL is the youth wing of the Communist Party of Nepal. The group's recent attacks have mostly targeted government members and activists against their cause.

summary:
Suspected members of the Taliban set fire to two NATO ambulances being transported along the Kabul-Jalalabad Highway in Afghanistan. The Taliban took the vehicles off road and then set them on fire. There were no casualties, however, the ambulances were destroyed.
The Taliban continue to attack NATO supplies throughout Afghanistan. The group remains very active throughout Afghanistan's border with Pakistan.

summary:
Suspected members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) threw a grenade at a bus in Yala City, Yala, Thailand. The explosion killed one civilian and injured 14 others. The bus was transporting commuters to work on Yala's Keulong Industrial Estate.
There has been an increase in the severity of terrorist attacks in Thailand since May 2009. On 8 June unidentified gunmen killed 11 civilians at a mosque in Narathiwat. It was one of the first attacks targeting a place of worship in the region.

A 1kg bomb exploded in a grocery store in Bacho, Thailand. It injured six civilians in the shop. The bomb was planted by two men who entered the store and pretended to be customers. While they were looking around the shop, it is suspected that they planted the bomb.
Small bombings of shops in southern Thailand are common. Terrorist groups are most active in the southern provinces of Thailand.

summary:
A bomb exploded on a railway track in the Rourkela area of Orissa, India. It destroyed four feet of railway track and caused a goods train to derail. The bombing took place near the Chandiposh railway station. The only civilian on the train, a guard, was not injured.
The Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) is suspected. The group operates in the area and has carried out similar attacks before.
The train route is not used for civilian travel, trains carrying minerals primarily travel along the route.

The CPI-M has increased its attacks targeting police patrols in Jharkhand state. This is the second incident to take place in the area in the past week.

summary:
A remote-controlled bomb exploded in Kohat, Pakistan targeting a police van. It killed one civilian nearby and injured eight policeman. The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected. Police sources say that the van was transporting prisoners at the time of the attack. It is unknown how many prisoners escaped.
The TTP is very active in Kohat and the border areas with Afghanistan. Police personnel and convoys are common targets.

summary:
A mine exploded in Shwak, Paktia, Afghanistan killing three security guards of a road construction company. The guards were travelling along the Khost-Gargiz highway at the time. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident.
Attacks on construction companies and their personnel is common in Afghanistan. The Taliban view those working with the government or foreign forces as legitimate targets for attacks. Since January 2009 there have been 15 attacks on the construction sector.

summary:
Suspected members of Dagestani Jamaat Sharia shot and killed a police major in Makhachkala, Dagestan, Russia. The policeman was on his way into work when the attack occurred.
There has been an increase in attacks in Russia targeting policemen and police facilities. The most afflicted areas are Dagestan and Ingushetia.

The increase in terrorist activity in Dagestan and Ingushetia has primarily targeted policemen and police facilities.

summary:
A suspected member of Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) assassinated a senior Sunni politician outside of the Shawaf mosque in Yarmouk, Mansour, Baghdad. The man walked up to Harith al-Obeidi and shot him. Government sources stated that five men approached Obeidi and asked him about prisoners, as the politician is a member of the human rights committee in parliament. As he spoke with the men, a teenager shot and killed him.
After shooting the politician, the teenager shot at others in the crowd, prompting the guards at the mosque to shoot back. A total of five other civilians died in the cross fire.
Obeidi led the Iraqi Accordance Front, an alliance of Sunni parties that is  parliament's largest Sunni Arab bloc. Nearly 80 members of the Accordance Front  have been murdered in the past two years.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A package bomb was delivered to the General Secuirty Headquarters in Beirut, Lebanon. The bomb contained 200 grams of explosives and was defused after failing to explode because of a technical glitch.
This attempted attack came after the coalition led by Saad al-Hariri, won a parliamentary election on Sunday, defeating an alliance spearheaded by Hezbollah.
Bombs are rarely sent to government buildings although several explosive devices are defused or explode periodically in Lebanon.
source_urls: Al Arabiyah; Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation; ESISC

summary:
An unidentified armed man shot and injured an official of Hizbul Islam in Beled Weyne, Somalia. The attacker was part of a group of armed men who attack the official. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
Hizbul Islam is a terrorist group allied with Al-Shabaab. Both groups are presently fighting the Somali government and the moderate Islamic Courts Union for control of the country. The group usually operates in southern Somalia.

summary: An small explosive partially detonated inside a supermarket in Antananarivo. The bomb caused minor damage. A similar small explosive device was found near a police checkpoint several days later, however, it was disabled before it could detonate. Eight men have been arrested in connection with the bombing, they are all thought to be linked to recently ousted President Marc Ravalomanana.

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated his explosives in the office of the senior cleric of Jaamia Naeemia madrassa in Lahore, Pakistan after Friday prayers. He killed five civilians, including a prominent Muslim cleric openly supportive of the military offensive in Swat. Pakistani security sources indicated that six civilians were wounded.
Senior cleric Sarfraz Naeemi headed a council of 22 Islamic groups opposed to the Taliban. The Jaamia Naeemia madrassa is one of the largest madrassas in the Pakistan and is seen as progressive.
At approximately the same time another suicide bomber attacked a mosque in the Nowshera area. Both bombings are believed to have been carried out by the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). The group previously stated that they would target cities in Pakistan due to the military offensive in Swat.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A suicide bomber drove a pickup truck into a mosque in Nowshera, Pakistan. It killed three civilians and wounded 32 others. The attack took place at approximately the same time as a suicide bombing at another mosque in Lahore.
The mosque was located in an area of Nowshera that houses military personnel.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected. The group previously stated that they would carry out suicide operations in major Pakistani cities in retaliation for the military offensive in Swat.
The TTP had attacked mosques before with suicide bombers.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Suspected members of the United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA) set fire to two bulldozers in the Ngariyan hills district of Imphal East, Manipur, India. The bulldozers were being used in the construction of a police station. The armed men told the construction workers on the site to leave work immediately.
Construction sites in eastern India are occasionally targeted by terrorist groups. The attacks mostly involve setting fire to the equipment.

summary:
Suspected members of the Taliban gassed a girls' school in Esari, Faizabad, Afghanistan. Afghan health sources stated that 24 schoolgirls had been taken to hospital after smelling poisonous gas; a number of them fell unconscious.
The Taliban had previously targeted girls' school with gas in Parwan province. Health officials reported similar symptoms among the schoolgirls. Although no student or teacher has died of the gas attack, a number of them have been taken to hospital.

summary:
A car bomb exploded in Greshk, Helmand, Afghanistan killing eight civilians and injuring 29. The suicide bomber was targeting a civilian convoy carrying supplies for NATO forces. In addition to the casualties, the explosion damaged 12 vehicles. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident.
The Taliban continue to attack NATO convoys throughout Afghanistan. The group is very active in Helmand province.

summary: A bomb exploded in a truck near the Zugdidi police station in Georgia. No one was injured. No group claimed responsibility. The event was part of a series of three bombings in Zugdidi on 11 June. The two other bombs exploded at the main train station. No one was injured.

summary:
A bomb in a rubbish bin exploded in the Zugdidi central railway station in Georgia. No casualties occurred, but there was some damage to the station. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
The bombing took place 15 minutes after a bomb exploded in a railway carriage in the same station. Neither incident caused any casualties.
The bombing is part of a series of three bombs to exploded in Zugdidi. The third bomb exploded in a truck near the town's police station.
Sporadic terrorist incidents take place in Abkhazia. Rarely do these attacks injure any civilians.

summary:
A bomb exploded in a cargo carriage of a goods train in Zugdidi, Georgia. No casualties occurred, however damage to the carriage was reported. The incident took place at Zugdidi's central railway station. No group claimed responsibility.
This is the first of three minor bombings in the Zugdidi area. Although this incident intended to cause property damage and not casualties, the other two bombs were placed in public areas. Despite the bombs placement, neither caused any casualties.
Sporadic terrorist attacks take place in Abkhazia. Rarely do they cause civilian casualties.

summary:
Suspected members of Al-Shabaab assaulted two journalists in Bardheere, Somalia. The journalists worked for Markabley Radio as a reporter and a newscaster. They were beaten by masked men with baseball bats.
After the assault the masked men warned that the other journalists in the town should leave.
Members of the media are frequent targets for Al-Shabaab. On 7 June suspected members of Al-Shabaab assassinated the director of a Mogadishu based radio station, Shabelle media, in Bakara market, Mogadishu.

summary:
Unidentified militants planted a remote-controlled bomb with a motorcycle parked on the roadside of the Quetta-Karachi highway in Wadh Tehsil sub-division of Khuzdar District, Balochistan Province, Pakistan. The attackers detonated the bomb as a security forces vehicle drove past. The explosion killed two of the security personnel and injured 10 others, six FC personnel and four civilians. No group has claimed responsibility, but Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected.
Roadside bombs are a frequently used tactic to target security forces in Pakistan.

summary:
Taliban militants attacked a NATO convoy on the main Kabul-Kandahar highway in Qarabagh district, Ghazni Province, Afghanistan. The militants set eight supply trucks on fire, wounding the security guard who was escorting the convoy. Following the arson attack Taliban seized three of the vehicles but two were recovered after a joint operation by Coalition and Afghan forces.
Supplies convoys have become a frequent target for Taliban as Coalition and Afghan forces continue to try to stabilize the restive provinces. Attacks are particularly active on the Kabul-Kandahar highway.

summary:
Suspected Taliban militants planted a roadside mine that exploded while a vehicle belonging to security guards of a private road construction company drove past. The explosion in the Shapato area of Khyrkut District of Paktika Province, Afghanistan killed two of the guards and wounded four others. The company is engaged in the construction of a road between Khyrkut and Yusof district.
Construction companies and projects have been a consistent target of militants in Afghanistan as they tend to be run by foreign companies.

summary:
A bomb exploded on a train going from Karachi to Quetta near Dozan railway station about 75 kilometres from Quetta near the Bolan pass. One person was killed and 35 injured in this attack.

summary:
Unidentified men shot and killed a senior Malian military intelligence officer in his home in Timbuktu, Mali. Security authorities in Mali believe that Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) carried out the attack because the intelligence officer was behind the arrest of two AQIM members.
AQIM has begun to spread its operations south. The group primarily operates in Algeria, but has now begun conducting operations in Mali and Mauritania. Security sources speculate that AQIM could even push into Western Sahara - taking advantage of its weak central government and security forces.
The most recent AQIM incident in Mali involved their killing of a British national on 30 May 2009. Edwin Dyer was kidnapped in Niger in January 2009 and held in Mali. AQIM wanted the United Kingdom to release Muslim cleric Abu Qatada in exchange for the civilian.

Suspected members of Ingush Jamaat Sharia shot and killed the deputy head of Ingushetia's Supreme Court in Nazran, Russia. Security sources say that the armed men shot Aza Gazgireyeva as she dropped off her children at school. They also injured three civilians outside the school building.
There has been an increase in terrorist activity in Russia in the past month. Over 20 attacks have taken place. Ingush Jamaat Sharia and Dagestani Jamaat Sharia are the two most active groups.

summary:
Ten suspected members of Dagestani Jamaat Sharia attacked a police station in Karabadakhkent, Dagestan, Russia. For one hour they fired machine guns and assault rifles at the station. No casualties occurred, however there was damage to the station.
There has been an increase in terrorist activity in Russia. The most active terrorist groups are Dagestani Jamaat Sharia and Ingush Jamaat Sharia.

summary:
A car bomb exploded in a market in Bathaa, Iraq. It killed 35 civilians and wounded 70 others. The area is a predominately Shi'a district. This is the largest bombing in Iraq since 20 May 2009 when a car bomb exploded near a restaurant in Baghdad, killing 34 and wounding 72.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected to be responsible for the attack. The group frequently uses car bombs and targets Shi'a civilians. However, the group normally does not operate this far south of Baghdad. The group's main area of operations for the past few months has been confined to Baghdad and the northern Diyala Province.

summary:
A known white-supremacist entered the United States Holocaust Museum and opened fire on security guards inside the building. One security guard was killed in the exchange of gunfire and the attacker was seriously wounded by gunfire from other security personnel. The building was evacuated safely and there were no other injuries in the attack.
The man who attacked the building, James Von Brunn, 88, was known to police as he had previously plotted kidnap members of the Federal Reserve Board in 1981 and spent several years in jail. He continued to espouse racist, anti-Semitic views and maintained a website espousing these ideas.
author: Unknown author

summary:
The Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) ambushed a patrol of Central Reserve Police and local police officers in West Singhbhum, Jharkhand, India. The CPI-M exploded a bomb and then began shooting at the patrol. Eleven police officers were killed and six others were wounded.
The CPI-M is very active in Jharkhand. It has carried out over ten attacks in the state in the past two months.

It is unknown if the group will continue to target primarily military, government and security personnel in Algeria or if it will start to target civilians more frequently.

summary:
A suicide car bomb exploded next to the Pearl Continental Hotel, the only five star hotel in Peshawar. It is frequented by foreigners (including aid workers and diplomats) in Peshawar. Three armed men managed to shoot through the building's security cordon before driving a van into the perimeter and detonating roughly 500 kg of explosives near the western wall of the hotel.
Eighteen people were killed and at least 65 others injured. Most of the casualties were hotel employees. The UN agency, UNICEF identified two of its employees as having been killed: one Serbian and another from the Philippines. A Russian UNHCR official was killed and 16 other UNHCR officials were wounded, including a Briton, a Somali and a German. The explosion caused a collapse of a significant portion of the hotel.
The Pearl Continental is owned by the same group which owns the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad, which was severely damaged in a similar attack in September 2008. The Pakistani wing of the Taliban, the Tehrik-e-Taliban (TTP) is thought to be responsible. TTP's leaders have promised revenge attacks on major Pakistani and claimed responsibility for several recent bombings.
On 11 June a previously unknown group called the Abdullal Azzam Shaheed Brigade claimed responsibility for the bombing. A spokesman of the group, Amir Muawiya, spoke to reporters in Kohat city and threatened similar attacks. Muawiya stated that the incident was in retaliation to the current Pakistani offensive in Swat. He also claimed that Abdullal Azzam Shaheed Brigade was behind the attack on the Manawan police training academy and the bombing of NATO transport terminals in Peshawar.
Muawiya is a Pakistani Taliban commander. His group is affiliated with the TTP.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is believed responsible. The TTP often use remote-controlled bombs to target police patrol vans in the North West Frontier Province.

specific_target: Chevron Otunana pumping station in the Niger Delta
summary:
Members of the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) attacked Chevron's Otunana pumping station in the Niger Delta region. The group said that it 'destroyed the station' but it is unknown how.
MEND sent statements claiming the attack to news publications in Nigeria and to some international press agencies. No casualties were reported.
Chevron security officials confirmed the attack.
The group had issued a warning to domestic and international oil workers on 6 June to leave the Niger Delta in 72 hours due to potential attacks on oil facilities. MEND said that it would begin a new offensive entitled Operation Hurricane Piper Alpha on the Nigerian armed forces and the oil industry.

summary:
A group of approximately ten armed men shot at an Israeli Defence Force patrol (IDF) at the Karni cargo crossing, just north of Nahal Oz, Israel. The gunmen were in trucks and leading five horses carrying bombs. Israeli military sources reported that some of the gunmen were trying to plant explosives near the border fence.
It is believed that the armed men planned to detonate a large quantitiy of explosives as a distraction and then kidnap IDF soldiers.
Palestinian health ministry sources confirmed that four of the armed men were killed. None of the Israeli soldiers on patrol were injured.The Army of Islam claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sporadic incidents of terrorism do occasionally take place along Israel's border with Gaza.

summary:
Members of the Izz al-Din al Qassam brigades blew up a bulldozer in Nahal Oz, Israel. No casualties occurred, but the bulldozer was damaged.
This is the second incident to occur in the Nahal Oz area on 8 June. The other involved an attack by unidentified men on an Israeli Defence Post. Palestinian sources say that four of the attackers were killed. There were no casualties on the Israeli side.

specific_target: Civilians at bus terminal in Dora
summary:
A bomb attached to a minibus exploded in the Abu Dshir neighbourhood of Dora, Baghdad. It killed seven civilians and wounded 24 others. The attack reportedly took place at a bus terminal.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) is suspected. The group targets Shi'a civilians and the attack took place in a predominately Shi'a district of southern Baghdad. There have been four bombings in the Dora district in the past two months.
The increase in terrorism in Baghdad and Diyala province could be linked to the anticipated withdrawal of US troops from major cities later in June. Active terrorist groups will want to claim credit for having driven US forces out.

The increase in attacks targeting teachers in Narathiwat prompted security officials to have them escorted by soldiers. This is the second time that a teacher protection unit has come under attack in Thailand.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

The attack on a mosque in Thailand is unprecedented. It is unknown what group is responsible for the incident.

Bakara market is an Islamist fighter stronghold in the Hawl Wadag district. Al-Shabaab is believed responsible.
The attack came after the abduction of a TV Universal station director in Mogadishu. Five journalists have been killed in 2009 so far.

A bomb exploded in Malakand, Pakistan killing two aides of a Muslim leader in Swat and one soldier. The men were aides to Sufi Mohammad, a religious leader who negotiated the failed peace treaty between the government and the Taliban in Swat.
The two aides were arrested and were being transported to Peshawar from Malakand at the time of the incident. 
Military sources suggest that the aides were targeted because they could provide the locations of some terrorist leaders.
The level of terrorism is still high in Pakistan. Terrorist organisations like the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan are carrying out attacks on civilians and government targets in major cities such as Islamabad and Karachi in response to the military offensive.

The group posted a longer claim of responsibility on 11 June. The alleged emir of the group, Ibragim Gadzhidadaev, signed the responsibility claim.

Police believe the attack is part of an intimidation campaign as the government has been using schools to shelter some of the 2.4 million people displaced by the ongoing military operation in Swat since late April. Roughly 200 schools have been destroyed by the TTP during the campaign.

Eyewitnesses said that soon after they left the bank, one bomb went off and, as rescuers attended to victims, a second explosion went off.
No group claimed the attack. The explosions incurred more casualties than any other terrorism incident in the country of the year, however militant and radical activity has been on the rise, especially near the Crimean Peninsula.

They also broke into the NATO supply terminal, shot the security guard and set four trailers of supplies on fire. The armed men abducted the watchman of the terminal at gunpoint.
This was the first attack of this nature for the border town.
The TTP often carry out raids and attacks on NATO terminals and supply convoys throughout Pakistan. A majority of the attacks take place in the early morning.

specific_target: US soldiers at a recruiting centre in Arkansas
summary:
An armed man in a black truck shot two US soldiers outside a US Army Navy Recruiting Centre in Little Rock, Arkansas. One died and the other was wounded.
When police searched his car they found a Massberg rifle, an SKS assault rifle, a semi-automatic handgun and ammunition.
The armed man is believed to have acted alone.
His original name was Carlos Leon Bledsoe but he changed it to Abdul Hakim Mujahid Muhammad after converting to Islam. Sources report that he previously travelled to Yemen after his conversion and was arrested for carrying a fake Somali passport.
During his interrogation Muhammad said that he specifically targeted the soldiers because he was angry at the US Army for attacks against Muslims overseas.
This incident is an example of 'lone wolf' terrorism. Lone wolf terrorists act alone and are not part of a larger groups. They tend to follow extremist ideologies but choose not to rely on or interact with like-minded people. Ted Kaczynski, the Unabomber, is one example of a lone wolf terrorist.

It contained metal shrapnel and glass pieces. Sources say there was no explosion because the batteries were disconnected from the circuit.
A letter signed in the name of the Students' Islamic Movement of India (SIMI) was near the site. The letter was typed in Gujarati and asked people to join SIMI and fight jihad.
The SIMI has transnational links to other terrorist organisations such as Harkat-ul-jihad-l-Islami/ Bangladesh (HUJI-B), Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) and Lashkar-e-Toiba (LeT).

summary:

The students and staff members were reportedly leaving the school for their summer holidays when the attack occurred. They were in a convoy of buses at the time of the attack.
The Taliban were moving the students and staff members to South Waziristan when the Pakistani military intercepted. After a firefight, the military were able to rescue most of the kidnapped students. Another 46 students and two teachers were held by the TTP for several days before being released unharmed on 4 June.
The government-run school trains future army officers. The students are mostly from the Federally Administered Tribal areas and the North West Frontier Province.

summary:
A bomb attached to the underside of a car exploded in Azamiyah, Baghdad, wounding two journalists, a cameraman and a sound engineer with Iraqi State TV. The media crew had finished a story in the Azamiyah district. As they got back into their car and started to drive away, the bomb exploded.
'Sticky Bombs' are small bombs which are fastened or stuck to the underside of a vehicle and are detonated remotely. The tactic has increased in popularity in Baghdad.
This is the second attack targeting media personnel in Iraq on 31 May. The other occurred in Mosul. In that incident one sports broadcaster was killed and two other journalists were injured.
Al-Qaeda in Iraq is suspected.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Al-Qaeda in Iraq is believed responsible.
Journalists are still targeted throughout Iraq by AQI. There were two attacks targeting media personnel in Iraq in May 2009.

Plain-clothes security guards that travel on Iranian flights found the device in a toilet. The plane turned back to Ahvaz for an emergency landing after the bomb was discovered.
The incident came at a time of rising tension in the run up to Iran's presidential elections on 12 June. It was the third successive attack in as many days. The previous incidents were a shooting incident at a campaign office of the Iranian president and a bomb attack on a mosque, both in Zahedan. The mosque bombing was claimed by the Baloch Sunni nationalist group Jundallah.

specific_target: Electoral campaign office of Presdient Ahmadinejad
summary:
A child and two other people were injured when three Gunmen attacked the south-east region election campaign office of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad in Zahedan. The attack came a day after a bomb attack in the city on a Shi'a mosque.
According to the head of the campaign office three men armed with knives and guns arrived on motorbike. They then made threats and tore up billboards. When campaign workers tried to protest, the attackers allegedly pulled out guns and shot at them. Police reportedly arrested the assailants as they tried to escape.
The attacks occurred during a time of heightened political activity across Iran, with just over two weeks before the first round of the presidential election. The attacks also came as a Sunni Balochi militant group, Jundallah, claimed responsibly for the attack on the Zahedan mosque the day before.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

summary:
A suicide bomber detonated an explosive vest inside a Shi'a mosque in Zahedan killing 25 people and wounding 125 others. The attack occurred during evening prayers when the mosque was full of worshippers. The attack is thought to be aimed at disrupting national elections set to occur in June.
A statement was subsequently posted on the Internet on 30 May by the ‘Popular Iranian Resistance Movement', another name used by the group Jundullah, claiming responsibility for the ‘martyrdom operation'.  It said the attack was carried out by Hafiz Abd al-Khaliq al-Malazihi from Sarbaz in Balochistan against the Basij militias who had gathered at the Ali ibn Abu Taleb husseinia to participate in a ceremony that was ‘insulting' to Sunni Muslims.
Iran's Balochistan province has seen terrorist attacks in the past due to the large ethnic Baloch minority in the region seeking greater autonomy.
The attacks occurred during a time of heightened political sensitivity across Iran, with just over two weeks before the first round of the presidential election.

No group claimed the attack but it comes hours after the deputy leader of the Tehrik-e-Taliban claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing in Lahore of 27 May. He warned of future attacks in the coming days in Lahore, Rawalpindi, Islamabad and Multan.
It seems likely that more attacks will follow in the Northwest Frontier Province claiming links to the ongoing government operation in Swat.

specific_target: Electrical pylons, warehouses, Yala Rama Hotel, auto showrooms and a mobile phone tower
summary:
Members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional Coordinate (BRN-C) launched a series of coordinated attacks in Yala with fire bombs and grenade attacks against several establishments.
The attack started off when explosives brought down pylons outside an electricity substation, crippling most of the telephone system and electrical power for the city.
Four warehouses came under arson attack, while a bomb exploded in front of the Yala Rama Hotel at about 04:00, and nearby two grenades were thrown at a cash machine and billboard pole in front of a car showroom. There were further fire attacks on auto showrooms and another pylon used to relay mobile phone signals.
Police report that the explosives were homemade with shrapnel made of steel rods cut into one centimeter pieces. They were set off electronically by remote control, possibly using mobile phones.
Similar attacks took place in February 2007 and July 2005, when the then government pushed through a controversial emergency decree that still holds today.
targets: Civilians/General Public; Tourism/Hospitality; Electricity Infrastructure; Undetermined; Telecommunications

summary:

The first bomb was planted in a drain in front of the government's Economic Bank and was detonated at 09:00. Shortly afterwords, a second bomb exploded near the Forestry Department. Neither attack resulted in any casualties.
The attacks come the day after the state-run newspaper, New Light of Myanmar, reported alleged bombing plots by exiled opposition groups, such as a bomb that had been found aboard a train headed for Naypyidaw.
FDB General Secretary Naing Aung denied the accusations, contending that they were part of government plans to discredit political opposition groups prior to the 2010 elections.

Two missiles were launched in the morning hitting the Kirara area of the city, killing two civilians and wounding seven. During lunchtime another three missiles hit the city; one struck the provincial judicial department building wounding another five civilians. No one has claimed the attack but the Taliban is suspected.
The border region with Pakistan continues to be an unstable area for Afghanistan where much cross-border insurgent activity poses a significant problem to security forces.

The incident occurred within two days of a meeting between the Balkh Governeor and district elders over security cooperation in their areas. Balkh province has not yet experienced the same level of instability as the southern provinces, however over recent months insurgent activity has increased in the north.

summary:
The Pakistani Taliban (TTP) claimed responsibility for an attack on the emergency response building of the Pakistani military in Lahore, Pakistan, killing 30 and wounding 250. Most of the dead were police officers.
The assailants reportedly arrived in a car and fired automatic weapons at the Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) building, before detonating a car bomb that destroyed the police building. The van exploded before it could reach the building and was carrying an estimated 100 kg of explosives.
The offices of Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) as well as the nearby hospital were damaged and cars opposite the building were destroyed.
The leader of the TTP, Baitullah Mehsud, had threatened to target major Pakistani cities if the attacks did not cease. The Pakistani interior minister stated his belief that the TTP were behind the attack, in retaliation for the Pakistani military offensive against them in Swat valley. Police subsequently made two arrests at the scene of the attack.
On 27 March Islamist militants attacked the Pakistani police training centre just outside Lahore, and only a few weeks earlier attacked the Sri Lankan cricket team in the city. Lahore was previously considered a safe haven from Pakistan's violence. It is clear that the militants want to change this perception.

Political leadership, along with security personnel, are the primary targets for Taliban attacks.

The attack comes less than a week after the leader of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) made explicit threats against foreign interests in Saudi Arabia. AQAP has not claimed responsibility for the attack, but it is likely its sympathisers were involved.

Somali gunmen has crossed the border into Kenya before, kidnapping two Italian nuns and five Kenyan government workers in separate incidents, however this is the first kidnapping of a Somali national.
This abduction reflects the range of operation of Al-Shabaab as well as the growing threat posed by the group throughout Eastern Africa. The attack comes at a time when Al-Shabaab is battling government forces to take over the capital, highlighting the group's growing capabilities and confidence.

summary:

It is reported that three of the attackers lured the foot patrol into an area that was then set on fire, when the rest of the attackers opened fire.
At least nine soldiers were killed and at least seven were wounded in the ambush. So far the army claims that one attacker was also killed during the exchange.
Local authorities have called this the most serious attack in recent years. AQIM is suspected.

The second attack took place between 01:00-05:00 at Kabona along the Kaniola-Ihembre road. During the attack one of the guards stationed at Kabona was kidnapped, the area was looted, and the military camp burned to the ground.
FDLR militants have been active in the eastern Congo for decades, involved through their Hutu links and their economic interests in the Kivu province of the DRC. The DRC has struggled to force the militants out of its territory.
There have been reports of threats and dissuading the local population against government military operations to combat the FDLR.
Locals are demanding military and civilian authorities increase the number of soldiers in the region.

Six guards and three civilianswere killed. Up to nine others were injured.
Witnesses reported that the suicide bomber had pale skin. There are believed to be about 300 foreign fighters among the Islamic insurgents but they are mainly of Somali origin. If reports prove true, this would be the first incident of a suicide bombing in Somalia carried out by someone from outside the Somali diaspora. However, Sheik Husein Ali Fidow, a spokesman for the Al-Shabaab militia, said that the attack was carriedout by one of their 'mujahideen', Abdikadir Mohamed Hasan, a young Somali boy born in Mogadishu.
Al-Shabaab has been engaged in battles against government forces in the capital for two weeks and hascaptured key positions from the Somali government.

summary:
Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) militants attacked a Sudanese military base at Umm Baru in northern Darfur, Sudan. During the clash 43 JEM were killed and 54 wounded, while 20 soldiers were killed and 31 wounded. According to Sudanese forces, the JEM forces were supported by 40 artillery tanks from the Chadian forces and about 80 vehicles. The Unamid peacekeeping force had mistakenly reported that the rebels had overrun the military base.
JEM is one of many Islamist rebel groups fighting the Sudanese government in Darfur, known to target the oil industry, particularly Chinese companies. Umm Baru has seen a number of clashes between pro-government forces and JEM fighters over the past two weeks. Tensions along Chad and Sudan's border have been mounting as each accuses the other of supporting rebel groups seeking to topple their respective governments.

summary:

The Nepal Defence Army (a Hindu extremist group) claimed responsibility. The group's intention is reportedly to restore Nepal's Hindu monarchy.
The explosion coincided with preparations for elections, with Nepal's parliament due to elect a new prime minister within hours of the attack. The elections were needed following the resignation of the Maoist leader, Prachanda, earlier in the month following the president's block on him choosing a new army chief.
On 2 June authorities arrested a woman claiming to have left the bag with the bomb in it in the church.

summary:
A bomb exploded near the base of a television relay station in Cantabria, Spain. No casualties occurred. The bomb damaged the station, but it was not severe. Authorities found a note near the station with an ETA symbol on it.
Much speculation has circulated about the future of the terrorist organisation due to a number of high level arrests in Spain and France. ETA's most recent activity in Spain has been the targeting of construction sites and businesses working on the high speed railway which will pass through the Basque area.

summary:
An unknown group attacked Siemens employees on the premises of the Inguri hydropower plant in Abkhazia's Gali District. A vehicle carrying the specialists hit a trip wire that stretched across the road at the end of a tunnel, triggering a grenade. No one was injured. The Gali District chief of internal affairs directorate claimed the blast was a provocation by the Georgian special services specifically timed to coincide with the NATO meetings, but this is unconfirmed.
Abkhazia is a disputed territory. While it declared independence in 1991 during the Georgian-Abkhaz war and functions largely as a de-facto state, the fighting has been ongoing since then. In August 2008 Georgia declared it a Russian-occupied territory.

summary:
Suspected members of Abu Sayyaf attacked Governor Abdusakur Tan's convoy in Jolo on Jolo Island, Philippines. A bomb concealed in a motorcycle exploded as the convoy passed by it and then armed men began shooting automatic weapons. Five security officers were wounded, but the Governor was unharmed.
The convoy was travelling from the provincial capitol building to the Governor's home in Jolo. The Governor makes the trip each day for lunch.
Governor Tan recently ordered a crackdown on Abu Sayyaf on the Island. He played a major role in freeing two of the Red Cross members kidnapped by the group.  The attack comes one week after a similar attack by Abu Sayyaf militants killed the Jolo provincial police chief and three escorts near Maimbung township.
Terrorist groups are very active throughout the Philippines. Kidnappings have become more frequent. The island of Jolo is considered to be an Abu Sayyaf stronghold. Abu Sayyaf has been blamed for numerous kidnappings, bombings and beheadings and is believed to receive funding from Al-Qaeda.

summary:
A car bomb exploded outside the Camp Salerno in Khost, Afghanistan. The suicide bomber killed seven and injured 21 Afghan nationals. A majority of the casualties were local labourers working at the base. No coalition forces were injured.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the incident. The Taliban is currently staging attacks as part of their spring offensive entitled Operation Victory. It has increased attacks such as suicide bombings on coalition troops and government supporters throughout Afghanistan.

Security forces are common targets in the region; Ghazni Province remains a volatile area of Taliban activity in Afghanistan.

Paktika Province is one of the most unstable in Afghanistan and is likely where many of the new additional troops will be deployed this summer.

Attacks targeting supply depots in Peshawar have increased in 2009. A majority of the attacks take place early in the morning and are low in casualty numbers. The supply terminals do not have large numbers of security personnel guarding them.

Heavy fighting has continued in the small coastal area north of Mullaitivu for weeks, with the military claiming to have trapped the LTTE in what is now just four square kilometers of territory. Between 20,000 and 50,000 civilians remain trapped in the area, where the army is believed to still be using heavy artillery and bombing tactics causing high numbers of civilian casualties.

No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Revolutionary Struggle is believed responsible. The group has targeted bank branches before with explosives. They normally phone in the threat and detonate the bomb in the early hours of the morning.

summary:
The Taliban attacked a municipal building in Khost, Afghanistan. Approximately nine suicide bombers raided the building. Four of them detonated their explosives during a firefight with security guards. The other five entered the building and took about 20 hostages.
Sources say that eight of the Taliban disguised themselves in Afghan Army uniforms. One was dressed in a burqa. After a brief siege of the building security forces freed the hostages and killed the Taliban.
The incident was part of a coordinated attack carried out by the Taliban on government and police targets in Khost. The near-simultaneous attacks killed eight and injured 20. Among the dead includes four policemen and four civilians. A total of 18 civilians were injured along with two policemen.

summary:

The incident was part of a coordinated attack of as many as 12 suicide bombings carried out by the Taliban on government and police targets in Khost. The near-simultaneous attacks killed eight and injured 20. Among the dead includes four policemen and four civilians. A total of 18 civilians were injured along with two policemen.
The Taliban warned earlier that they would increase attacks on government officials that work with foreigners. Terrorism remains at a high level in south Afghanistan despite the presence of coalition and Afghan troops.

The CPI-M has kidnapped railway employees before. They were all released without harm on 14 May. The CPI-M has increased attacks in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh since April 2009.

summary:
A remote-controlled bomb detonated on a road linking Diyarbakir and Bingol, Turkey. It targeted a convoy of Turkish soldiers, killing nine and injuring two. No group claimed responsibility, however the PKK is believed responsible. This is one of the largest terrorist attacks on Turkish armed forces since 2008. The car targeted had armour between four to five and a half centimetres thick on its underside; meaning that the bomb had to be powerful enough to render the armour ineffective.
There has been a spike in terrorist activity throughout Turkey since the commencement of major counterterrorism operations in Istanbul, Gaziantep, Sanliurfa, Konya, and Adana. Over 60 people alleged to have connections to terrorist organisations have been arrested.

summary: A pair of car bombs exploded in the Shi'ite Sadr City area of Baghdad. The explosions occurred in a busy market area killing at least 17 people and wounding 45 others. Police defused a third bomb which failed to detonate. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) has, however, been increasingly active over the past few weeks and some sources suggest they are responsible.

summary:
A female suicide bomber attempted to assassinate an ex-Justice Minister at Bilkent University in Ankara, Turkey. However, there was a malfunction and the bomber only injured herself. She was disguised as a female student and attempted to detonate the explosives after trying to ask the former minister a question outside a classroom. She was less than a metre away from him at the time. The ex-minister's bodyguards attacked the bomber once her explosives did not detonate and she drew a weapon.
It is believed that the bomber is linked to the PKK, as the group has been fighting for self-rule in southeast Turkey for over two decades. She had entered Turkey from Bulgaria using a fake identity card.
There has been a spike in terrorist activity throughout Turkey since counterterrorism operations throughout Istanbul and the south led to the arrest of over 60 people.
One other suspect seen on security camera with the bomber was arrested at a bus stop by security forces.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Kongra-Gel (PKK/KGK), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Electrical transformers and mobile telephone signal towers
summary:
Suspected members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional-Coordinate (BRN-C) detonated two explosives next to electrical transformers and set fire to mobile signal towers in Waeng, Narathiwat, Thailand. No injuries occurred. However, the government communication system was disabled. It is unknown how long it will take to repair the damage.
The incident is part of a larger set of attacks which occurred throughout Narathiwat. The unidentified men targeted schools, local homes, electrical transformers and mobile phone towers. The incidents took place the day before the fifth anniversary of the Krue Se massacre. On 28 April 2004 security forces stormed the Krue Se mosque and killed 32 militants. The incident took place during an uprising of Thailand's three southern provinces

summary:
A bomb detonated in Bir el-Ater, Tebessa, Algeria killing one civilian and injuring four others. Among the injured was the mayor of Bir el-Ater. The group of five were hunting in the area at the time the bomb detonated near a gas pipeline. The pipeline travels from Algeria to the Tunisian border and feeds gas to Italy.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb operates in the area. They are very active and frequently target pipelines and government officials.

summary: A bomb detonated in Narino, Colombia as police on patrol passed by. The bomb killed two policemen and injured six others. After the bomb detonated, suspected members of the National Liberation Army (ELN) began to shoot indiscriminately at the patrol. This is ELN's first terrorist attack in 2009. The group primarily operates along the border regions with Venezuela and the rural regions of southern Colombia. Its capabilities have diminished over the years.

summary:
Suspected members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) detonated two bombs simultaneously in two supermarkets in Neiva, Colombia. The bombs caused no casualties, but damaged the supermarkets, the fronts of nearby stores, nearby homes and ten apartment buildings.
One of the bombs was concealed on a motorcycle parked in front of one supermarket. The other bomb was hidden in a telephone booth next to the other store. The bombs both weighed 4 kilos.
FARC continues its transition to targeting more urban areas throughout Colombia. There have been a total of three bombings at commercial outlets in Nieva in the past four months.

The security force's convoy had 11 vehicles and was travelling past a police check-point at the time. A spokesman for the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan claimed responsibility for the incident. The spokesman said that the attack was in retaliation for the US drone strikes. The group frequently attacks security personnel in northwest Pakistan.

summary: Armed men on boats attacked a Shell oil facility in Bayelsa, Nigeria. The armed men commandeered a Defender-class naval vessel, killed one sailor, and injured four civilians. The Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta wrote an email to the Associated Press stating that it was not directly involved in the attack. Sources suggest that the Niger Delta Vigilante Movement is responsible. It is unknown the extent of the damage to the Shell facility.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Police reported that at least four mortar shells exploded overnight in a northern working-class district of Brazzaville. There were no reported casualties. The attack came hours before talks between the ruling party, opposition and civil society groups in the run-up to the July presidential elections, which President Denis Sassour Nguesso is expected to contest.
Human rights activists allege the attack was to put pressure on the politicians to move ahead with the 'republican dialogue' to review the institutional framework of the election, electoral body, and the financing of political parties. Such a forum has been long demanded by civil society groups, the opposition and the clergy.
Others believe the attacks were the work of 'bandits', likely remnants of the civil war militias, known as Ninjas, who are still active in the southern Pool region and have largely resorted to banditry to survive.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Terrorist attacks throughout Baghdad have spiked in March and April of 2009 with AQI responsible for a majority of the attacks on civilians.
author: Unknown author

Sources say the train was carrying commodities from Lumding to Badarpur. The Black Widows targeted the engine and the car carrying railway security personnel. No damage to the train was caused. Terrorist group activity has increased in Assam due to the national elections. The Black Widows and the Communist Party of India - Maoist have become increased the severity and frequency of incidents.

Suspected members of the Karbi Longri National Liberation Front (KLNLF) detonated a bomb on the railway track in Kalahandle, Assam, India. The explosion destroyed 23 feet of railroad track. Railway personnel were in a small train car checking the tracks for bombs when the incident occurred. The railway car derailed but none of the personnel were injured. The Kamrup Express trains were stopped throughout the area.
Various attacks from separatists groups have spiked in recent weeks due to the national election.

specific_target: National Aluminium Company Limited in Koraput
summary:
The Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) attacked the armoury and bauxite mine of the National Aluminium Company Limited in Koraput, Orissa, India. They killed seven security force personnel and took sophisticated arms, ammunition, and explosives from the armoury. Four CPI-M were killed during the gunfight which began during the night and continued into the early morning. Sources say that there were 100 workers in the mine during the attack, but none were injured.
The CPI-M split up into groups and attacked the mine from all sides. One group detonated explosives next to a mobile phone tower on site. This disrupted communication between security personnel. They also planted obstacles on the roads towards the entrance of the mine, preventing vehicles from travelling down it. The mine is Asia's biggest bauxite mine.

They destroyed several NATO vehicles and set fire to ten containers storing supplies for the troops in Afghanistan. No injuries occurred. NATO terminals have been attacked more than ten times by the Taliban causing significant losses of materials. They also have forced NATO to look to store and ship supplies through other neighbouring countries.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a Sunni militia group in Iskandariya and killed nine people and wounded 31 others. The attack occurred as militiamen from the local Awakening council were waiting to collect their salaries at an army post in Iskandariya, south of Baghdad. The suicide bomber was wearing a belt of explosives, which he detonated after mingling with militiamen.
Awakening councils are former Sunni insurgent groups who are now sponsored to enforce the peace in local areas. They have been instrumental in routing Al-Qaeda from many Sunni regions and are a prime Al-Qaeda target
The attack came at a time when relations between the councils and Iraq's Shi'a-led government - which formally took control of the Awakening movement on 1 April - have worsened in recent weeks. The arrest of a leader of one of the councils in Baghdad the previous month sparked violence between militiamen and government forces.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) killed five Central Reserve Police Force officers and injured three others in an ambush in Jharkhand. The attack happened only a few hours before the Congress party chief Sonia Gandhi was due to address an election rally in the area.
The CPI-M has called for a boycott of the general election in the state and has stepped up its attacks ahead of the polls that begin next week.
The attack happened in the forested Khunti district, 10km from where Gandhi was due to address the rally.

summary:
A suicide bomber drove a truck laden with explosives into an Iraqi police station in Mosul, killing seven in total, including five US troops and two Iraqi soldiers. The attack alsoinjured two US soldiers, 27 civilians and 43 security force personnel.
The truck reportedly veered sharply into thefence around the location and then into the sandbagged defences of thebase, now occupiedby a contingent of US soldiers.
The Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility on 13 April.

According to reports, more than 125 Maoists armed with AK-47s fired at a team of central reserve police force patrolling the forested Chintagufa area, about 445 km (275 miles) south of Raipur, capital of Chhattisgarh state.

summary:
A man was killed and two others were injured in a bomb blast in Bannu. The target was a jirga (an assembly of tribal elders), which was reportedly underway when the blast occurred.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) has repeatedly struck at tribal leaders opposed to them, so as to undermine the capability of local tribes to resist their influence.
The attack happened around the same time the TTP extended the ceasefire in Darra Adam Khel for ten more days. According to reports, the TTP announced the extension during a jirga with five local tribes at an undisclosed location. The TTP also authorised local elders to hold talks with the government.

The rebels, believed to be affiliated to the BlackWidows,fired indiscriminately at the Barak ValleyExpresstrain as it approached Wadrendisa train station in North Cachar.
The Black Widows are fighting for an independent homeland state in Assam. Last year, the rebels set fire to several railway stations and attacked railway employees in North Cachar, forcing theauthorities to halt train services for a number of days before they were resumed with heavy security.

summary:
Police in Plaka, Athens, Greece defused a bomb left in a rucksack in the Mitropoli Orthodox Cathedral. The bomb consisted of gas canisters, petrol, a clock and a battery. This is the first incident which targeted a religious site in Greece.
Police received an anonymous tip off about the bomb at 14:10. Warning calls were also made to the newspaper Eleftherotypia and the Skai media network. The caller said the bomb would detonate in 45 minutes. It is believed to be related to a bomb left in the Aghia Triada Church in Piraeus. No group claimed responsibility for either incident.

summary:
A bomb planted at the Aghia Triada Church in Piraeus, Athens, Greece partially exploded and caught fire. The homemade bomb was in a rucksack and consisted of two gas canisters, petrol, and a detonator. Sources say only the detonator exploded. There were no casualties. A priest at the church extinguished the fire before any damages were caused. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
This was the first time a religious facility was targeted in Greece. It is believed to be connected to the bomb left at the Mitropoli Orthodox Cathedral in Plaka also on 9 April.

summary:
Shining Path rebels ambushed a Peruvian army patrol in the jungle in Sanabamba in the southeast of the country. In the first attack of two, one soldier was killed and at least three were injured.
The attacks were reported on Saturday 11 April by the Peruvian Ministry of Defence. Peruvian Prime Minister Yehude Simon characterised the attacks 'as the desperate last acts of a nearly defeated movement'.
Shining Path has re-emerged in recent years as a deadly group, killing some 25 members of the security forces in ambushes and gun battles. It is believed to consist of a few hundred fighters who didn't lay down their arms after the group's leader declared an end to their revolutionary violence in 1992.

summary:
A bomb attack in Jayapura, west Papua province killed five men and injured several others. The attack followed the bombing of a bridge nearby the day previous. Police reported that both bomb attacks used TNT, and moreover forensic evidence supported the assertion that the attacks were linked, likely done by the same people.
No group claimed responsibility but police believed the bombs were linked to the elections, and blamed the series of attacks on separatists linked to the Free Papua Movement (OPM) who aimed to disrupt the elections.

summary:
The Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) blew up a school building in Palamau district in India's eastern state of Jharkhand, taking the total number of government buildings destroyed to 10 in different districts within a week.
According to reports, about a dozen armed CPI-M reached the Belhra high school at Bishrampur, placed dynamite in the rooms and blew them up. The attack occurred at night and no one was hurt.
The CPI-M left a note at the spot claiming responsibility for the attack. Earlier, the groups had blown up schools, panchayat and community bhavans in Latehar, Gumla, Chatra and Palamau, apparently with the aim of preventing security forces taking shelter there during security operations ahead of the first phase of local polls, due on 16 April.
The CPI-M had also reportedly burnt two campaigning vehicles in Palamau and Garwah in the previous three days, police said.

summary:
A bomb concealed in a plastic bag detonated in Kadhimiyah, Baghdad, Iraq near the tomb of Imam Mousa al-Kazim. It killed seven and wounded 23. The plastic bag also contained screws and nails. Sources indicate that the attacker may have not been able to pass through security checkpoints, so he left the bag and ran off before the bomb could detonate.
The pedestrian-only area is filled with jewelry and clothing shops. The tomb is one of the most important religious sites in Baghdad; al-Kazim is one of 12 Shi'a saints. Al-Qaeda in Iraq is believed responsible but did not claim responsibility. There has been a surge in bombings throughout Baghdad since 5 April.

Rise International is a USAID-funded project that collaborates with the Pakistan education department. The team worked in conjunction with the 18 union councils of Manshera and created Parent Teacher Associations at the village level. Rise International said they did not receive any threats prior to the attack.
A majority of the attacks targeting humanitarian organisations and NGOs in Pakistan have taken place along the Afghan-Pakistan border. Peshawar and its surrounding areas are the most afflicted regions.

Allegedly the woman carried a backpack with explosives in it. She was shot dead by Israeli police. No casualties occurred.
No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however groups such as Fatah, Hamas and Hezbollah all claim to have female units. Female terrorist attacks in Israel are rare, however, female suicide bombers are known to have strategic advantages as they can more easily evade invasive security checks.

specific_target: President Karzai's brother - President of the Provincial Council
summary:
Members of the Taliban attacked the provincial council offices in Kandahar, Afghanistan killing 13 and wounding 14. Those dead included Kandahar's head of the education department and deputy head of the health department, five police officers and six civilians. They were attending a seminar by the American group The National Democratic Institute. No one from the group was injured.
Sources say that the attack was an attempt to kill President Karzai's brother- the President of the Provincial Council.
First a car bomb first exploded outside the council office building. After which a suicide bomber rushed inside and detonated an explosive vest. Three men in Afghan police uniforms then went inside and began firing automatic weapons indiscriminately. The three were shot by police before they could inflict any damage.
Police claimed they killed two other suicide bombers before they managed to get inside the building. Other sources indicate that the men were able to detonate.
The attack resembles the Taliban attack on another Afghan government building on 30 March 2009 in Andar. In that incident a Taliban suicide bomber also wearing a police uniform detonated inside Kandahar's district headquarters.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
source_urls: Associated Press (Lexis Nexis); Afghan Islamic Press news agency, Peshewar (BBC Monitoring)
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

The TTP seized the house and detonated explosives, causing severe damage. The former minister and his family were not home at the time of the assault. The TTP frequently target past and present government officials who disagree with their policies in the North West Frontier Province as well as in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas.

Sources indicate the TTP fired two rockets at the van, set it on fire, and then fired their weapons indiscriminately at it. Police are common targets in the North West Frontier Province. Attacks on mobile police units are becoming more frequent in the area.

No group claimed responsibility, however the Balochistan Liberation Army is suspected. They have carried out similar attacks in the area. Gas pipeline in Balochistan are common targets for separatist groups.

specific_target: Transmission power lines near Sher Garh
summary:
Unidentified men detonated explosives next to power transmission lines near Sher Garh, Pakistan. No casualties occurred. Damages to Tower No. 54 and 55 of the 132-KV Mardan Dargai Transmission Line disrupted power supplies to other power stations in Chakdara, Swat, Khawaza Kehla, Madain, Taimergara, Dargai, Bajaur and Daggar Grid Stations. Alternative power sources restored the electricity in the area, but they are unable to manage the high demand for electricity alone for a significant time frame. According to sources, the damages may take weeks to repair.
The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is suspected. This incident may signal that the TTP will incorporate attacks on critical infrastructure facilities to their repertoire in order to disrupt any government control left in the northwest.
author: Unknown author

summary:
Several armed men kidnapped two Dutch tourists from Sanaa. The hostages were taken out of the city and are believed to be held in Bani Dhibyan, an inaccessible mountainous area southeast of Sanaa. The kidnappers have demanded the release of several tribesmen currently being held by the Yemeni government. Many of the tribes in Yemen are known to have links with Al-Qaeda.
The couple were released on Monday 13 April. Conditions of their released are not available.

summary:
Approximately eleven armed men wearing police uniforms threw grenades and fired automatic weapons indiscriminately at the Manawan Police Academy in the outskirts of Lahore, Pakistan. They killed eight policemen and two civilians and injured 95. The armed men entered the compound and took an unknown number of hostages. Around 850 police recruits attend the training centre and were conducting morning exercises at the time.
On 24 March sources indicated that the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan leader Baitullah Mehsud dispatched 20 foreign militants, mostly Uzbeks, to carry out terrorist attacks in major cities in Pakistan. Mehsud claimed responsibility for the incident on 31 March. He stated that it was in retaliation for the continued drone strikes by the US in collaboration with Pakistan.
The eight hour siege ended when Pakistani security forces stormed the facility. A total of eight gunmen were killed and three others were arrested. The gunmen were holed up on the top floor of the three-story building.
author: Unknown author

summary:
At about 15:00 a group of terrorists targeted elements from the Gendarmerie in Tamazirt, south of Ahnif municipality in Algeria. According to sources a group of terrorists hid a home-made bomb on the edge of the road in Tamazirt then detonated it as the first vehicle of the gendarmes passed by. These gendarmes provide security for the Chinese company CITIC-CRCC, responsible for building El-Adjiba road east of Bouria.
Three of the gendarmes were slightly wounded. Sources report that one of the terrorists responsible for detonating the bomb was killed in the explosion. His and his group's identity are still unknown, but Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb is believed responsible. Attacks on foreign interests particularly in construction and infrastructure are common behaviour of violent reactionary groups in North Africa.
