Around 100 members of the Communist Party of India - Maoist (CPI-M) attacked a police station, a nearby rest house and the control room of a communications tower in Malkangiri. They attacked the police station and rest house with a bulldozer they had stolen from a road construction site.
They then set fire to the control room of a tower belonging to Bharat Sanchar Nigam. The watchman and another person were injured.
Shortly after the incident CPI-M members put up posters in the area, asking people to boycott the general elections scheduled for April 2009. They warned that those taking part in them would be punished.

No group claimed responsibility, however the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) often targets shops that do not follow their rules stating what can and cannot be sold in the area. The incident occurred at night, suggesting that the target was not the civilians who frequent the bazaars but the shops selling the merchandise.

summary:

The construction workers were completing a project on Victoria Island, located in Lagos and one of Nigeria's busiest business districts. While kidnappings are more common in the Niger Delta, they are rare in Lagos. No group claimed responsibility.
The Lebanese hostage was freed on 30 March during a police ambush disguised as a ransom payment. Six rebels were killed in the operation and the ransom payment of $230,000 was fully recovered.

summary:
Bomb disposal experts disabled a car-bomb outside the Lev Hamifratzshopping mall in Haifa. Police had been called to the sceneafter a small explosion was heard frominside a parked white Subaru at 20:30. It is likely that this wasintended to detonate the rest of the explosives but failed.A police spokesman said the car was loaded with about 200 poundsof explosivessurrounded by ball bearings. The car is registered as belonging to a female resident of Jerusalem. The mall, which also houses a train station and is adjacent to a bus terminal, was evacuated as a precaution.
The Ahrar Al Jalil (Free People of Galilee) claimed responsibility for planting the bomb and said in a statement that the charge did not go off due to a technical failure. The group stated that this attack is one of a series of operations that will be carried out in retaliation against the demolition of Palestinian homes in Jerusalem and Israeli actions in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

summary:
Armed men shot dead two Israeli traffic policemen near the Israeli town of Nablus on 15 March.The attack occurred in the Massua district of the Jordan valley. When emergency responders arrived, the police car was reportedly turned over. One of the policemen was dead at the scene and the other died after a failed resuscitation attempt.
The attack was the first fatal attack on an Israeli in the West Bank since April 2008. The Nablus area had been relatively calm recently with the last violent incident in January 2009.
A previously unheard of group, The Imad Mughniyeh Group, claimed responsibility for the attack. However, a Palestinian Al-Qaeda faction also claimed responsibility several days later and it is unclear whether the groups are connected or one in the same. The group refers to itself as a unit of the al-Malhamah Brigades, the military wing of the World Islamic Front for the Liberation of the Al-Aqsa Mosuqe/Al-Aqsa Army. They claim the attack was launched as a response to a call issued by Osama bin Laden urging attacks to be launched on Israel from inside Jordan.
Hezbollah had vowed revenge for the killing of Imad Mughniyeh, one of its top military commanders. It believes that Israel killed Mughniyeh. Israel has always denied involvement in the killing.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: The Imad Mughniyeh Group, perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A suicide bomber from Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) killed five people, including four South Korean tourists, when he detonated his explosives in the touristic site of Shibam in Hadramout, Yemen. Two South Korean tourists were also injured.
The bomb detonated as the tourists' vehicle passed by the UN world heritage site. A Yemeni man was also reportedly killed in the attack.
AQAP claimed responsibility on 27 March on an Internet forum. Their statement claims the operation was a response to 'the command of the prophet to expel the polytheists from the Arabian Peninsula'. It also says that the attack was in retaliation to South Korea's role in Afghanistan and Iraq.
There is increasing concern that Yemen is becoming a base for Islamist terrorism in the region. Jund-al Yemen brigades recently announced their merger with Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP). There have been a series of attacks against Westerners recently, including the September 2008 double car-bombing targeting the US Embassy in Sana'a.
Yemen released 176 men suspectedofties to theAQAP terroristin February on condition of good behaviour.

summary:

The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) are suspected, but have not claimed responsibility.
The Sri Lankan armed forces continue to site progress in eradicating the LTTE, however, the group regularly attacks civilians throughout the country. Suicide bombings are frequently carried out by the LTTE.

He was responding to a 999 emergency call from a female who said a street gang had shattered a window of her home. He later died of his injuries. This incident occurred within 48 hours of an attack on the Massereene barracks in Antrim. The area is considered a strong hold for the Continuity IRA.
In a statement claiming responsibility for the incident, the group said 'As long as there is British involvement in Ireland, these attacks will continue.'

specific_target: Pakistani civilians accused of spying for the US
summary:
The Taliban executed three civilians accused of being US spies in South Waziristan, Pakistan. One civilian was found in Wana with a DVD showing him confessing to providing information to US officials which led to US missile attacks. The two others were found with similar DVDs. All had notes with their bodies, stating that similar attacks will happen for those spying for the US.
The Taliban often target civilians who they believe have aided the US. The group is extending their stronghold over the North West Frontier Province and the Federally Administered Tribal Areas. Waziristan is often used as a cross-over point for the Taliban to travel into Afghanistan to carry out attacks on NATO and coalition forces.

specific_target: A police academy and police officers
summary:
A suicide bomber killed 30 people and wounded 58 others when he attacked a police recruitment centre on Palestine Street in Baghdad. The attack happened at in the middle of a crowd queuing outside the police academy.
Sources suggest the bomber detonated his explosives belt as he crashed his motorbike into a line of people waiting at the side entrance to the training centre. Most of the dead were police recruits, while others were serving officers and civilians.
Palestine Street was closed to vehicles for two years for security reasons. However, one lane reopened in late 2008 with no stopping allowed.
Dozens of candidates gather at the academy on days when the police authorities announce a recruitment drive. They queue to pick up application forms.
This was the deadliest suicide attack reported in Iraq for almost a month. Police academies across Iraq have come under repeated attack by Al-Qaeda and other insurgent groups.
On 11 March the Islamic State of Iraq claimed responsibility for the incident.
targets: Law Enforcement/Internal Security Forces; Public Spaces
author: Unknown author

summary:
Members of the Real IRA killed two British soldiers and seriously wounded two others as well as two Polish pizza deliverymen in an attack at the Massereene barracks near Antrim, Northern Ireland.
According to reports, earlier in the evening, soldiers at the base had ordered pizza from Domino's Pizza in nearby Antrim. Two men left the shop in cars at about 21:20 GMT to make the delivery. When they arrived at the main gate of the barracks just off Randalstown Road, some 20 minutes later, four soldiers came out to collect the food. As they did so, two gunmen in a Vauxhall Cavalier car parked nearby opened fire with semi-automatic rifles. After the initial volley of gunfire, the attackers then approached their victims, who were lying on the ground, and shot them again.
The attack is the first major terrorist attack in the province for more than a decade and the first time British soldiers have been killed in Northern Ireland by terrorists since 1997. The attack followed a series of warnings by security chiefs over the previous six months that dissident republicans were reorganising and increasing their capability to launch attacks. The Real IRA called a local Dublin based newspaper and used a recognised code word to claim responsibility for the incident.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Real IRA, perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A car bomb killed eight people, mostly police and soldiers, in Badaber, Pakistan. Police said they died after being lured to a booby-trapped car on the outskirts of Peshawar, the capital of North West Frontier Province.
The local police received an anonymous tip-off that there was a body in a car on a highway near Badaber. When police examined the car the explosives in it detonated. Five of the dead were police officers and two were paramilitary soldiers. A passer-by was also killed. Five others were injured. The bombing is said to have occurred on a route between the Khyber tribal agency and city of Peshawar. Authorities reported that the bomb weighted approximately 30 kg and was detonated via remote control. There was no claim of responsibility although the Taliban is suspected.

summary:
A group of men wearing masks lit fire to a subway train after forcing people off of it in Kifissia, Athens. The arsonists wore carnival masks and used Molotov cocktails and gasoline to spread the fire. The damage was reportedly in the millions of Euros and includes six train carriages. But, there were no casualties.
Two groups claimed responsibilty for the incident: a group calling itself Gangs of Conscience and the Conspiracy of Fire Nuclei.
In a message posted on the Internet, the Gangs of Conscience said it carried out the attack in revenge for the assault on a union head who had acid thrown in her face.
Far left-wing groups in Greece frequently use arson as a tactic.
author: Unknown author

summary:
At least 12 gunmen ambushed a convoy of vehicles carrying the Sri Lankan National cricket team early on the morning of 3 March in Lahore's Liberty Square. The attackers fired RPGs to stop the convoy, then converged on the vehicles with heavy fire from assault rifles from four directions. An RPG round was fired at the team bus directly, but missed. Grenades were also rolled under the bus, but failed to detonate. A 20 minute exchange of fire with Pakistani security forces ensued.
Bomb disposal units defused two car bombs and recovered grenades and three kilograms (6.6 pounds) of explosives. In the attack, at least five Pakistani policemen and one official were killed. Eight members of the Sri Lankan team were injured. Two cricket officials were also injured.
The attack occurred as the players were en route to resume play on the third day of the second Test match at Lahore's Gaddafi stadium. The attack was relatively sophisticated in nature, and was carried out by well-trained men. Although no group has claimed responsibility and none of the attackers were apprehended or killed, officials suspect that it bears strong resemblances to tactics used by the Lashkar-e-Tobia (LeT) who are linked to the November 2008 Mumbai attacks.
On 4 March police arrested approximately 24 suspects from the Lahore area. Their identity had not been released.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Lashkar-e-Toiba (LeT), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:

A simultaneous attack occurred at Chandiposh, which lies on a nearby branch line. The attacks coincided with the start of a 24 hour general strike organised by Naxalites in northeastern India.

specific_target: Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC) crude pipeline
summary: Unidentified gunmen attacked and damaged the 24-inch Trans-Escravos oil pipeline in three places between Ogulagha and Warri in southwest Nigeria. The pipeline line belongs to Shell operated firm Escravos. Due to the explosion, Shell was forced to suspend its operations in the North and South Bank and along the Forcados Terminal crude line. This shut down could result in the loss of 70,000 barrels per day. No group claimed responsibility, though the Movement for the Emancipation of Nigeria (MEND) have increased their attacks on oil employees and infrastructure in recent weeks.

summary:

Global Intifada had previously set fire to the stores in Sodertalje in December 2008 and January 2009 that sold American goods and urged people to follow their example. The group is thought to have staged firebomb attacks against military and diplomatic targets in 2006 as well.

summary:
A bomb detonated outside a café in front of the Al-Hussein hotel in the Khan al-Khalili area of Cairo, Egypt. It killed one 17 year old French girl and injured 24 others. Those injured included 17 tourists from France, one from Germany, three from Saudi Arabia, and three from Egypt. One French male was in critical condition in hospital. Authorities defused a second bomb that did not explode. Initial reports indicated that the bombs were thrown by men on motorcycles or were dropped from the hotel balcony above the cafe. However, authorities stated their belief that the bombs were placed under a nearby bench. The explosives were reportedly home-made.
The café was full of French adolescents who were on a school-trip at the time of the attack. It is located in a medieval area near the historic Al Hussein Mosque. The market is a 'must see' according to some Cairo tourist books and is noted for its goods and outdoor coffee shops. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, but Islamist terrorists have targeted foreign tourists in areas like Cairo before and in September last year gunmen in the far south of the country kidnapped a group of ten foreigners, mostly Germans and Italians, who were on a tour of a remote desert region. Tourism is very important for the Egyptian economy and targeting it is a way of getting at the government. Authorities believe that the French students were not specifically targeted in this attack, but that it was rather a random attack on tourism in general.
Egyptian authorities arrested three male suspects. Their identity has not yet been disclosed.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Al-Qaeda (AQ), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

specific_target: Sri Lankan Air Force installation in Colombo
summary:
Sri Lankan anti-aircraft guns shot down a plane near the International Airport just north of Colombo in Katunayake, Sri Lanka. The intended target was a Sri Lankan Air Force base nearby. No injuries were reported from this incident, however, this was part of a dual suicide mission by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) targeting Sri Lankan Air Force installations in Colombo. Another plane was shot down and crashed into the Inland Revenue Service in Colombo injuring 40 and killing one. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) claimed the attack on their website.
Authorities shut off the electricity in the city when one plane was spotted on radar flying down the east coast of the country. Authorities closed the airport following the attack.
Air Force spokesman Wing Commander Janaka Nanayakkara confirmed the raid was a suicide mission aimed at the two air force installations, but said that the planes were hit by anti-aircraft guns and missed their targets.  At least one of the planes had 130kg of explosives in it.
The LTTE have used light planes before, mostly the Czech-made Zlin-143 aircraft. Previous targets the LTTE have attacked with planes in 2008 include military and navy bases in the north-west of the country. The planes were believed to be smuggled into the country in pieces and then reassembled.
source_urls: BBC NEws, Hindustan Times, Times of India
perpetrators: Sri Lanka:Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE):Nationalist/Separatist

specific_target: Sri Lankan Air Force installation in Colombo
summary:
Anti-aircraft guns shot down a plane which crashed into the Sri Lankan Inland Revenue Building in Colombo. It killed one and injured 40 others. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) claimed the attack on their website. The Inland Revenue Building is near the Air Force Headquarters, the intended target of the pilots. The LTTE said the planes intentionally crashed as part of a suicide mission targeting two Sri Lankan Air Force installations.
Air Force spokesman Wing Commander Janaka Nanayakkara confirmed the raid was a suicide mission aimed at the two installations, but said that the planes were hit by anti-aircraft guns and missed their targets. At least one of the planes had 130kg of explosives in it.
This incident was part of dual attack on the city. Another plane was shot down near the International Airport in Katunayake. Authorities shut off the electricity in the city after a plane was spotted on the radar.
The LTTE have used light planes before, mostly the Czech-made Zlin-143 aircraft. Previous targets the LTTE have attacked with aircraft in 2008 include military and navy bases in the north-west of the country. The planes were believed to be smuggled into the country in pieces and then reassembled.

specific_target: Deputy Chief of Nong Chik police
summary:
A bomb weighing over 15kg exploded at about 08:40 on Ban Prang-Thayamu road, Pattani, as a three-car police convoy travelled past. The bomb was triggered by a detonating cord buried under the road. The police were returning to Nong Chik police station after escorting teachers to a local school. The last vehicle in the convoy, a pick-up truck containing four officers, was thrown into a roadside ditch. The explosion left a 10cm-deep crater in the road.
The attack killed three policemen and critically injured another. One of the dead was the Deputy Chief of Nong Chik police station. The authorities believe the killing of Pol Lt-Col Yuttakarn Pienpo signals a change of tactics by insurgents to target more high-ranking officers so as to lift the profile of their operations.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A bomb on a bicycle detonated as provincial lawmaker Alam Zeb Khan passed by in his car on Dalla Zak Road in Peshawar, Pakistan. The bomb destroyed the car and left Zeb in critical condition and injured seven others. He later died of his wounds. Khan was also a member of the Awami National Party. Investigators have reported that the explosives used in the attack were similar to the material which caused recent blasts in Peshawar.
The incident occurred shortly after US envoy Richard Holbrooke visited the city. The Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the incident and said they will continue such attacks on Awami National Party leaders in the future.
author: Unknown author

summary:
A car bomb planted by ETA detonated outside a convention centre in the Campo de las Naciones district of Madrid. After a caller informed the Red Cross at 07:37 about the bomb next to the Ferrovial-Agroman building, authorities began evacuating the area. The bomb which used 80kg of explosives damaged nearby offices of the Spanish infrastructure group which owns Heathrow, Gatwick and a series of other British airports within the BAA group. The group was targeted due to its involvement with a high-speed train link through the Basque Country. No injuries were reported.
Later reports indicate that ETA issued three different warnings: one to the Red Cross, one to firefighters, and another to the Spanish Secret Services. The bomb left a three metre crater in the ground despite that not all of the explosives went off. Material damages amounted to 30 cars, a bridge, and buildings nearby. The van used had been robbed the night before in the suburb of Pozuelo de Alarcon.
source_urls: The Times online; Gaceta de los Negocios (Factiva)

summary:
Unidentified men kidnapped the head of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees (UNHCR) for Balochistan in an ambush in Quetta, Pakistan. The driver of the UN vehicle was killed. They were on their way to the UNHCR office at the time from the officer's home in the Chaman Housing Scheme. The armed men fired on the vehicle, which then went out of control and crashed into a wall. Foreigners are rarely kidnapped in this area of Pakistan.
A previously unknown group called the Balochistan Liberation United Front claimed responsibility for the incident on 7 February. They issued a statement on 1 March that they would kill the UN employee in four days if the Pakistani government did not release more than 1,000 prisoners.
On 4 April John Solecki was found with his hands and feet bound alongside the Quetta-Karachi highway, roughly 30 miles south of Quetta. He was unharmed.
author: Unknown author

summary:
In a pre-dawn encounter, two suspected Pakistani terrorists trying to enter Delhi from Ghaziabad were killed and a member of Uttar Pradesh's Anti-Terrorism Squad was injured. The incident occurred a day before the Republic Day celebrations.
The incident took place at 02:35 hours at sector 97 near UNITECH after the alleged terrorists, travelling in a white Maruti car, opened fire on the Anti-Terrorism Squad team, leading to an exchange of fire between the two sides.
Additional Director General of Police said one of the terrorists, while being taken to hospital identified himself as a resident of Okara in Pakistan, and his companion said he was from Rawalakot in Pakistan-administered Kashmir. The authorities recovered two AK-47 assault rifles, four magazines, 120 rounds of ammunition, five hand-grenades, nine suspected RDX rods, detonators, a Pakistani passport and 18,000 rupees ($USD360).

The incident, late on Thursday night, happened in a village near the town of Balad Ruz, north of Baghdad, in the province of Diyala. The area has seen some of the worst recent violence with security forces and tribal militiamen fighting Sunni insurgents reportedly tied to Al-Qaeda.

summary:
Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) kidnapped a group of European tourists from Bani-Bangou, Niger. They have been identified as one German national, one British national, and two Swiss nationals. They were returning from a festival of nomad culture at Anderamboukane on the border between Niger and Mali.
AQIM claimed responsibility on 17 February and said that they 'reserve the right to deal with the captives under Islamic sharia law'. Moctar Ben Moctar, one of the leaders of AQIM, is holding the foreigners and is demanding the release of two Mauritian members currently held in prison.
One of the Swiss nationals and the German national were relased near the northern Mali-Niger border on 22 April along with two Canadians who had been held for several months. Malian authorities had been negotiating their release for several months. The British and other Swiss hostage remain with AQIM.
On 26 April AQIM released a statement which said they will execute the British hostage unless the UK released Sheikh Abou Qutada al-Filistini in the next 20 days. Al-Filistini is also known as Omar Mahmoud Othman or Abu Omar. He is a Jordan native connected to Al-Qaeda who is wanted on terrorism charges in several European countries.
On 2 June Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb claimed it had executed the British national. He has been identified as Edwin Dyer. The foreign office and the Prime Minister said that there was 'strong reason to believe' that the cell carried out its threat. In a statement posted on a jihadi website, the group said it killed the British national on 31 May.
On 11 July the Swiss national was released by the group.
perpetrators: Algeria:Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM):Global Islamist

summary:
At least three Katyusha rockets were fired from Lebanon into the northern Israeli area of Nahariya. One of the rockets struck a nursing home, injuring two people. Israeli cabinet minister Raid Eitan stated that Palestinians in Lebanon, not Hezbollah, were behind the attack. Nahariya is five miles south of Lebanon.
No group claimed responsibility for the attacks. However, on 24 July 2009, an Al-Qaeda linked group, the Abdullah Azzam Brigades, released a video on the Internet that documented a rocket attack they claim they carried out against an Israeli army installation from southern Lebanon.  It is unclear if that video documents these attacks, although Lebanese officials stated a Palestinian terrorist group was reponsible.

summary:
Sandinista militants linked to Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega's administration attacked a protest being held by the Liberal Party opposition in La Concepcion with mortar explosives. The demonstration was being held to protest the allegedly fraudulent national municipal elections of November. At least two people were reported injured from the attack, which ultimately resulted in a clash between the two groups.
Several such instances of political violence have been reported in Nicaragua since the November elcetions, indicating heightening political tensions and public opposition to Ortega.

summary: Members of the Tuareg group threw grenades at the homes of two government officials in Gao, Mali. A servant was killed in the home of a local official and a man was wounded in the house of a member of Parliament. One of the attackers died when a grenade exploded in his hand before he could throw it.
author: Unknown author

summary: Armed men attacked and killed eight people at a Central Reserve Police Force camp in Rampur, India. Seven of those killed were CRPF non-commissioned officers. The civilian killed appeared to be a rickshaw puller. Additionally, there were two people wounded. The attackers were armed with AK-47 rifles and grenades. No group claimed responsibility for the incident.

summary: Suspected members of the United Liberation Front Assam (ULFA) planted 3 bombs in Guwahati, India. The first bomb detonated near Lokopriya Gopinath Bordoloi TB Hospital at 14:35, injuring five. The second bomb attached to a bicycle detonated at the Bhootnath market, killing two and injuring 25. The third and final detonated at 17:45 in the Bhangaghar area of the city, 200m from the Times of India office, killing three and injuring 34. The ULFA has not claimed responsibility for the incident but is suspected in the attack. The bombings occurred on the day the Home Minister was scheduled to visit the area.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA), perpetrator_type: Nationalist/Separatist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Suspected members of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) shot T. Maheswaran, a member of Parliament in a Hindu temple in Kotahena, Colombo, Sri Lanka. A security officer for the MP was also killed and 12 others were injured.
